Der blev sagt, at der skulle gå 1200-et-eller-andet dage, før jeg bragte temaerne omkring mere fairness i den frie bevægelighed op i Europa Parlamentet, og det er jo rigtigt i den forstand, at det er første gang, jeg optræder i Europa Parlamentet. Jeg har jo heller ikke været inviteret før, jeg er ikke medlem, så jeg har jo ikke rigtig haft mulighed for at komme lige her før. Men det er jo ikke et rigtigt billede at tegne, at der ikke har været arbejdet med den sag, og hele denne sag handler jo altså om, hvordan vi – inden for visionen om den frie bevægelighed – sikrer, at befolkningen føler rimelighed, og at vi undgår løntrykkeri, social dumping, noget af det vi har set på den dansk-tyske grænse. Det har der været arbejdet med, og det er jo rigtigt, hr. Vistisen, at vi jo ikke har haft den store succes. Jeg var selv glad ved, at vi op til den britiske folkeafstemning jo rent faktisk begyndte at nå nogle resultater. For under indtryk af en britisk folkeafstemning om brexit eller remain lykkedes det jo faktisk i Rådet at lave et kompromis, som betød – under den forudsætning, at briterne stemte remain – at nogle af de danske prioriteter, f. eks omkring indekseringen af børnechecken, kunne sættes igennem. Det er jo sådan set bare en ekstra grund til at beklage udkommet af den britiske folkeafstemning, og jeg bliver nødt til at sige, også i dette rum, at vi kommer til at genbesøge nogle af disse spørgsmål. Og det bør vi jo gøre allerede i forbindelse med forordning 883, hvor jeg har noteret mig, at der nu er opbakning her i Parlamentet til, at der kommer en generaldebat i Parlamentet om den forordning. For vi skal finde de balancer, der gør, at vores befolkninger stadigvæk omfavner den frie bevægelighed. Og det gør de ikke, hvis man optjener retten til dagpenge allerede efter én dag. Det gør de ikke, hvis man kan hjemsende en børnecheck, der modsvarer mere end en månedsløn, til børn, der bor i et andet land, hvor leveomkostningerne er langt lavere end i f.eks Danmark. Og her er der en kæmpe opgave for Parlamentet, som jeg håber, man vil gribe ud efter. Jeg har jo lyttet nok til debatten allerede nu til at kunne konstatere, at der jo ikke i Parlamentet er konsensus om alting, men der ligger en vigtig opgave for Parlamentet her.  Så kunne jeg godt have lyst til at sige en bemærkning omkring de spørgsmål og kommentarer, der har været rejst fra forskellige sider, om en europæisk hær, den nye sikkerhedspolitisk situation, etc.  We are living in a different security situation, that goes without saying: a more aggressive Putin to the East – and I totally share what the Vice-President said about Russia’s aggression in Ukraine – but it’s not only about Russia, it’s also about what we experience in the Middle East, in Turkey, a US President who is not as engaged in world policy as one perhaps could wish, and we have to respond to this. But we have to respond to this in a clever way, and introducing this vision of a European army as something very operational, something that is kind of in competition with NATO, that’s not, at least in my opinion, the right way to respond. We need to uphold this strong transatlantic defence cooperation. With the UK leaving the European Union, I think the rest of us together will represent less than 20% of NATO’s total capacity. So the idea that we should, among ourselves, be able to do something which can compete with the NATO alliance, that’s not a good idea, but that’s not what is proposed either. So I think we should be careful in the way we use words. My perspective is that it is absolutely necessary that Europe steps up – it’s about spending but it’s also about closer cooperation. But by doing so we have to be sure that we do not duplicate capacity that already exists in the NATO framework. So we should stick to the idea of added value, and that’s not a European army in the sense that I think people will interpret the idea if you just say ‘a European army’. It’s all about closer cooperation in the defence industry, it’s about closer cooperation when we, for instance, go in and stabilise things after wars in neighbouring countries. And the reason why I have called for a debate in Denmark about this defence opt-out is exactly this. We are known as a country who always participates and steps up. This is the case for aid: we haven’t reduced our aid actually, due to the growth in our economy our aid budget is increasing year on year. We are always ready to contribute soldiers to the NATO framework, and if we develop in the future a different division of labour between NATO and Europe, then it will be from my perspective a disaster if Danish soldiers wearing a NATO cap can do the tough missions but then if we turn the tough missions into soft missions and stabilise nations – talking about nation-building within the European framework – then Danish soldiers have to return home. That’s exactly why I raised this debate about a possible referendum sometime in the future about this defence opt-out. Not joining a European army under the leadership of Juncker, as was said, but a stronger cooperation between national defence capacities within the European Union. Given the time, I think I should bring this to a conclusion and just respond perhaps to one very concrete question about the Nord Stream, which is in my eyes, or in my opinion, linked to this discussion about the new security situation in Europe. And that’s why I have been asking again and again and again – and I really hope that the Parliament will give a big push towards this – for us to discuss this infrastructure project at a European level, because it is definitely a project which comes with some geopolitical implications as well. And honestly speaking, I must say that I think it shouldn’t be up to Denmark, squeezed in between countries who have already given a clear ‘yes’ to this line, to take the final decision. So what we need is a European answer to that challenge. I think I will limit myself to these short comments and I’m looking forward to this catch-the-eye element. (Applause)

name: Bendt BENDTSEN
text: Mr President! First of all, I would like to thank the Prime Minister for a fine speech, thank you for the vision that lies specifically on climate, sustainability, energy. To see the Prime Minister like that was attacked a little domestically, we have to take that as it comes. Now there is a tradition, in this Chamber, that when we have prime ministers from Denmark, they are attacked by the Danish People's Party. Well, to what I would say about climate, sustainability and the like: I am pleased with the moments that came in the speech today. There is a place where I would like to know if the Prime Minister agrees. It is about europe's building stock. We use 40% of our energy in our houses, 75% of Europe's buildings are energy inefficient, so we need to get something done about the existing building stock in order to achieve the climate targets. That is why there are now long-term plans for EU Member States to increase the renovation rate of our buildings in Europe, so that we can also achieve the climate targets, while at the same time being the cheapest way to cut CO2 at all. And once again welcome!

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Mr President, Prime Minister - I'm waiting for you to put on your headphones, I'll speak in my language, at least for celebrating a hundred years. Prime Minister, I have tried to be present at all the presentations made by all the Heads of State and Government, because I want to understand what vision and future of Europe the Council wants, the Heads of State and Government want. I must admit that from your speech I understand that you make it very clear that Denmark has its way, that you want the eight exceptions further, that at the same time you want labour mobility, but you are talking about social dumping. The only country that can dump it is Denmark, if you receive a worker from my country and do not pay it on the salary in Denmark. Also, also contradictory, you say that you want to listen to citizens and be solidarity, but you are talking about child benefit, which should be deducted because they are citizens of other countries who come to you. Frankly, I want to ask you very concretely, you have not told us anything: what is your vision for the new multiannual financial framework? You have not told us anything: what is your vision for the mobility package, very important things that concern us. You have not told us anything: how do you see the future of Europe, whether to put conditionality on the rule of law? Of course, you are not afraid of a resolution: my country had a resolution. Unfair, actually.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: – Mr President, I would like to say to the Prime Minister: you mentioned Brexit and I would like to take you up on the subject. Today the UK’s economic institutions have projected the impact of Brexit on the British economy, and it is a disaster. Less known is the fact that there will also be a significant impact on the European economy. You mentioned that there were numerous referenda in Denmark, that there were special deals for Denmark, there were opt-outs for Denmark. On 8 December the British Parliament will decide on the new deal. It is possible that the new deal will be rejected. Mr Prime Minister, this would be your hour because you could lean on Brussels and make sure that Brussels offers Britain a new deal. A new deal, possibly, on freedom of movement, which will enable the remainers to get some more dynamic support in Britain, and it will offer the Brexiteers a face-saving way out. So it increases the chances of a second referendum. I think one thing we can learn from Denmark: a democracy which ceases to learn, ceases to be a democracy.

name: Morten PETERSEN
text: Mr President! Thank you to the Prime Minister and welcome here to the European Parliament. Not surprisingly, I fully agree that the EU is of course the way forward for Denmark, that the EU is incredibly important for Denmark's future. However, an offensive Danish EU policy requires the EU to be given priority in Denmark. It is not doing enough at the moment in my opinion. Let me give you a few examples: Danish ministers are among the least diligent when it comes to appearing in the EU Council of Ministers, according to a study for the think tank EUROPA. Denmark has no strong partners in the EU, according to a study for the European Council on Foreign Relations. The missing friends mean Denmark is struggling under its weight class on the EU stage, the study states. And Denmark could be a green power that pulled the EU in an even greener direction, if we wanted to. That is why my call to the Prime Minister here today is that Denmark is seeking the real common solutions to the real problems. My call to the Prime Minister will be for Denmark to refrain from the bilateral initiatives with Austria in the field of refugees and to seek the real common solutions to the common problems we face together.

name: Margrete AUKEN
text: Mr President! Welcome here, Prime Minister, and thank you for the speech – if it held everything together, Then I think I could agree with most of it. I have one point that is extremely close to my heart. A very strong value in the European Community is humanism. And it is great to hear that you are adamant that Denmark should also sign the treaty in Marrakesh, that you do not let yourself be pressured. However, I must say that I am very disturbed to hear that you may not resist the pressure to introduce a new principle into our asylum policy, namely a scrub-by-principle. Instead of telling people that when they've come here and been here for a while, and the kids are here and so on, they can have a life. Children can have a life. Then there is now a tendency, unfortunately, in Denmark to say that those who are here on some form of refugee status, they must return home. I hope it will not be a Danish position, and I hope in particular that it will not be a European position and that you will go ahead with it, but it is very frightening if we come together and come together first and foremost to build great walls, border controls and then say scrub off to the people who come here and who, of course, also have – yes sorry – the right to a life.

name: Rina Ronja KARI
text: Mr President! And welcome to the European Parliament, Prime Minister. I have listened with particular interest to your words about listening to the citizens. For there is indeed a need to listen to the citizens and take them on advice and make sure that they are the focus. That's why I'm surprised you so categorically reject referendums. This is precisely where we can clarify what the citizens' position is. Now it may be that you have some kind of special ability so that you can anticipate what the citizens think, but frankly, the only way we can make sure is actually in a referendum. That is why I am concerned when you talk about Denmark being part of a banking union, but completely refuse to ask citizens what they think of the banking union. Or as when you talk today about us having more trade agreements, despite the fact that they face great resistance, precisely because they restrict our democracy and because they expose core parts of our welfare, to being destroyed. That's why, Prime Minister, now get serious of your own words, ask the public what their own position is, hold a referendum. Thanks!

name: David COBURN
text: – Mr President, George Orwell said if you want a picture of the future, imagine a boot stamping on a human face forever. The EU has tried to stamp the jackboot down on Britain with this recent so-called Brexit deal for democratically daring to leave. An attempted enslavement of the very nation that fought the Nazis and liberated Europe. The EU is supposed to be about government by consent, not force. I asked the Parliament when we voted on an arrangement for Lake Lugano’s Italian-Swiss border why the same arrangement could not be made for Northern Ireland. No answer. Well it is because the EU are using the tragedy of Ulster as a bargaining chip. Well that’s not government by consent with friends. In reality, I tried in vain to explain to Mr Barnier that the UK constitution explicitly forbids one Parliament binding another. The deal must be fair to stick. Well, he obviously hasn’t got that message through – obviously I got it wrong. When the Brexit deal fails in the UK Parliament and we have a World Trade Organisation deal, a totally liberated UK economy will take on a command economy – Europe – and we will win. We will see that happen. A potentially despotic EU army controlled by unelected bureaucrats, more EU isolationism and regulation. Crazy immigration, a false currency, mass unemployment as you isolate your greatest trading partner, London, the financial centre of the world with which you can never compete. The future of Europe is one of a division like the Berlin Wall. On one side we will have those countries outside the EU, particularly in the Anglosphere and its free enterprise, which will prosper and grow as it always has. On the other side will be a command economy – the EU. Once again plunged into poverty, darkness and held back from real progress like the Soviet Union. It is the EU folly, along with the absence of a proper relationship which will cause Europe to collapse. We should try to part amicably as friends. Orwell’s picture of the future is probably accurate. The EU, however, should not think too soon, that theirs is the boot rather than the face.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Everyone in this House is free to say what they think. I hope that his prophecies will not come true because otherwise we would all sink. But I do not believe that we will sink and, indeed, I hope that all of us will be able to live for a long time.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Mr President, Prime Minister, welcome. The way in which we deal with today's problems also prejudges future developments. On the basis of this reality, I will ask you two questions. Firstly, what is your position on tackling the serious problem of illegal immigration? You mentioned earlier that redistributing those seeking political asylum is not the solution. Are you in favour of the view that illegal immigrants should remain in the countries of entry? In other words, should Italy and - above all - my country, Greece, bear the brunt of the wrong and tragic mistakes of the European Union, which has solved this problem, and become permanent camps for unhappy and impoverished people?  The second question concerns the principle of unanimity. Do you consider that the abolition of this principle and - in fact - the obsolescence of the power of the vote of small countries, as is yours, which will create a two- and three-speed Europe, is the ideal model and instrument for the creation of the Europe of the future as envisioned by those who love their country and their nation?

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: Mr President! Dear Prime Minister, dear Lars, welcome here to the European Parliament. Although we don't agree on everything in politics, I think it's great to see the prime minister of his country here. I am also very glad that you emphasized this with freedom of movement and fair movement when you told me about the situation with the drivers down in Padborg. But I'd like to get you to try and unfold it a little more – what do you imagine we can actually do to solve this? We are talking about the European Union in the future: what can we do in the social field? Are you in favour, for example, of a social protocol that can equate workers' rights and freedom of movement? It's a way of doing it, even if it's not straightforward. It's a very important matter for us. I think it is quite crucial for us to resolve these issues, to get the public's support for us to remain strongly committed to our European cooperation, so I am very excited to hear your views on that.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: – Prime Minister, i would like to thank you for your excellent work. Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking I want to make three short thesis because of the limited speaking time. I hope that the Prime Minister will make a question about them.  Firstly, I feel that the biggest opponents of the European Union are, however, among the Euro-enthusiasts. Those who do not see defects, those who do not see shortcomings, those who do not see obstacles, at the end of the day must lead to a collision. Opponents on the far left or far right recognize perfectly, know what they want and can deal with them.  The second point is seeing the flaws. A good inventory is just a chance for success. On the other hand, we lack the tools to emerge from this crisis, in short. And the third, last thesis. Today we are not standing still, as some theorists claim. We either march or even run, but unfortunately in place. And this is worse than standing, because standing, we do not waste energy. Unfortunately, we waste energy without improving our condition.

name: Ramón JÁUREGUI ATONDO
text: – Mr Prime Minister, twenty prime ministers of the European Union have already passed through this plenary hall. Everyone has said very important things about the future of Europe, but if a common denominator were to be established, a common value of what they have said is that we face challenges so great that we can only face them together.  If there was a phrase that could sum it up well, it would be something like "we must do better what we can only do together." Under this idea, the European Parliament has been expressing the call for two fundamental problems to be overcome for the future of Europe.  The first is that more contributions need to be made to the financial framework over the next seven years. Is your country ready to make more economic contributions for a Europe that has to face all these challenges that I was talking about?  And, second problem: unanimity. Is your country willing and in favour of overcoming unanimity to establish absolute majorities that allow us to be more agile, more flexible, more effective in addressing the challenges of the future of the Union?

name: Morten LØKKEGAARD
text: Mr President! Welcome, Prime Minister, welcome Lars. Also from the Liberal side. And thank you to all my distinguished Danish colleagues for starting the election campaign here in the room, I think it is nice to be reminded that we are now in the running.  I would like to point out that what concerns me a great deal – I am not going to repeat some of the many questions and comments and issues that have been raised, which are also campaign topics – but just point out that much of a debate that is taking place, which is of little concern, is a debate which, of course – and you can also hear this illustrated here – is a debate about more or less. There are also a few of my colleagues who, as has been the question of more or less the European Union, are a mistake – completely flawed premise of a conversation, so I would like you, Prime Minister, to perhaps say a few words about the fact that it might really be about a better European Union. , and not more or less the EU. If you could do that a little, because I think the debate deserves that before everyone goes into the usual self-t struggle to make it a matter of more or less the European Union.  I think it is quite right to point out that we have a special obligation in this House, because we are in a situation precisely in the Council where what is going on is not necessarily very helpful. So if you could perhaps elaborate on the situation that is, to be able to make it clear, including to other Members of the House here, that we have a special obligation to make sure that that debate does not go completely off the rails.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: " Prime Minister, very grateful for your very consistent position on the Danish country, we are truly jealous and jealous of certain things – that you are independent on some issues today.  However, first of all, I would like to ask you. I come from Lithuania, from one Baltic country. We, as baltic states, are quite active and loyal to those common principles in the European Union.  First of all, what would you do in our place when our standard of living – and you know for what, because we had other neighbors and our other past for 60 years – when our country's standard of living is low and when our companies cannot pay those drivers a salary like you are trying to tell us? Secondly, what would you do when the major countries in the European Union bypass the common agreements and supply gas through Nord Stream I, Nord Stream II? What would you do when our neighbor constantly, every time, threatens, and we are scared every night that there would be no kind of invasion, what happened, what happened in the forty-first year? I very much congratulate you on your having gained independence in the forty-five, but we only received it in the 90 first year.  So, Prime Minister, if you say "I don't know", I will be very pleased.

name: Jens ROHDE
text: Mr President! Well, I too would like to say welcome, Prime Minister. When you hear Anders Vistisen's speech to you, it will probably surprise a lot in this house that they are the ones you share a political duvet with on a daily basis. You may be quite concerned that you are actually suffering from Stockholm syndrome, but otherwise I would say that we, the Radical Left, are, after all, an open-minded party, and we are also asylum-friendly, so if the Prime Minister is going to need help one day, we would be happy to discuss it.  As one of those who usually criticises you, I would like to acknowledge both the fact that you are here today and also the government's position on the Marrakesh Treaty, despite internal displays and pressure from the Danish People's Party not to sign it, and for support for us to start discussing defence policy in the EU. Even your speech today was about what we should be doing in the EU, instead of us constantly in Denmark talking about what we should not. But four points of fix are not resolved if we want to build support for European cooperation. It requires coherence in defence and security policy, common tax base, so that we can put an end to all the cheating that is going on in the financial sector, common migration rules – what is the government doing to unblock the situation that is in the Council at the moment when things are locked into the asylum package? It also requires social equality, a certain social equality if we are to have support for freedom of movement. Then it requires the defence of democracy and the rule of law, and then it requires that we have some children's rights in the European Union. And there I would like to ask the Prime Minister: what is the Danish Government doing in the Council to promote these matters?  The Prime Minister says you have to put your head to the ground and listen to the people, yes, but that's fine, Churchill just replied when he was told to put his ear down more, that "then it's more difficult for people to look up to me." I would like the Danish Prime Minister to get a little more up in the Danish EU debate instead of always lying on the floor with the Danish People's Party. But thank you for the attendance here today.

name: Liisa JAAKONSAARI
text: – Mr President, you, Prime Minister, said that we must listen to the citizens. I am sure we do it every day, we MEPs. You also said that we should report on what has been achieved. That's what we're doing. But I do not believe that past achievements will ever win more support, but we must be able to find solutions to today's hot issues and we must have some idea of the future.  One of these things is immigration. This has been discussed here today, but unfortunately I have to say that Denmark is not good enough here, for example, because you lack humanism. You have pragmatism, but there is hardly any humanism. But I believe that what you said by putting Africa at the heart of your speech is the core issue. Yes, Africa is a matter of destiny for the European Union.  Together, we really need to reflect on all the things that can help Africa and see it as a partner and not just as a target for development aid. We need that, too.

name: Liisa JAAKONSAARI
text: Prime Minister of Denmark. Mr President! Thank you so much for the many comments, the many questions, many of them from Danish committed Members of the European Parliament. I shall try to answer as much as possible.  In relation to the green transition, Bendt Bendtsen has mentioned – and I think that is wise – that you should also reach for the low hanging fruits, and they are of course to get hold of. And there is no doubt that greater efforts towards energy efficiency and energy refurbishment are part of it. There is therefore much that can be done if all Europeans washed at 10 degrees lower than what we normally do, then it corresponds to the total capacity of all German a-power stations – that is, if we washed at 30 degrees instead of 40 degrees – and similarly, in the case of energy renovation, similar calculations can be made. It just goes to show that we have to use all the instruments in the green transition, and what you are pointing to, Bendt, is one of them.  Then I would like to say to Grapini, who creates an image that I should be against, that people who work in Denmark, for example, do not have the same rights as Danes who work in Denmark. It's not. what I say! It is clear that if you come to Denmark and you have your children with you, you must be able to work and live under the same conditions as all sorts of others. I am talking about the fact that you do not have your children with you and where the Danish children's cheque, which is thus intended to cover the costs of having children in Danish society, is sent to other countries where the cost of living is much lower and the money therefore goes further. That is the situation I am talking about.  Grapini also asked about my views on MFF, and it could be a very long lecture. I would just like to say quite briefly that under a reasonable framework, 1% of GNP, which will be an increasing budget, given that there is growth in Europe, our priorities will be to invest in new areas. It is, among other things, development, research, innovation, but it is also – to make a point on the very last question from the Finnish MEP – a more holistic effort in relation to the whole challenge of migration in all forms, and several have mentioned it: Margrethe Auken has mentioned it, Jens Rohde suggests it, several others have mentioned it. And I think the time has come when we need to talk about these things in a context and be a little clear when we talk about these things. For there is an extreme difference between a young African who, quite naturally, one might say, seeks happiness in a prosperous Europe in order to improve his life situation, and so the individual persecuted, who is genuinely on the run, versus the internal movement in Europe in a labour market. And there is a tendency in the debate – possibly not here, but then elsewhere where I participate in the debate – to mix it all together in a big bulb ouster.  I am a staunch supporter of freedom of movement in Europe. Denmark will not be able to function unless we had the privilege of drawing on labour that comes from elsewhere. Sometimes there are also some problems. I am very much in favour of us taking action in relation to and combat, in relation to and safeguarding people who are on the run. That is why I am proud to come from a country where we, like only a handful of countries around the world, are increasing the UN target of 0.7 in development aid. That is why we need to develop – and Mr Rohde is asking what we are going to do in the Council – we need to develop a comprehensive strategy that is not just about protecting the external borders, which is not just about making development aid in Africa, which is not just about supporting a truly free market economy in Africa. with the potential to develop, in a reflection of Europe, an African internal market. But it can't just be about that. It's got to be about everything at once, and that's the only way we get everyone on board. That is also why I have the view, in relation to Mr Morten Helveg and others who have raised the issue of reallocation and solidarity, that we have to work on a basis of reality, and the reality is that it is not possible to reform the Dublin system based on compulsory reallocation. That is not to say, it will not, it will divide Europe. And then, on the basis of pragmatically, we will have to discuss what we are putting in place. What can be put in place is, after all, another form of committed solidarity, which is not just about welcoming people on the run, but which is about and making a different contribution in a different way elsewhere. Because if we do not get any progress in the development of this concept, which is both about protecting Europe and reaching out to Africa, and which is also about ensuring temporary access to the people who are temporarily fleeing something, an opportunity and return, then we will not have to deal with the overall challenge, which is huge, huge, and perhaps in fact the greatest we face.  I must say to Ronja about referendum and democracy: Danish participation in the European Union is based on not just one but several referenda. After the Danish people's 'no' vote on Maastricht, a national compromise was then reached in Denmark, which was also put to a referendum, and that is where our reservations rest. And it goes without saying that if the conditions on which the Danes have agreed in the Maastricht Treaty are to be changed, then of course a referendum is needed. However, this cannot be edenth to the view that any adjustment to cooperation, which is not covered by the Danish opt-outs, would require a referendum. I do not subscribe to the view that we should have this year's referendum to decide whether we still want to be part of it. I also say this as a remark to Hekel and the reflections on a new deal, if and if a decision is not reached in the British House of Commons to support the agreement that has been reached, and Denmark should bid in here and say that we will just find another solution. In my reading of it, the agreement that Theresa May has reached is to compare with what we did in Denmark when the Danes back around Maastricht said no to Maastricht, namely that we defined our national bid for the circumstances under which we can then have a relationship. We went to a referendum on that and we won that and it will not be a viable path if it is to be renegotiated successively. So I think I have to say that I am in line with Juncker and all colleagues in the Council who have said that now there has been a long complicated process in which every comma in a very, very complicated agreement has been reversed. It is like the construction that is on the table, and that is the one that has to be decided.  I would like to conclude by saying, perhaps, when the Lithuanian MEMBER asks me how I would look at things, from, for example, a Lithuanian perspective, in the light of the fact that there are differences in living standards. And it is also an answer to Christel Schaldemose and others who have touched on the issue of freedom of movement and the fairness of things – Jens Rohde also, Mr. Morten Lykkegaard also. Basically, as a precondition for freedom of movement, it is a question of making sure that when you move somewhere else, you are acting on the same terms, under the same conditions as those that were already there – that is, when we talk about pay and employment. If you look at Denmark as a showcase here, you have to say that where we are challenged is not where people move into Denmark for shorter or longer and say, "I'm taking a job here". If we look at their level of coverage collectively, it is almost on a par with the Danes in general, that is not where the problems arise. Problems occur in relation to service, problems occur in relation to transport. And the problems we've seen lately are just the link to it. We have to do something about that and do something about it, and we have to attack that in concrete terms, and parliament also has a job to do here. After all, it is a question of guarding against the fact that you can use mailbox companies to win some rights to cross borders in reality. It's about making some demands on what pay conditions you can drive around. It is about making sure that there are not many exceptions to the general services directive in relation to the transport sector. It is, of course, a very practical piece of work that needs to be done and on which we must work together if we are to secure the support of the people. Because my own reading of the Danish people is that it is not against freedom of movement, it is against situations where people find that, under the guise of freedom of movement, people are in fact being offered wages and conditions that we would not agree to take on our own bodies. That is what it is all about, and it is a piece of practical work that needs to be done.  Then I think I will just finish by saying thank you to Jens Rohde for the nice words. And then perhaps one thing about the UN paper, the global migration pact, which is not a treaty and is not a Marrakesh treaty, but which is a UN paper which will then be discussed in Marrakesh. And I just want to try and put it into context to finish on. There is no point in introducing international cooperation, where the standard will be that of participation only if everyone thinks the same as oneself. And that is a bit of a shadow that I think is being cast into the European landscape, at least in a trend, and which you also see. at a few of the speeches here today. We want it the way we want it, or we don't want to be part of it. This is against the whole concept, and I am, of course, talking into a topical Danish debate, but I am also speaking into a European debate. The European Union is a dream, but it is also a reality, something we must deal with in practical terms. And there is no point in dividing us into the camps where we either have to praise the whole project with all its glories, because otherwise you are probably not a true European and you have to criticise everything. We need to take a balanced approach to it, that when we talk about cross-border problems and about lifting European prosperity, even in a global competition that is becoming sharper and sharper with an increasingly self-aware China, with a United States that turns its back to itself to some extent, then cooperation is needed! And there we all have an obligation to get that dialogue going with our citizens, where we say – because I think we all understand it – that if everything is going to be our own solution, then there will be nothing to cooperate on. That is the heavy task, and it is also where I think – and i would therefore like to thank you for coming here today – that the whole idea of trying to launch a European debate with Europeans at national level and anchored in this House has something to do. It is not done with it, we must also deliver on the specific content, but we need to start where we are told that there is no alternative to cooperation, other than that we turn into ourselves and slide backwards in terms of prosperity, etc. And with those words, I would like to thank you very much, Mr President, for having to be here today.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Thank you very much, Prime Minister Rasmussen. Thank you for your participation in this very important debate on the future of the European Union.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – If we are to reflect on the Future of Europe, we must take stock of what we have achieved. European citizens enjoy freedom of movement in the biggest single market in the world, education opportunities under the Erasmus programme; and solidarity in times of crisis. Nevertheless, the unity of our union is put into question. I believe we need to learn to live in this new environment, where the European idea will be under attack and it will need to compete with other less liberal and less globalist ideas for the future of the European continent. What is more important, we need to learn to defend the European idea, by providing real solutions to the public’s fears like migration, security and climate change while upholding the values our Union is based on. In the physical world, strengthening the Schengen area, the eurozone and the accession of the Western Balkans will ensure security and stability for our continent. In the digital world, in spite of setting the highest existing standard for data protection with GDPR, Europe should also be a digital frontrunner with investments in new technologies and innovations, and ethical AI.

name: Pirkko RUOHONEN-LERNER
text: Written. – Over the past few years, the European Parliament has held a number of debates on billion-dollar cases of tax evasion and money laundering. This autumn there has been a money laundering scandal at Danske Bank in Denmark. Up to EUR 200 billion worth of money was laud in the Estonian unit of the Danish bank. The first tip on criminal activity came from the Central Bank of Russia as early as 2007, but it was allowed to continue for years to come. No one was willing to intervene in criminal activity and there was total failure to monitor money laundering.  The whistleblower of the case, The Briton Howard Wilkinson, appeared before parliament's Special Committee on Financial Crimes, Tax Fraud and Tax Avoidance at the end of November. According to the evidence provided by Mr Wilkinson, the Danish Financial Supervisory Authority has deliberately turned a blind eye to the problems and even felt obliged to help the bank in its home country in its difficult situation. It is certainly not the supervisory authority's job to help the bank in its own country, but to monitor it. If the information provided by Mr Wilkinson is correct, the activities of the Financial Supervisory Authority appear to be unskilled, if not corrupt.  The fight against money laundering, the activities of public authorities and the exchange of information between countries must be stepped up. Hopefully, Prime Minister Rasmussen and his colleagues will do everything in their power to ensure that this does not happen again in any EU country. When crimes are detected in the banking world, it is the duty of the supervisory authorities in particular to intervene immediately.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The next item is the debate on the Commission statement on the strategy for long-term EU greenhouse gas emissions reduction in accordance with the Paris agreement (2018/2941(RSP)). We have two Commissioners with us this evening. You are both very welcome. I will now give the floor to Vice—President Šefčovič, who is also responsible for the energy union.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, under this mandate we focused primarily on what needs to be done for the clean energy transition between now and 2030, and by the end of it, also thanks to the great cooperation we had with this House, we will have delivered on all our commitments. The policies put in place will go a long way even after 2030, but they will only bring us to emission reductions of around 60% by 2050, and this is not sufficient for the EU to contribute to the Paris Agreement temperature goals. Climate change is already impacting on the European Union. We had extreme heat waves in four of the last five years and this summer temperatures in the Arctic Circle were five degrees higher than normal. Central Europe was so dry that the Rhine was in places too shallow for inland navigation. And this is just the beginning: a planet with a climate that’s out of control would not be a safe and prosperous home, and we have to act. Today we are therefore looking further ahead towards 2050 and towards a climate-neutral Europe, not only to contribute but to lead on the Paris goals. The Commission is responding to a call by this Parliament from last October which was renewed last month. In March the European Council also called on the Commission to present a long-term strategy by the first quarter of 2019, taking into account national plans. Parliament called for an ambitious mid-century zero emission strategy for the EU, providing a cost-efficient pathway towards a net zero carbon economy in the Union by 2050 at the latest. The Commission has taken up this challenge and we are starting from a good basis: we have reduced emissions by 22% while our economy grew by 58% since 1990 and this was accomplished by investing in clean energies, energy efficiency, innovation and cleaner transport. We have seen that this not only produces benefits for the environment and therefore for the citizens, but that it also creates growth and jobs. Four million green jobs already exist in the European Union. Under this Commission we have learned how to better integrate climate, energy, transport and other policies into the energy union and we are the world leader in designing coherent policies that drive investment, and investment that delivers results. The strategy we are presenting today builds on this comprehensive approach. The strategy looks at all the key economic sectors, at innovation, finance, agriculture, the circular economy, trade... in short, how to make climate neutrality a cornerstone of a modern European economy fit for the 21st Century that will leave the planet clean. Climate neutrality in 2050 will require additional investment – EUR 175 to 290 billion a year – but it will drastically reduce our bill for fossil fuel imports, which today is EUR 266 billion a year. The mathematics are clear, instead of paying to burn fuels that pollute our climate and our air, we can invest in cleaner and modern European industries that provide good local jobs. I’m particularly proud of one aspect. It’s a strategy that makes sure that we do not leave any Europeans or any regions behind. It analyses which sectors will benefit, which will transform and which will lose out, and it looks into how to mitigate these losses, especially through upskilling for higher quality jobs, and it has European solidarity at its core. Honourable Members, there are many strong reasons to put forward the long-term strategy now: global commitments, economic rationale, but also a key political reason. More and more people are asking in the run-up to the European elections about the future of Europe. There is widespread public support for climate action and actually widespread optimism: 85% of Europeans agree that fighting climate change and using energy more efficiently can create economic growth and jobs in Europe, and I am one of them.

name: Miguel ARIAS CAÑETE
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, the long-term strategy adopted by the Commission today spells out a clear vision for the European Union climate and energy policy, one that can lead to net-zero greenhouse gas emissions by 2050, through a socially fair transition in a cost-efficient manner. The strategy is meant to set the direction of travel for European Union climate efforts and to frame the European Union contribution to achieving the Paris Agreement goals. In Paris, the world committed to keeping the global temperature rise to well below 2°C and to pursue efforts to limit it to 1.5°C, and thanks to the support of the European Parliament, the European Union has adopted all the legislation needed to meet our Paris commitment, and in fact in doing so we have de facto increased the level of ambition to some -45%, and the role of the Parliament was instrumental in this process. We should now follow through and start preparing the next step, looking at the 2050 perspective. The difference between 1.5°C and 2°C is considerable, and the IPCC Special Report presented this year provides a clear signal. If we are to avoid the more disastrous impact of climate change we should seek to limit it to 1.5°C. The IPCC report also told us what we have to do collectively to limit climate change. The world will have to go to net zero greenhouse emissions in the second half of the century, but if the aim is to pursue 1.5° this goal needs to be reached at global level by 2070. The European Union should lead in this transformation, demonstrating to others that the transition to net zero greenhouse gas emissions is possible and opens up many opportunities, and this is what the Commission is doing today. With this strategy, the European Union would become the first major economy to be climate neutral. If we succeed, others will follow. If we do not lead, nobody else will, and if nobody else acts unrestrained climate change will severely impact Europe and rest of the world. The Commission proposal is based on a detailed assessment looking at the possibilities for economic and social transformation that deliver such decarbonisation pathways. Some pathways are looking at reductions going to 80% by 2050, while others look into pathways leading to net zero greenhouse gas emissions by 2050. The results clearly point to a comprehensive vision with seven key strategic building blocks that will be required to achieve a net zero greenhouse gas economy by 2050. First, energy efficiency plays a central role. In the future our economy will grow but we need to prepare for reducing energy consumption by as much as a half compared to 2005. Energy efficiency is central to continue reducing emissions from industry but equally in the housing sectors. Second, we need to advance the deployment of renewables. By 2050 more than 80% of electricity will be coming from renewable energy sources and these will have beneficial effects on our security of energy supply and deliver cumulative savings on our import bill of between EUR 2 and 3 trillion over the period 2031-2050. There will also be additional benefits due to the reduced fugitive emissions of fossil fuels used in the energy sector and in this context, the Commission is looking into policy options for addressing methane emissions. A central tenet here is the electrification of our energy system, at least doubling its share in final energy demand by 2050 and with electricity generated by renewable sources, spreading to more uses such as heating and transport. Thirdly, we have to embrace a clean mobility system. The automotive industry already invested in this new future and electrification is a promising option but some transport modes will not be able to electrify. For them alternatives in the form of advanced biofuels and e-fuels would need to be applied. And it’s not only the vehicle or the fuel that can change. With 75% of our population living in urban areas, cities are breeding grounds for new solutions and we already see movement towards smart urban planning and traffic management. These, together with clean public transport, have the potential to reduce emissions and improve the quality of life. Our industry is already one of the most efficient globally, but the transformation will converge with the need for modernising industrial assets. Steel, cement and chemicals dominate industrial emissions and in the next 10 to 15 years technologies already known in these sectors will need to be demonstrated at a scale to facilitate investment in clean and competitive industrial installations. Electrification, hydrogen, biomass and synthetic fuels are part of the solution. The transformation will require an adequate smart network infrastructure and interconnections and we need also to harmonise the potential of the bio-economy while preserving our carbon sinks. European Union agriculture and forestry will continue to provide food, feed and fibres as well reduce emissions. Continued efficiency improvements, better fertiliser application and nutrient management, and healthy animal stocks will benefit both farmers and the climate. Agriculture and forestry will contribute also to decarbonising other sectors and EU forests will play a central role in providing biomass. The transition of our economy will always have to be careful of how to make best use of scarce land and other natural resources. And finally, we need to look into how to tackle with carbon capture and storage those CO2 emissions which we cannot otherwise reduce. Thanks to the rapid deployment of renewable energy this is no longer the silver bullet to decarbonising. Still, CCS has a crucial role to close the circle for a net-zero economy, notably for energy intensive industries. If combined with sustainable biomass it could create negative emissions, helping to compensate for remaining emissions in our economy. While by no means easy, these options, if deployed together, can make our path towards net-zero greenhouse gas emissions a reality. But to achieve this vision we will need additional investment of around 0.8% of our GDP. But this can also benefit our GDP by up to 2% by 2050. This transformation will also save on health costs, with estimated reductions in premature death of more than 40% and health damage reduced by around EUR 200 billion per year. The European Union climate policy relies on global cooperation and next week’s Conference of the Parties – COP 24 – is decisive for the future of the Paris Agreement. In Katowice the European Union has a good story to tell. We have adopted all the legislation needed for implementing our Paris contribution and our 2030 targets are projected to reduce greenhouse emissions by around 45% by 2030, which is the starting point for long-term planning. With the strategic vision that we adopted today we can also show our partners that we have started preparing for a climate-neutral economy fully in line with the Paris Agreement. It demonstrates our determination to shape together the best future for our planet, and this should inspire others to follow. In the months ahead our proposals and different pathways should be studied in detail to understand how the European Union can best achieve a net-zero greenhouse gas emission economy in 2050 in a cost-effective way. We look forward to engaging with you, the European Parliament, Member States, national parliaments, business, NGOs, cities, communities and our citizens on the EU’s long-term ambition and its contribution to the Paris Agreement. Whatever the outcome of this debate, the European Union objective needs broad and deep endorsement, not only by our decision-makers, by our legislators, but also by all stakeholders and citizens. These debates and discussions should allow the European Union to adopt and submit an ambitious and broadly supported long-term strategy by 2020 to the UNFCCC. I look forward to continuing this essential work with you in the months to come.

name: Ivo BELET
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioners, good evening. This plan is indeed coming at the right time, on the eve of the climate conference in Katowice. We can now send a clear signal to the world that we in Europe are taking our responsibility to put the Paris Agreement into practice. Our group fully supports this plan. We support all the investments you are making in the field of research and development. These are, of course, crucial. We support your proposals, Mr Šefčovič, to create a battery alliance in Europe to realise and produce batteries in Europe itself. We also support your proposals to achieve CO2 storage. You have referred to the chemical, steel and cement sectors, where this is of course essential. There are a number of points that can be even more ambitious. I'm referring to the transport. I refer to aviation and shipping. Aviation will be one of the major threats to our climate in the coming years. This sector is once again in danger of escaping and avoiding responsibility. The Corsia negotiations (on the carbon compensation and reduction scheme for international aviation) are in danger of being boycotted and eroded. We are counting on you, Mr Šefčovič and Mr Cañete, to stop that. Finally, a comment on the accompanying social measures. They are only realistic if we maintain social support. Workers whose jobs are threatened in the automotive industry or in coal fields must be sure that we will guide them in the transition to a low-carbon economy. We must continue to keep a close eye on this dual aspect of this transition. I wish you good luck next week in Katowice.

name: Kathleen VAN BREMPT
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, we can say ‘yes we can’. Yes, we can take the right decision to go to a fully climate-neutral economy. This is one of the real ‘TINAs’ – there is no alternative to taking this decision. But let me also be very clear. There are different pathways to get there and we need to change that as well. it is not just about greening the economy. it is about making a just transition to do so. We’ve witnessed the gilets jaunes in Belgium, and more in France. We should not say these are climate sceptics. We should not say that. We need to make sure that moving in that direction – and we really need to do that – is done in such a way that takes everybody on board. I’m looking to my good colleague, Ivo Belet. I liked your speech and I hope that next time, if we vote on CO2 car emissions or energy efficiency that we have your support to do so. That is really very clear because it is not good enough just to give speeches. We need to get results, and one of the results that we have to work on – and we need your support, Commissioners – is: we need to change the governance in Europe. We need to change the European Semester, take ecological and social indicators into account and change the way we govern the European Union. I sincerely hope that we will have the support of the EPP on that as well.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioners, i would like to thank you for your comments. Climate and energy policy is a particularly difficult challenge for Polish, where coal is the primary raw material in the process of generating electricity and heat. I appreciate the fact that the strategy has recognized the role of forests in CO2 absorption, which is an effective method of reducing the concentration of carbon dioxide in the air.  Poland is open to a fair, fair and constructive discussion on how to jointly achieve climate objectives in a cost-effective, socially acceptable and without affecting the country's energy security. However, I am afraid that restrictive scenarios will have little global significance, but will cause huge problems in the European Union, especially in my homeland, Poland.

name: Gerben-Jan GERBRANDY
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, I would like to thank both Commissioner Šefčovič and Commissioner Arias Cañete very much. I would like to congratulate them on this visionary document. It’s a really fundamental document. I would argue that it’s the most radical transition of our economy and society in 150 years, and that is quite something. It means that climate change is not business as usual. We have to do things differently, not in an incremental way, but in a quite radical way. In that sense, it’s essential that we build the trust of citizens, as my colleague, Ms Van Brempt emphasised, but also the private sector. One other thing is very obvious to me. We have to be focused, we have to be united and our policies have to be coherent. That means not just mainstreaming a part of our budget like we’re doing now. It means climate-proofing the entire budget. My plea is that the Commission should launch a climate-proofing exercise of the next 2021—2027 budget proposal. I do not think we can leave it like this after you have published this fundamental document. The Commission should also look again at its plans for sustainable finance because just sustaining a very small part of the financial sector will not be sufficient for this fundamental change of our economy and society.

name: Bas EICKHOUT
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, I would like to thank the Commission for this strategy. I quote Mr Šefčovič, ‘our strategy now shows that by 2050 it’s realistic to make Europe both climate neutral and prosperous, while leaving no European and no region behind’ – it’s beautiful – and Mr Arias Cañete, ‘going climate neutral is necessary, possible and in Europe’s interest’. It’s a beautiful press release, so I was eager to read it. I’m a bit confused now because, at the end of the document, you conclude, ‘well, you know, the EU should adopt and submit an ambitious strategy by early 2020 to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC), as requested under the Paris agreement’, so our mid—century strategy for this beautiful scenario will be published sometime in early 2020. Now I’m really confused. I thought we were doing that here. This is just eight scenarios on the table and, more importantly, it’s avoiding one of the key questions: what are we going to do by 2030? If you are sketching a beautiful scenario out there that we should do it for everything – for people, for the economy, for the environment – so we are creating a heaven on earth, but we wait until 2030 before we take additional action, it doesn’t make sense economically. Environmentally it doesn’t make sense because the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) was very clear: we need early action to meet the 1.5 degrees goal. 2030 is not early action and for Katowice, it doesn’t make sense because everyone will watch Europe. Are you going to raise ambition before 2030? There is a gap in reaching the Paris commitments. This document is beautiful, but this document is avoiding the question ‘what is Europe going to do by 2030?’ That’s the question in Katowice. That’s our economic and our environmental challenge, and the Commission is just postponing, as always. Unfortunately, I can only conclude that, despite the nice words, climate change policy is not a priority for this Commission.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, this is an ambitious strategy. On paper it’s aiming to keep all Member States on board and reacting to the alarm bells from the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) UN Special Report. If it’s lived up to, it would be a step in the right direction, but is the strategy really safeguarded, given that it is so dependent on the strong political will that we need across the board in every single Member State. If we want to be serious about curbing global warming at 1.5° Celsius rather than 2°, we have to make sure we are providing a realistic chance to achieve this. We firstly need to avoid factoring in reliance on technologies that are not even proven yet. We cannot cross our fingers with techno-fixes when it comes to the climate. Secondly, to ensure that this target is actually achieved and that we don’t miss it, has the Commission considered any pathways looking at reaching carbon neutrality already by 2040? Taking account of the EU’s huge responsibility for historical emissions, logically we should be aiming for zero net emissions before 2050. We are talking about human existence on this planet, so we cannot risk missing this contribution to curbing global warming at 1.5°.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: on behalf of the EFDD group. Madam President, while Parliament debates the environment, air pollution and cars, a new citizens' movement was born in France: yellow vests, supported by 80% of the French.  Overwhelmed with taxes, some compatriots will soon no longer be able to drive to work because fuel is so expensive. At the same time, the United Nations is warning of the growing gap between state action and COP21 commitments. However, it is globalization that has encouraged pollution, through the massive importation of products designed on the other side of the world. So what are we waiting for to punish not the citizens, but the real polluters? Shipping using very poor quality fuel oil with sulphur oxide, nitrogen oxide and fine particulate matter is much worse than diesel. What are we waiting for to encourage short circuits?  Let us be clear, it is not by promoting free trade with the whole world that the European Union will fulfil the announced objectives.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ENF Group. Madam President, Commissioner, Commissioner, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his work and the commissioner. They today presented their net zero emission strategy for 2050.  Full decarbonisation is expected to cost EUR 290 billion per year and 2% of economic output is expected to have a positive impact by 2050. Some industries – especially those that depend on fossil fuels – may disappear completely from the market in this scenario, but that is accepted. It also means a huge effort for the Member States to achieve climate neutrality, so far CO2 emissions have only been reduced by a fifth. Even if the measures recently adopted at EU level, such as the expansion of renewable energy, the increase in energy efficiency and the reform of emissions trading, were implemented, emissions would be reduced by 60% by 2050. That is still a long way from the hundred percent limit of the zero-percent scenario. The way there leads through a higher CO2 price, up to 68 euros/tonne, says the Emmissions Gap Report. At the moment we are at EUR 19.77 per tonne, an increase of three times – the death rate for some industries. I therefore ask you to act in harmony with other regions around the world, let us not carry out the energy transition alone. Let Europe lead the way for a climate-neutral economy – but in line with the others.

name: Jerzy BUZEK
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioners, i would like to thank you for your comments. This strategy is the most ambitious attempt to implement the Paris Agreement, which speaks of climate neutrality only in the second half of the 21st century. The success of the strategy will be decided by two factors: internal and external.  Internal – to what extent our industry, small and medium-sized enterprises, research centres will be able to implement this strategy. I'm talking about technologies, their availability and cost. It is also important to support citizens, so it is good that the strategy comes before the European elections. It also appears before COP24.  And here I will move on to the external factor – the title of the strategy is "Pure Planet for All". The European Union is an important but small part of this planet and is responsible for 10% of CO2 emissions. Already in Katowice we will find out how seriously the rest of the world takes the Paris Agreement and whether it is ready to go even further in its ambitions by 2050. This is crucial to saving the whole planet and we have a great task ahead of us at the meeting in Katowice. How to convince all the major issuers to follow in our footsteps, because our plan is to limit the temperature to 2 degrees. And according to the latest research, according to what we committed ourselves to in Paris, it could be as much as about 3 degrees, or maybe more. So it's dangerous.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: – Sinjura President, Kummissarji, Jekk hemm messaġġ li dan id-dokument iwassal b'mod b'saħħtu, huwa l-fatt li i nistgħux nibqgħu nipposponu d-deħiżjonijiet li rridu nieħdu. Jekk verament irridu li sas-sena 2050, tletin sena biss 'il bogħod mil-lum, ikollna ekonomija dekarbonizzata, irridu naħsbu għaliha mil-lum.  Il-liġijiet li qegħdin niddiskutu llum se jwittu t-triq għat-tnax-il sena li ġejjin. Eżempju tipiku hija l-liġi dwar it-tnaqqis fit-tniġġis mill-karozzi. Huwa llum li nistgħu, jew nieħdu d-de大iżjonijiet li verament jagħmlu d-differenza, jew inkella noqogħdu sottomessi għall-interessi ta' min ma jaqbillux li din it-tranżizzjoni sseħħ. Dan id-document jidher pożittiv, imma i nistgħux nibqgħu biss kliem fuq karta. Dan id-document wassal messaġġ 大ar li fl-Unjoni Ewropea, l-agħar li se jkunu milquta, huma dawk il-pajjiżi li qegħdin fil-Mediterran, dawk il-pajjiżi li jmissu mal-kosta, jew il-pajjiżi li qegħdin taħt il-livell tal-baħar. B'indikazzjonijiet li l-baħar jista' anki jogħla b'seba' metri jekk it-temperaturi globali jitilgħu b'1.5 gradi Celsius jew 2 gradi Celsius, inħallikom taħsbu x'jistgħu jkunu l-konsegwenzi għal min, bħali u bħan-nies li jiena nirrappreżenta, jgħix qrib il-baħar.  Għalina u għal ħafna ħadiddini madwar l-Ewropa, il-prezz tan-nuqqas ta' azzjoni huwa għoli żżejjed, ifisser l-eżistenza ta' pajjiżna u tal-ħajja tagħna. Sakemm se nibqgħu naħsbu li l-ekonomija u l-ambjent huma separati minn xulxin m'inix konvinta li se jinbidlu l-affarijiet. Irridu, illum, naqblu biex ninvestu fl-innovazzjoni u fir-ri大erka biex ikollna soluzzjonijiet li jagħmlu sens ekonomiku u li jpoġu flower-Unjoni Ewropea fit-triq tad-dekarbonizzazzjoni.

name: Evžen TOŠENOVSKÝ
text: – Madam President, I certainly agree that we must increase environmental protection and protect it from the growing effects of civilisation – the growth of transport, production activity and the general impact on natural resources is currently enormous. On the other hand, we are gaining new technologies, and science and research bring incredible progress, knowledge and assistance with environmentally friendly technologies. On the other hand, we must be very careful in defining the objectives and strategies for the next decade on climate. If we over-set the limits, which look very nice and ambitious today, we could achieve very negative developments in many areas. I also believe that our concern must be a comprehensive approach, as was ultimately done in the post-coal region platform programme. I thank the Commissioner very much for this activity. I am in for strong support for science, research and innovation, which will only enable people to behave in accommodating and sensible way towards the environment.

name: Michèle RIVASI
text: Madam President, I thank the Commissioners for finally presenting a long-term strategy, but you are proposing eight scenarios, of which only the last two are aimed at achieving zero emissions by 2050. These rely on sorcerer's apprentice techniques to capture huge and unrealistic amounts of carbon, or even to remove them from the atmosphere.  If we want to show the rest of the world that the European Union remains the climate champion and to keep it below 1.5 degrees, the priority is first and foremost to reduce our emissions. The bar must be higher in order to achieve a zero-emission economy in the European Union by 2040. That is what it means to be a leader in climate change.  On the other hand, the latest report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) calls for rapid and far-reaching transitions to limit global warming to 1.5 degrees. What does the European Commission tell us about 2030? Nothing. It begins the scenarios in 2030, as if the European Union were on track.  The climate change is here. We need to act now. Let's be ambitious: we need to reduce emissions by 65% compared to 2010 if we really want to achieve greenhouse gas neutrality.

name: Robert Jarosław IWASZKIEWICZ
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The level of greenhouse gas emission reductions imposed on industry has already reached the limits of absurdity. There are no technologies to satisfy your ambitions, and no spells will change that. The Paris Agreement was a mistake from which the most important partners are already withdrawing. Co2 emissions in China are almost three times higher than in all countries of the European Union and this cannot be changed.  You highlight the gains from green energy development and emission reductions, but why are you silent about costs? Why are you not talking about the escape of industry to eastern countries bordering the European Union? Meanwhile, the costs of eu energy policy for my country, Polish amount to about PLN 5 billion per year and continue to rise. Poland will soon have the highest energy prices in europe. This is the real effect of your policy. The timeframe for climate policy should be immediately suspended and so-called emission allowances removed.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, déanaim comhghairdeas leis an mbeirt Choimisinéirí Cañete agus Šefčovič as ucht na lainseála inniu. Is dúshlán mór é chun ár n-astaíochtaí carbóin a laghdú go náid faoi 2050 ach, tá sé indéanta. So as one who represented Parliament at COP 21 and 22 and will be at COP 24 in Poland, and as the rapporteur for the renewable energy file here for the EPP Group, I welcome these announcements today. Also, I think that we are being ambitious, regardless of what people say, and as the Commissioner said: ‘if we don’t lead, nobody will follow’. Europe is doing that and I think that’s what we need to do.  I am going to mention something I haven’t mentioned before, and that is those who might be left behind. I welcome the emphasis on the socio-economic impact. Citizens and workers were made redundant in my own constituency. Bord Na Móna has announced 430 job losses because of the closure of peat factories or power stations. I would be the last person to say these should be left open – obviously they should not, but we do need to show empathy with these people and I think there are opportunities for us to have a just transition fund at national level to use the MFF. I’m the rapporteur for my Group on InvestEU. All these possibilities need to be explored so that nobody is left behind. This is a very important point. I think if we do that, we can make progress, but it has to be inclusive and fair, and I think we can bring citizens with us in that way.

name: Sylvie GODDYN
text: Following the alarmist conclusions of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC), the European Commission has decided to accelerate the achievement of the 2050 Paris Agreements targets. The peoples of Europe will have to atone for what has structured their way of life for a century and do penance. Penance will be painful, and the Commission knows this because it is cautiously considering differential treatment according to the Member States. My country, France, is classified as a rich country. However, the reality is different: 10 million French people live below the poverty line, the French economy stagnates and unemployment does not fall below 10%. On this subject, the President of the Republic, Mr Macron, has clashed with social reality, he has unleashed the anger of the yellow vests by increasing taxes on gasoline. This must serve as a warning: punitive ecology, which urges the poorest, is deadlocked. So I will make proposals to you: first, to reduce greenhouse gases and to finance the ecological transition, we must tax global flows before taxing peoples. We can also use the European Central Bank, as you did to save the banking system. Finally, intelligent protectionism, based on virtuous environmental standards, must be put in place that will give our companies a competitive advantage over their foreign competitors.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank Commissioner Šefčovič and Commissioner Cañete for the proposal that has been published today, which outlines the strategy for a zero-emission Europe by 2050. So, as you have heard, in this House, there are those who consider your proposal, on one side of the House, to be unatiding, and those who believe that it is a proposal that goes a long way. So, it is clear that you have achieved the goal: you have given this Europe a path to continue to be an international leader and to lead the fight against climate change; as we did after Paris and as we are continuing to do.  As you all know, this year we have had several adverse events on the European continent – events certainly triggered by climate change – which have also resulted in the deaths of hundreds of people. It is clear that this must encourage us to act, to do more, especially in order to save the areas that are most sensitive. On the one hand, we must protect our environment, of course we must reduce the increase in temperature; However, on the other hand, we must always be attentive to what the economic system is, because we must not go too far where we cannot go.  I believe that the strategy you have outlined is a balanced strategy that can achieve the 2050 targets but that will certainly help the growth of a green and sustainable economy.

name: Dario TAMBURRANO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I am very proud as a European citizen to receive this communication. It is an important signal – and it is – if it is the first Paris signatory to set itself a precise target for a net-zero economy by 2050. In fact, the effects of climate instability, which science has been planning for some time, are now daily news stories, outlining what is our new daily life. Furthermore, I am pleased to note a change of pace, including terminology, since the title of the communication already mentions not the word 'growth' but the word 'prosperity': words are important, in addition to content.  However, to avoid more disastrous effects, we know that a deeper paradigm shift is needed. We have entered an era of enormous challenges, where the neoliberal market-based economy is not always able to manage our future any more. To overcome these challenges, we need highly expansionary economic policies and overcoming austerity, finally paying attention to the budget of natural capital and not only to the financial balance sheets that have lost sight of what is thermodynamic balance, which regulates the economy and our existence on Earth, thus paying attention to what is the so-called ecological spread.  At the same time, it is ineffective to think of leadership in the fight against climate change without considering the effect of trade; products are not subject to an analysis of the carbon emitted by the relocation of the products we import: there is therefore an urgent need for a carbon tax at the European border and, possibly, a reform of the WTO in this regard.  Moreover, in order to be responsible and aware leaders, we cannot neglect the needs of developing countries: we live on the same planet! We must prevent them from making the wrong choices that we made in the last century, and we must therefore allow not only people, but above all knowledge, to flow freely. We owe a debt to certain countries to which we have raised resources and it is a debt that we can repay by providing them with the knowledge and technologies necessary to combat climate change.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: - Madam President, Commissioners, I would like to begin by thanking Commissioners Arias Cañete and Eef-Soviet for the Commission's rapid response to combating climate change following the publication of the alarming United Nations report.  Today, at the doorstep of the Katowice Climate Summit, the European Union must renew its leadership and commitment in the fight against climate change and I wish you, in that sense, equal success and luck.  We need to move faster and faster. To this end, together with the necessary investments, we must provide ourselves with the tools to support a process of decarbonisation and dephospholization that will allow our commitments to be combined at international level with the maintenance of a competitive European industry, capable of creating new jobs that allow the social transition, which will also allow us to recover those who are left behind. By 2020, Member States and major CO2 issuers must participate and provide the Commission with all available information so that, together with this Parliament, they can decide on the best strategy to achieve such a high objective that, in my view, it is a determined commitment to renewable energy; technological neutrality; close collaboration, therefore, with the main players in industry, innovation, research; improvement in energy efficiency; and greater implementation of the circular economy at all stages of the production process. For this purpose, the Commission must also understand that it is urgent to update the Ecodesign Directive.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: – I am in favour of green solutions, but of course real solutions. And also a supporter of counting gross costs and not only net costs. If someone says that green energy is more expensive, they forget that living in smog is costly for states. Costly when it comes to treatment, loss of health and in some cases life. I am in favour of real programmes and real monitoring. This monitoring also needs to look for additional incentives for those countries that have to bear the costs of changing their energy system, because in some cases it actually builds up negative effects on the cost of living, direct ones, paid by consumers. But I stress once again that for us today, in order to achieve real goals, we need good monitoring, effective tools and good motivation.

name: Maria GRAPINI
