text: – Madam President, Commissioners, ladies and gentlemen, obviously the subject is interesting and important for everyone, obviously we, as parliamentarians, agree, as the European Parliament, with emissions reductions, but, as has been said here, there are different levels of possibilities of the Member States and the Commissioners have stressed here: we need investment in technology, investment in infrastructure. My question to the Commission is: if we want to achieve these targets and not leave some dreams put on paper, how do you think in the new multiannual financial framework that resources should be allocated to come up with modern technology, to be able to improve infrastructure and to be able to reach these targets which are obviously beneficial to humanity?  I would also have a question about the fact that the European Union is the leader in the fall in new emissions, we are not alone here in the world: what do you think, what can be done to make the other continents and the other institutions fight to lower their emissions, globally?

name: Jakop G. DALUNDE
text: Madam President, the Commission and my fellow Members, I would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur on his excellent In its new climate strategy, the Commission finally confirms what the Paris Agreement is already committing – europe must become carbon neutral. It's a welcome and a belated insight.  The Commission has also recognised the value of the green transition. The strategy describes well how climate action can go hand in hand with economic development, increased competitiveness and job creation. In view of this, however, I am very critical of why work is being made to start working from the new strategy until 2030. If you describe the urgency, why not act now?  It is crucial that this strategy is translated into new initiatives now – tough legislation, higher price of climate impact and aggressive green investment. Otherwise, the target of zero emissions is impossible to achieve. It is time to act now – the climate cannot wait.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: – Madam President, Commissioners, the Commission has taken a good step by proposing climate neutrality by 2050. However, I see in this proposal the same dance of dates and figures as when you, Commissioner Arias Cañete, have to answer when your family's offshore accounts were closed.  And yet I also ask myself: is this goal believable coming from you and what you have been doing so far? How are we going to believe them when they're proposing to delay most efforts by after 2030, when the key is what we do in this decade? That, in football , you, Commissioner, you know - is called the 'palating patapum': delaying the urgent.  How can we believe them when we have just adopted totally insufficient renewables and energy efficiency targets which are either wet paper, or need to be revised upwards, as we already claimed from our group?  How can we believe him if they intend to continue to maintain and prioritize fossil gas in the European Union's strategy? Climate change, Commissioners, already affects millions of people, including many Europeans, so please be consistent.

name: John Stuart AGNEW
text: – Madam President, agriculture will be expected to reduce its greenhouse gas emissions. Farmers can reduce CO2 emissions by reducing tractor use. This is possible without reducing productivity if GM seeds and glyphosate are regularly used to establish crops. The green lobby hate GM and glyphosate even more than they hate CO2, so the alternative is to abandon some land and reduce food production. Farmers can reduce methane emissions by feeding their ruminants expensive cereals and soya instead of grazing grass. This significantly raises the costs of producing meat, milk leather and wool. The green lobby insist that ruminants should be able to graze naturally so the only alternative is for the farmer to reduce ruminant numbers. Farmers can reduce nitrous oxide emissions by growing fewer leguminous crops, but the green lobby want more protein crops grown in Europe. These are leguminous. The green lobby cannot have it both ways. Farmers can reduce water vapour emissions by maintaining large areas of bare soil, preventing transpiration. The green lobby do not like bare soil because of erosion risk. Perversely, but fortunately, the green lobby do like the greenhouse gas water vapour.

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I may not know how to lower the temperature on Earth by two degrees, but I know how not to do it. This should not be done in such a way that the countries responsible for 10% of global emissions will bleed out in an attempt to reduce their emissions by 40%, which will have less effect worldwide than if we had persuaded everyone to cut emissions by 5%. This attitude is sucker, because the emissions that we will exclude on our territory will move to another place, others will earn it, we will lose and none of all of it will be. In addition, by raising the stakes and raising the targets higher and higher, to 30, 40, 50%, we discourage others from going our way, because we show only negative effects and high costs that do not have any effect in the world. Therefore, let us not go down this path.

name: Florent MARCELLESI
text: – Madam President, Commissioners, thank you for your proposals, but I am afraid that none of the scenarios proposed by the Commission is really compatible with limiting global warming in time to a degree and a half, and that cannot be, because, in these scenarios, southern Spain could become a desert and the next climate refugees could be the ones and the Andalusians. I'm not saying this: united Nations climate experts say so. And I say, since we are going to decarbonize the economy, why not get it right now; that is, faster and more ambitiously, to comply with the Paris Agreement as we call on in the European Parliament. This would mean thousands of jobs and a much more prosperous economy, as well as great health benefits.  Within days of COP24, we are missing the opportunity to lead global climate ambition. If Donald Trump doesn't believe climate change, and the EU gives no example, tell me who else is going to do it.

name: Florent MARCELLESI
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, if you’ll allow me to elaborate on three points on the deepest transformation. We started with our European economy, on the importance of social inclusion and the need for more advanced technology to use to power this transformation. Before I start, I really would like to thank the honourable Members for what I feel was broad support for our approach and for seeing this importance in the same way as we do. I absolutely agree with honourable Member Gerbrandy that what we started under the Energy Union is the deepest transformation of our energy systems since they were built in Europe one hundred years ago. I would like to assure Ms Rivasi and Mr Eickhout that climate change is a top priority for this Commission and I am ready to say that no other Commission in the history of the European Union did more to tackle climate change than this one, and it was in close cooperation with this House, the European Parliament.  Looking at the parameters, at the pace and milestones – and here I am sure that my colleague, Commissioner Miguel Arias Cañete, will explain the calendar and the timelines of our efforts – it is very important to have public support and to have people on board. Therefore, the issues like energy poverty and the need for upskilling for those who might lose their job because of this energy transformation are so important. Therefore, we started close cooperation with the co-regions in the transition, where we already have seven countries working with us and we will have our first annual assessment already this Friday and, yes, already in Katowice, just to show that we care, we have the solution and we have to offer these people a new, brighter, cleaner economic future.  When it comes to technologies, as you will see from our strategy, we’ve been looking at all aspects of the technologies and some of them would need help through our research and innovation programmes, would need help through our eligible Important Projects of Common European Interest (IPCEI) state aid programmes, like we do for batteries. Of course, we need to de-risk some of the financing for these cutting-edge new technologies, but it is very important, because what I see in the world of batteries is that if we hadn’t started at European level a year ago, we would really have risked being behind our competitors in Asia for many, many years. We need cleaner mobility, we need electric cars, we need less air pollution in our cities. Therefore, we are aiming to have 35 million electric cars in Europe by 2030, and I want to make sure that they will be powered by high-quality green energy batteries in Europe because the market for that would be enormous: EUR 250 billion a year. That is the challenge. That’s a market we have to capture.  What we are announcing today is the opening of the debate. We need to have the people with us. We need to analyse all the aspects of it and I’m sure that we will present an excellent story and clear European leadership, not only in Katowice, but also later when we present the document to the UN.

name: Miguel ARIAS CAÑETE
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank all the honourable Members who have participated in this debate. Some of you have complained that this strategy is not ambitious. Others considered the importance and dimension of this strategy. I would just say that the strategy proposed by the Commission is fully in line with the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) Special Report. The Special Report talks of global greenhouse gas neutrality by 2070 and carbon neutrality, which is not as ambitious as greenhouse gas neutrality, in 2050. The Commission strategy is far more ambitious because it nails down climate neutrality and greenhouse gas neutrality already in 2050, 20 years before what the IPCC, with the better science available, recommends at global level, so we have ambitious objectives. It is very clear, if you read the communication, that the Commission considers that the European Union should, by 2050, be among the first to achieve net-zero greenhouse gas emissions and lead the way worldwide. To do so, the European Union needs to step up its efforts. That means that we have to go through scenario 7 and 8, which are the most ambitious scenarios and those which lead to climate neutrality. The ambition is here and it touches all sectors of the economy.  Some of you say, ‘well, but there is no action’. We have started taking action. We have delivered, as Vice—President Šefčovič said, all the legislation needed on the climate, the Emissions Trading System that performs as foreseen, regulations on, land use, land use change and forestry, the whole energy union package. With the cooperation of Parliament, which has been more ambitious than the Commission – for sure, I have to recognise it – we could have a very good dialogue and we convinced also the Council to go along and now we have legislation that permits us to reach a reduction in emissions in 2030 of at least 45% – it might be bigger if other legislation comes – and this simple legislation, as the Vice—President said, will lead us in 2050 to emission reduction of greenhouse gas emission levels of 60%. So we are already working, but also because of you, we have excellent review clauses in 2023 and 2024 in all the legislation. That means that there will be more ambitious targets in 2030 because there are review clauses there that you have introduced and you have agreed, Mr Eickhout. So we have the tools, we have the elements to start being ambitious, but for sure we have to step up efforts in the future. This is a revolutionary change, a societal change. It’s a radical change. That’s why I don’t understand very well why Mr Eickhout considers that we can lead this exercise in 20 minutes. No, because now we, the Commission, are inviting the European Parliament, the European Council, the Committee of the Regions, the Economic and Social Committee and the European Investment Bank to consider this mission for a climate neutral Europe in 2050. We have to prepare the special summit of the Heads of State and of Government for shaping the future of Europe at the European Council on 9 May 2019 in Sibiu. In order to prepare for that Council, we want to have a real Council – all the relevant Council formations should have extensive political debates on the contribution of the respective policy areas to the world vision because this touches every area: industry, transport, mobility – all of them –energy, buildings, heating. This is a very complex debate at Council and at Parliament level. It touches all the committees of the House. All the Commissioners have worked together in project teams in order to deliver this communication. It has been a complicated exercise, but we have the product here. Also, in parallel to this political exercise, during the first half of 2019, the European Commission will take the debate on the necessary deep economic transformation and the profound societal change in an open and inclusive manner to all Member States, to national parliaments, to business, NGOs, cities, communities, citizens and youth. They should participate in a dialogue in the European Union and give their contributions on what is the level of ambition we really want and what is the speed of travel we really want with this informed debate in the whole of Europe. I expect in the European elections we will talk about the climate and that could be one of the most important topics. Nine out of ten Europeans think that the climate is an important problem and more than 74% that it is a very important problem. I think these topics will be at the election. If the different political parties show their positions and we have a world debate, then we are ready to go to the United Nations in 2020 with the final strategy. This is the first Commission communication to launch the debate. We have preferred scenarios, for sure. We have four ambitions and we also want an informed debate and that, finally, we follow an ambitious path and we are the first major economy to reach climate neutrality in 2050. It’s hard. We will require huge investments but with huge benefits also: for health, the economy and also for the responsibility we have with the rest of the world. Some of you said it, if we don’t lead, nobody will lead us. The United States are on climate holidays, as the Governor of California, Jerry Brown, said, and it is up to us to lead the way. But if we show that it is feasible and all our impact assessments – and I recommend that you have a look at the in—depth analysis that supports the Commission communication, which is a communication with 20-something pages, the documents here show the difficulties and the challenges, but the possibility to achieve our targets. This is a complex exercise. It touches all society and is something we have to discuss in depth. This is the first moment we sit together. There will be much conversation on it and I expect that we will reach agreement on a very ambitious pathway to deliver what is expected of the European Union: the leading climate change policy in the world.  (Applause)

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: I close the debate. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. – The S&D Group supports a net economy with zero carbon emissions by 2050, but demands action for a fair transition. In this regard, the Spanish Social Democrats in the European Parliament welcome the European Commission's proposal to end greenhouse gas emissions by 2050, but bearing in mind that the transition to a net zero carbon economy must be ensured to benefit all citizens and not create new inequalities. The strategy should help close the growing gap between rich and poor and strengthen social cohesion between citizens and between regions. Social Democrat MEPs have led the legislative work in the European Parliament to achieve ambitious legislation on renewable energy and energy efficiency. However, a global vision is needed to ensure a sustainable society and lead an ecological transformation that goes hand in hand with reform of economic governance and social policies to ensure that this is a fair transition for all. Finally, we are aware that, in order to achieve the long-term objectives, the ambitions of intermediate targets by 2030 must be improved.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. – The S&D Group supports a net economy with zero carbon emissions by 2050, but demands action for a fair transition. In this regard, the Spanish Social Democrats in the European Parliament welcome the European Commission's proposal to end greenhouse gas emissions by 2050, but bearing in mind that the transition to a net zero carbon economy must be ensured to benefit all citizens and not create new inequalities. The strategy should help close the growing gap between rich and poor and strengthen social cohesion between citizens and between regions. Social Democrat MEPs have led the legislative work in the European Parliament to achieve ambitious legislation on renewable energy and energy efficiency. However, a global vision is needed to ensure a sustainable society and lead an ecological transformation that goes hand in hand with reform of economic governance and social policies to ensure that this is a fair transition for all. Finally, we are aware that, in order to achieve the long-term objectives, the ambitions of intermediate targets by 2030 must be improved.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. – The S&D Group supports a net economy with zero carbon emissions by 2050, but demands action for a fair transition. In this regard, the Spanish Social Democrats in the European Parliament welcome the European Commission's proposal to end greenhouse gas emissions by 2050, but bearing in mind that the transition to a net zero carbon economy must be ensured to benefit all citizens and not create new inequalities. The strategy should help close the growing gap between rich and poor and strengthen social cohesion between citizens and between regions. Social Democrat MEPs have led the legislative work in the European Parliament to achieve ambitious legislation on renewable energy and energy efficiency. However, a global vision is needed to ensure a sustainable society and lead an ecological transformation that goes hand in hand with reform of economic governance and social policies to ensure that this is a fair transition for all. Finally, we are aware that, in order to achieve the long-term objectives, the ambitions of intermediate targets by 2030 must be improved.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: in writing. – The Social Democrats support a net economy with zero carbon emissions by 2050 and call for action for a fair transition. In this regard, the Spanish Social Democrats in the European Parliament welcome the European Commission's proposal to end greenhouse gas emissions by 2050, but bearing in mind that the transition to a net zero carbon economy must be ensured to benefit all citizens and not create new inequalities. The strategy should help close the growing gap between rich and poor and strengthen social cohesion between citizens and between regions. Social Democrat MEPs have led the legislative work in the European Parliament to achieve ambitious legislation on renewable energy and energy efficiency. However, a global vision is needed to ensure a sustainable society and lead an ecological transformation that goes hand in hand with reform of economic governance and social policies to ensure a fair transition for all. Finally, we are aware that, in order to achieve the long-term objectives, the ambitions of intermediate targets by 2030 must be improved.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. – There is a starting problem in the European Union's approach to the greenhouse gas emission reduction target: the option and insistence on a market approach that has revealed not only its ineffectiveness but also its perversity. The rest is a lot of propaganda and some debatable measures. The creation of a trade in allowances to pollute has done nothing or do not do for the desired reduction of greenhouse gas emissions, especially if we want it to be achieved in a framework of justice and sustainability. Leaving environmental objectives in the hands of the market – which could and should be achieved by other means – will be useful for some, no doubt, but detrimental to the environment and to the people. Moreover, this EU approach has linked the limitations, shortcomings and contradictions of the Paris Agreement itself. Advertising's not enough. Above all, when concrete actions either do not accompany it or work the other way around. We remain, in the fundamental case, in the face of a framework of incoherence between the objectives proclaimed in the field of the environment and the content of relevant sectoral policies – from agricultural policy to trade policy, among others. If means are needed to achieve certain objectives, the proposal for a post-2020 Multiannual Financial Framework does not authorise triumphalism.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. – The creation of a trade in allowances to pollute has done nothing or do not do for the desired reduction of greenhouse gas emissions, especially if we want it to be achieved in a framework of justice and sustainability. Leaving environmental objectives in the hands of the market – which could and should be achieved by other means – will be useful for some, no doubt, but detrimental to the environment and to the people. Moreover, this EU approach has linked the limitations, shortcomings and contradictions of the Paris Agreement itself. Advertising's not enough. Above all, when concrete actions either do not accompany it or work the other way around. We remain, in the fundamental case, in the face of a framework of incoherence between the objectives proclaimed in the field of the environment and the content of relevant sectoral policies – from agricultural policy to trade policy, among others.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. – The European Commission's communication "a clean planet for all", discussed today, is extremely timely, and follows the presentation by the International Energy Agency of very pessimistic forecasts on the degree of overall compliance with the Paris Agreement, which considered that even the BEST EFFORTS of the EU may not be sufficient to contain the increase in emissions to be occurring, especially in Asia.  This Communication highlights the importance of rapid implementation of the clean energy package, as well as the ambitious completion of the ongoing institutional negotiations on clean mobility. It should be stressed that the communication "a clean planet for all" is proposed to be a pillar of a long-term strategic vision enabling the European Union to make a sustainable and fair transition to a prosperous, modern, competitive and decarbonised economy. The European Union is now well-equipped with conceptual tools and is in the process of having the necessary legislative tools to aspire to a favourable position for people, the economy and the environment in the energy transition process. The key, in an intergovernmental plan, is implementation. Governments must follow up on this legitimate European and citizen ambition.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: The next item is the Commission statement on the Single Market Package (2018/2903(RSP)).

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, today we have the opportunity to talk about the communication we have just issued on the Single Market. In March, maybe some of you remember, the European Council asked us to present the state of play of the Single Market. They called on us to assess the remaining barriers, but also to set out opportunities for the future. Of course, there are more reasons why we decided to and why we needed to put this out right now. First, and most obviously, because this Parliament has six months left in this term and this Commission has just under one year. It is right to tell citizens and businesses where each of us stands. It is right that they know what the Commission has done and what the co-legislators have done so far. Second, because everyone in this room knows that the Single Market and the freedoms of the Single Market are really under threat today. Third, because there is no time to lose: what I hear again and again from businesses and entrepreneurs is that every minute we delay in creating the true Single Market is really an extra minute for our competitors in Asia or in the United States.  We need to revive the case for the Single Market. We need to shift the narrative from the traditional – completing the Single Market – to the new one: the Single Market as a tool to improve the lives of our citizens, raise our industrial competitiveness, to boost our standing and influence in the world. The traditional narrative of completing the Single Market really means only ticking the boxes, and this is what really, really a lot of bureaucrats do, but this is not really what we need right now in this moment of history. Our communication shows that there are very real benefits for our citizens and for businesses, not just in terms of jobs, not just in terms of more growth, but also in terms of freedoms and opportunities for people’s lives. It shows also three main areas where we really need to do more. These areas are as follows:  First, we need to adopt the proposals on the table. We have put forward, as a Commission, proposals only where there were the highest priority and all of them passed the most strict impact assessment. We have not flooded both Parliament and the Council with the new proposals, but still the statistics are stark. For instance, out of 67 proposals from the Commission directly relevant to the proper functioning of the Single Market, 44, for now, have still not been agreed by Parliament and the Council. The situation is especially bad on services and on capital markets and the banking union. We also need to agree on some key proposals for our digital Single Market, for example, copyright, e-privacy and platforms to business, just to name a few. We have four months to remedy this. We have four months to find truly intelligent compromises.  Secondly, we need to ensure that the rules deliver in practice. The Single Market needs everybody in the EU to play by the agreed rules. Let me just mention two words: defeat devices. I am currently dealing with over 1 000 infringement cases and this is over 1 000 unfair limitations on our citizens and on our businesses. I don’t exempt businesses from the criticism either. We recently, for example, found out that 40% of websites do not allow customers from other Member States to conclude purchases online. Geo-blocking: our geo-blocking regulation enters into force next week, and it needs to be implemented very swiftly.  Third, a real third point, we must continue adapting the Single Market so that it really fits a changing economy. We have to be more precise on how services become more important because they complement products or replace products. We need to be more ambitious in integrating digital technology in our traditional service sectors. The Single Market for services, as we all know, does not work as well as the Single Market for goods, but it offers really great opportunities and it shows enormous untapped potential. We need to look more at how the Single Market supports our trade agenda and we need to reflect more on how to be much more consistent and ambitious on enforcement and how this fits with our competition rules.  Let me conclude by saying that of course I understand that these are not easy issues. I understand that they take political courage and they need strong leadership, but time and again, I hear representatives of different institutions and different Member States declaring their belief in the Single Market outside the negotiating room. Once they enter this negotiation room, the proposals are blocked or watered down. Decent proposals are blocked or watered down. When the European Council addresses or discusses the future of the Single Market next month, I hope that the leaders will renew their commitments, not only in words but also in deeds, and I hope that they will show true leadership on this.

name: Andreas SCHWAB
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I think it is good that, a few months before the European elections, the Commission has once again made it clear with this communication that the internal market and cooperation between the economies of the 28 Member States have the potential for prosperity that brings us growth in Europe and is ultimately responsible for the prosperity of almost 500 million citizens in Europe. Unfortunately, you can only show this in the end with numbers, and numbers always lead to emotions being lost. However, to be brief, the fact that we are doing so well in Europe today – and this is true statistically for all Member States on average, even if many citizens do not want to see it – is because we work together in Europe, because very often we have only one European regulation instead of 28 different individual regulations. That is why it must be made quite clear that Europe does not stand for bureaucracy, but at the same time we are abolishing 27 with a European regulation. That is why the internal market means less bureaucracy. This is, of course, particularly true in view of what the Commissioner has said, that the Member States, the economic stakeholders concerned, always point out in the external discussion how strong they are for the internal market, but when it becomes concrete, they find it difficult. We have seen this with the Commission's service package. However, I should also like to point out, of course, that the European Parliament, in its hard work, has also ensured, with some resistance from the Council, that we have at least made two of the proposals capable of winning a majority, which in the end also faced this very hostility in the Member States. That is why I believe that, in the coming years, we need to make it much clearthat that the internal market is not just the responsibility of the Commissioner for the Internal Market, that the internal market is not just DG GROW, but that the internal market is characterised by a great many other competences in the European Commission, all of which must work together so that they can convince the European Member States accordingly.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would also like to thank the Commissioner for this communication. I think it is important to celebrate these 25 years of the single market – which is certainly Europe's success story – but also to start having a different approach, because in any case not everything is good, and here we are also highlighting the good and, above all, we must begin to get through the notion that the single market is not simply an abstract category but impacts on citizens' lives every day. : from roaming to digital products, to consumers. I mean, a lot of things that improve people's lives.  I think it is important to take stock of this end of the parliamentary term: it is clear that the Commission has had many proposals on the table – as you said, Commissioner – it is also true that many of these proposals have been strongly supported by Parliament. These include: certainly the abolition of roaming, the digital one-stop shop, the regulation on consumer cooperation, data initiatives – both free flow and personal data, in short geo-blocking – as you mentioned – all of which Parliament has contributed to in an improvement direction. Of course, we wasted time on proposals that were not the best, those on the services package; these did not meet the needs of citizens or add value to the quality of their lives. I am thinking of the e-card – which we have stopped in this Parliament – although we then found some compromises on the proportionality test and notifications.  However, Commissioner, let me tell you: there are also proposals that have come too late. You are right, we have a few months ahead of us, but we have only had important proposals in the last year concerning consumer protection, which relate to the goods package, which affect platforms. These proposals, with six months to go, would certainly have been completed by this Parliament and, unfortunately, we are currently racing to bring to a close things that are very important for European consumers and citizens.  However, Mr President, let me say one last thing to the Commissioner: I think that the single market will only evolve if we also deal with taxation, without a fiscal issue in Europe the single market will find it increasingly difficult to move forward. (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". I would like to thank Mr Danti very warmly, because he mentioned that the roaming regime is a real benefit for our citizens. Now, of course, it is a matter of developing "roam like at home" – this has also been very well received by the population. But the SIM cards we buy are only allowed to buy in our own Member State. That is why competition between the European Member States has not yet been possible. Do you think that in the future it will be possible to buy a SIM card in all 28 Member States and generate real competition?

name: Nicola DANTI
text: Answer to a blue card question. Mr President, I think that we still have a great deal of work to do on the issue of competition at European level. Surely we can make progress. It is clear, however, that we must ensure at European level that there is real competition and fairness also from a fiscal point of view, because a company that pays little tax in a country is in danger of competing unfairly in this sector, as in other sectors, with companies that pay a higher level of taxation. That is why I believe that the single market will have a great perspective if we accompany the regulatory part of strengthening the single market with a strengthening of fiscal policy.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, I’d like to start by thanking the Commission because this report is a stark warning that the Single Market is far from complete, lacks political support from Member States and is, in fact, under threat. At the heart of this report is a goods-services divide. The Single Market in goods is well developed, although often undermined by national regulations, but the Single Market in services has barely got out of the starting gates. Only a third of Single Market-related legislation proposed this term has been approved. If we didn’t already have the Services Directive, does anyone really believe that it would be passed today? The European Parliament is often as guilty as Member States of protectionism. The e-card system, which would have made it easier for professionals to work across borders, was blocked here. The Single Market is supposed to be at the heart of the EU. Services is supposed to be one of the four freedoms – that’s what I keep hearing in the Brexit negotiations – yet this Parliament seems to show little interest in it. Try being a hairdresser in Germany or a ski instructor in France. It’s virtually impossible, and we are discriminating against other European citizens here. We need to match rhetoric with delivery and real commitment if the Single Market is to progress further. The risk today is that it slips backwards.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I will start with a quote from the Mario Monti report: ‘the single market is less popular than ever, yet it’s more needed than ever.’ So 20 years since Jacques Delors declared the single market, people now take for granted the benefits it has brought our citizens: from cheaper and safer products to the right to work freely in any Member State, the four freedoms of the single market are the crown jewels of the European Union. It is something to treasure and to protect. The daily benefits of the European Union can be found in the single market. I do share your conclusions, your regret that after 25 years the single market is still not complete. The four freedoms, especially on services, are not fully implemented. So we must do more. I believe the European Council must commit to a new pledge to further complete the single market by 2025, including a new binding timetable for action as European leaders did in 1985, a new pledge based on a proactive movement towards strengthening the single market and away from a defensive national focus. We must not fall into the trap of returning to national protection measures and new regulatory barriers, such as gold-plating European legislation. Our citizens need to understand that it is the single market and trade that supports jobs and growth, it is not isolationism in the form of new barriers.

name: João FERREIRA
text: gue/NGL Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, the Single Market has winners and losers. Capitalist free competition in the Single Market has asymmetric effects, which tend to accentuate economic and social divergence. On the one hand, the main economies of the European Union and the euro area, and their multinationals, which have colonised markets from the centre to the peripheries, are the winners. On the other hand, the most economically fragile countries, exposed to unequal and destructive competition, whose markets have been colonized with a sharp disorientation of the business fabric, are the losers. Insufficient cohesion policy has never entirely compensated for this divergent and asymmetric effect. The deepening of the Single Market, on the other hand, has been subjugating the market with growing spheres of economic and social life, and is inseparable from liberalisation, privatisation and the attack on public services and the social functions of the State. The idyllic portrayal that the right and social democracy repeatedly make of the Single Market corresponds only to one side of the coin: that of the interests they defend.  Workers and people have no reason to review themselves in this picture.

name: Robert Jarosław IWASZKIEWICZ
text: On behalf of the EFDD Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The single market is the european Union's biggest, if not the only, success. However, in recent years it has been evident that it still plays a major role in the individual approach and interests of the Member States, mainly the well-developed countries of Western Europe, at the expense of weaker partners from the countries of the new Union. These interests are supported by the EU administration and EU agencies.  It is the Byzantine administration that creates further barriers to entry to the single market, thereby imposing a muzzle on freedom and free trade. In 2017, as many as 7076 single market directives were in force. Is it still a free market? If we want to maintain free trade, if we want to increase competitiveness, if we want to strengthen our industry, let us pause the legislative machine and allow companies to compete peacefully in a really free market.

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The single market will be when countries refrain from regulating it. Any regulation, even an attempt at regulation common to all countries by the European Parliament, leads to the market not being single. Even these common regulations are implemented by national parliaments a little differently, and this ends, as I say, with gold-plaifulness, that is, when implementing some countries sometimes undermine the meaning of an act, or at least the intentions of the EU legislature.  Moreover, I must refer to the incredible nonsense that my utter gave about unfair tax competition. It is unfair to tax people excessively. It is unfair at all to tax people in order to allocate the funds obtained to things that are absolutely not necessary for the functioning of the state. It is unfair to force people to take money and give it to other people. This is unfair. There is nothing unfair about the fact that taxes are being cut somewhere, because lowering taxes is precisely a form of fairness. It is fair when everyone has what he has worked out.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Mr President, I also subscribe here to those speakers who clearly highlight the importance and positives of the single market. In short, even for those EU citizens who need to be critical of some of our policies, single market policy is clearly explainable and defensible. However, we are still fighting protectionism and we must continue to defend and explain the ideas of the single market.  In her speech, the Commissioner asked rhetorically whether the single market would ever be completed. I believe that the single market will never be completed. There will still be areas where it will be appropriate to adapt legislation already adopted or find uniform regulation for the whole of Europe. If the basic institutional frameworks of the Single Market could be adopted by 2025, that would be great. In any case, I believe that a revision of what has not yet been adopted must be carried out at the end of the parliamentary term and these things should be forwarded to the next administration, the next Commission, the next Parliament. It would be a great shame if the next Parliament and the next Commission started from scratch and did not follow up on what this Commission has done, what this Parliament has approved.  In addition to what has not been finalised, we should also communicate visions where we think that the objectives of both Parliament and the Commission should be strained in the next parliamentary term, as is the case in the field of services. I, like some of my colleagues, feel that, in the area of services, the regulation is simply not working very effectively.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: Mr President! Thanks for that. I would like to start with and say thank you very much to Mrs Bienkowska for making a really important case for the car industry and for the internal market, namely to align with those Member States that do not provide for and comply with our legislation. Thank you for what is needed, even if it is hard work. The single market is really important to us and we are celebrating its 25th birthday. But if, at the same time, we still see the overview and see that we are not in the measure of all the things, then perhaps it may also be because we sometimes get focused on a bit of the wrong thing. So it is really important that we obviously have the right laws in the internal market. But implementation must also be in order, and enforcement must also be in order, and it has not been. Perhaps in the future we need to be more focused on having a little less laws we work with in order to make the single market work. It should not be understood as i am against regulation, I would like regulation, but a little less, slightly more important laws, and then make sure that they are adopted, implemented and enforced That I think is the way forward for our good internal market.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Mr President, the free movement of goods, services, people and capital is an essential factor for Europe-wide prosperity. This creates the second strongest economy in the world and we should be able to exploit this potential. Nevertheless, there are fundamental problems, for example, the single market for goods also means some unfairness, which is why I welcomed the Commission's initiative to meet the calls of Members and some Member States for one quality of food and goods. It is not possible for dual-level consumers to be here. Thus, I consider the measure that will be put in place – i.e. that certain practices of retail chains will be considered unfair – to be the right solution.  Another issue is the free movement of services, it has already been mentioned here. The free movement of services should be simplified and not new barriers are built, such as for the Posting of Workers Directive.  Personally, I would like to thank the Commissioner for presenting the e-card proposal, because I regarded it as a very good simplification of services for certain sectors, and unfortunately it was the EP that blocked this Initiative by the Commission so far. I believe that it will be restored and that this movement will be simplified on the European services market.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, the Single Market is vital for the prosperity and economic well-being of citizens in the UK and the EU. It gives UK businesses access to the world’s largest market, of 500 million people, generating about GBP 10 trillion in economic activity. It is therefore a tragedy that the UK has agreed, in principle, to leave the EU and the Single Market. It is an act of self-harm and beneficial for neither side. It’s obvious that the UK’s best interests would be served by remaining as a Member State and continuing to be a part of the Single Market, enjoying all four EU freedoms – movement of goods, capital, services and people. EU countries trade twice as much with each other as they do with third countries. The Single Market is responsible for income gains in the UK between 2 and 6% – that’s up to GBP 3300 a year per British household. Leaving the EU and the Single Market means that we will GBP 100 billion worse off a year, with our economy reduced by 3.9% by 2030. This will cost the average person, in each year, GBP 1090. Trade between the UK and EU will fall by 46% and foreign direct investment into our shores will fall by 21% and there would also be a fall in (off mike) revenue, up to GBP 23 billion less to spend on public services, pay … (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: – Dear Chairman, the single market is the european union's greatest strength as it ensures economic prosperity and can be used as an important map in relations with other global players, as everyone wants to sell their products and services in a large and rich market.  Instead of wasting time on further political integration that triggered the UK's departure and fuelling a rise in mistrust of the Union among citizens, we need to focus on what is proven to work, which is the single market. We need further economic, not political, integration.  I therefore hope that by the end of this mandate, the Commission will continue to strengthen the single market, reduce administrative burdens and remove barriers that still exist in the financial sector, services and energy.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. In addition to lasting peace on our continent, the single market is the most important achievement of European integration. Its importance is underlined today by the political pressures of internal anti-integration and the strengthening of new challenges from international competitors.  Examples such as the Capital Markets Union and the Digital Single Market require breakthroughs in order to respond to emerging challenges on the side of services, employment and the social system, circular and sustainable economic development models or artificial intelligence.  In particular, I stress tax policy, where I believe that the full implementation of fiscal union can be a realistic objective in the wake of vat schemes and steps towards the unification of the common consolidated tax base.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, without doubt the single market is probably the single best example of what Europe has done in its time, and I suppose it has helped to create jobs, it has helped to create wealth. My own country is probably as good an example as you’ll get. One of the poorest countries when we joined in 1973, now one of the wealthiest and fastest growing economies, because it opened up a market of 500 million people to us basically free of charge. My friend Paul Rubig mentioned what we can achieve when we work together, particularly in relation to the roaming charges, which has been hugely beneficial to businesses and indeed individuals, probably knocking 50% off their phone bills every month. So for that reason one wonders why is there a reluctance to complete the single market. I just don’t understand it, and my question for Commissioner Bieńkowska is how much can she achieve in the next 12 months? Maybe not all but everything would be a help. How much realistically can be achieved?

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, I think that at least one conclusion we have: that the single market is important and that we have not completed it. Based on these ideas, I would like to add to the ones discussed here and a few things and perhaps you can in response to bring new information. The functioning of the Single Market, of course, depends very much on other things that are not in your portfolio, I believe that the Commission as a whole must work for the functioning of the single market. We still have a lot of problems with the customs union. If the customs union does not function uniformly, there are obviously effects on the single market. We have a segmentation of the single market. We do not have the single market, because we have Schengen and non-Schengen, we have euro and non-euro, we have problems with a lot of directives, late payments, for example, or the directive on purchases, and a lot of examples can give you, euro and non-euro.  What we intend to do concretely, because we have very few achievements from my point of view, colleagues have nominated them, I do not say them anymore, but perhaps in your answers, you can, synthetically, tell us what are the following things that we could solve in the single market, because here we need jobs, sustainability for SMEs , growth in this global competition.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: – Mr President, thank you very much, Commissioner. Undoubtedly the single market is one of the main achievements of the European Union. But I very much agree with what has just been said by those who have used the word before me, to point out the difficulty of not having a genuine customs union, because that implies that there is no genuine single market.  A tariff union is one thing, a customs union requires that there be a homogeneous criterion for inspections, in the field of sanctions, in the field of controls; and I'd like the commissioner to listen to me because I wish she could answer my questions. I would like to ask you: what is your coordination as Commissioner with the Commissioner responsible for finance to put an end to this problem? We cannot continue to defend a single market without a genuine customs union that guarantees fair competition to our producers in the face of unfair competition from products arriving at other ports that fail to comply with the rules. Unfortunately, I see you haven't listened to me.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you very much for your input, for your questions. I think all of us agree that, because it was repeated many times, the Single Market is one of the greatest achievements of the European Union, but of course, we have to face the truth, we have to face the reality that we are not using the full potential of this greatest achievement. We are not using it in 100% as was said, mostly in the services sector. The goods sector is more unified under the Single Market. I welcome very much your constructive approach on the various issues, although I very much do not agree on one of the statements saying that some of our proposals were a waste of time. It was not a waste of time, for example, the e-card proposal was – I’m completely sure – a step in a good direction, it was a step to allow our companies to go cross border and to trade cross border and to provide their services cross border. Unfortunately, it was blocked, as some other proposals were. I definitely also want to state that a fully functioning Single Market – because it is also under the framework of this communication – together with a properly functioning standardisation system will make the European Union, in an economic sense, more attractive, more powerful internationally and at the same time, ensure the high standards in the various sectors of our lives. Of course, those benefits should not be taken for granted. As we see also under this term of the Commission, of the Parliament, there is a lot of untapped potential. The question was what else we can achieve in the next month to come. Let me say – and I regret it very much – that three of our proposals, notification, e-card and Single Market Information Tool (SMIT), were blocked either in the Parliament or in the Council. Still to go are the single digital gateway, mutual recognition, market surveillance and some parts of type approval in different sectors. There are still proposals that are being negotiated in trilogue. Some of them have not started yet, but I think we’ll be able to deliver on all of those that I have just listed now before the end of this term. Definitely, those three, notification, SMIT and e-card, although seen by some as not highly ambitious, were really very important and substantial steps in a good direction, as I said.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: I close the debate. The vote will take place during the next part-session. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: in writing. – The European Single Market is, unquestionably, one of the European Union’s paramount achievements which significantly improves our citizens lives on a daily basis. However, our common market needs immediate adaptation to a fast-changing global economic environment, emerging business models and evolving digital technologies. I stress that existing fragmentations of the Single Market are to a high degree detrimental to EU’s overall global competitiveness and its role within a world-connected economy that gathers ambitious and aggressive actors. I strongly believe that a fast, feasible solution would be to focus on implementation, instead of new legislation, especially in those cases where transposition overlaps existing national laws and standards.

name: Lidia Joanna GERINGER DE OEDENBERG
text: in writing. – The Single Market is one of the most basic and biggest successes of the European Union. We have accomplished the creation of the Single Market, but we have not completed it yet. Now it is time to implement needed improvements for the benefit of consumers and businesses. As achievements, we can mention the elimination of roaming, te recognition of qualification and university degrees across the EU, the enforcement of passengers’ rights facing delays and inconveniencies or removing obstacles in claiming social security abroad. The Single Market solutions bring tangible benefits to the everyday lives of European citizens. Nevertheless, there is still work to be done. The proposals regarding copyright, the free flow of non-personal data, e-privacy and other crucial files need to be finalised before the end of the parliamentary term. The main challenges have not changed: explaining the idea and advantages of the Single Market; facing protectionist flows at various levels of governance; and the lack of a concrete deadline by when the Single Market will be completed. Every month of delay harms the competitiveness of the European Union market.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: in writing. – At the request of the Council, the Commission makes this Communication where it stresses that no more time can be wasted when legislating in the single market. It is 25 years since its creation, however, its freedoms are currently under threat. We must abandon the traditional narrative and be more ambitious in order to achieve a fully harmonised and efficient internal market, which is truly fair, transparent and equitable. We must also be much more ambitious in integrating the digital economy, which is growing at a rate 5 times faster than "analogue". Parliament has supported the Commission in its initiatives, but sadly some of them are being blocked by some Member States in the Council. Similarly, we must address fiscal issues as a priority. In order to achieve real competitiveness in the single market, it is essential that taxation be the same for all undertakings, regardless of the Member State on which they are based. If one company pays less tax than another, but competes in the same market, it is competing 'unfairly'. In order to advance the harmonisation and cohesion of our single market, we must also make joint progress in tax matters.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: The next item is the debate on the report by Bernd Lange and Paul Rübig, on behalf of the Committee on International Trade on the WTO: Future Action (2018/2084(INI) (A8-0379/2018).

name: Bernd LANGE
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done. We have a global economic reality characterized by global value chains. This is indeed about rules for these global value chains. It is a question of ensuring that reasonable working conditions prevail at all stages of these global value chains. All of this actually means that we need more international rules, more multilateral rules. That, of course, is what the WTO is looking at.  On the other hand, we have a tendency for individual countries to undermine precisely these rules, which are so necessary. That is why one of the first statements in our report is to urge all partners, all 164 partners in the WTO, not to call this set of rules into question, but to develop it further. This is, of course, particularly true of the United States, which is still blocking the functioning of the WTO's jurisdiction and of re-appointing judges and appointing new ones, and which, in other areas of their trade policy, do not accept and respect the rules of the WTO. If that means not accepting rules, then of course the whole system will fall apart, and this will have immense political and economic consequences. That is why it is so important that we now start to preserve this instrument, but at the same time develop it further, because we naturally see that this instrument, which was founded in 1994, needs to be reformed.  That is why we want to go down the road to reform, and we also support the Commission's activities in saying in all three areas: we need to review the rules, both to ensure that development can be promoted for less developed countries, but also to integrate new elements – such as electronic commerce – so that we also have a modern world trade organisation set of rules here too. We also need to look again at how the judiciary works, the second pillar of the World Trade Organisation. Whether we can perhaps bring in more transparency, also process the processes more quickly and also reform the question of the nomination and functioning of the court, so that criticisms can be absorbed. Thirdly, we must also look at working methods. To think that all 164 partners can decide everything together at once, this single undertaking, I think, is an illusion. We must develop flexible facing-in methods, as we have already done with the trade facility agreement and other agreements, so that groups of countries can go ahead without leaving other countries behind, while also ensuring that each country has the opportunity to participate, in other words to organise capacity building, so that momentum can once again enter the negotiation process. All in all, of course, we must ensure that the WTO is also consistent with other international challenges, such as the SDGS, with other international challenges, such as the global sustainability objectives, and that must also be integrated.

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, I would like to thank the First of all, I would like to thank Mr Lange very much, because we are working really well together in this area. The WTO is the basis for strengthening purchasing power worldwide. Purchasing power is generated by exports on the one hand, because new jobs can be created and good wages can be earned, and it serves to secure workers' jobs and to have an even better income. Import serves all of us. We are all consumers. If we can get products cheaper and better from anywhere in the world, it will also increase our purchasing power. So exports and imports double the purchasing power of our population. I believe that this is the essential feature of trade, it serves both sides and it is a global positive development if we promote trade, and ultimately trade also ensures democracy. The WTO was established in 1995. I have to say that I was there for the first time in 1999 in Seattle, where there were only demonstrations in the streets, where people spoke out against trade and against protectionism. I will never forget that the President went to the dockworkers at the time and said, "We're closing the borders, We're helping you-away-what I've never understood." We then had the Doha Round in 2001. Pascal Lamy has pursued the idea here that we focus on trade facilitation. This chapter has been closed positively. We also have, of course, the question of agriculture, where there is still much to discuss, and aid for trade is actually at the heart of our development policy. I believe that the Sustainable Development Goals play a very important role in this area: No 2 – safe food, sustainable nutrition; No. 6 - sanitation, clean water; No. 7 - Renewable energy. There is a real need for action here, and here we can increase purchasing power not only in Europe, but also in those countries that are really bad, and thereby support it. I remember well, as we said in 2002, that it cannot only be up to ministers and our excellent officials to deal with this issue internationally. We then began to set up the Conference of Parliamentarians for the WTO. I remember well that, together with Erika Mann, we created this conference of Members on an equal footing with the International Parliamentary Union. And the last time, in Buenos Aires, we had 300 to 400 Members, where the ministers and the negotiators were speaking. This is also part of the fact that the members of parliament, not only the governing parties, but also the opposition, have the opportunity to follow these developments, especially in the least developed countries. In my view, this is crucial that we also try to communicate the successes. If we see that many of the least developed countries have now become advanced industrialised countries, then that is also a success of the WTO. The fact that we can resolve trade disputes in court, before the Appellate Body, and no longer have to settle them by military means, is also a huge success for the WTO. And we already know that with 164 states to achieve a unanimous result means a lot of work and a lot of time. And I know that we have already had 42 meetings at the Conference of WTO Parliamentarians and that these 16 years have really paid off, because, of course, attention to world trade issues has become accordingly stronger. Now is the time for reform to move on to the next round. The system has proved its worth, and we need to improve it in the future.

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank the two rapporteurs, Mr Lange and Mr Rübig, for your report. It is very timely and you highlight many of the challenges that the World Trade Organisation (WTO) is facing. You also point at ways forward and they are very much in line with what we are trying to do in the Commission with support from you and Member States. It also sends a political signal in this moment that the European Union is strongly committed to strengthening and to modernising and to preserving the WTO. As you said, the multilateral trading system has been good for Europe. It has been good for the world. We have had clear rules. It has been good for companies. It’s been good for economies. It has helped economies to grow, lifting hundreds of millions out of poverty and promoting stability and peace. As you say, the WTO is now under huge pressure and experiencing a very, very severe crisis and, even though the WTO is not perfect, without the WTO, we would not be well off. That would be bad for us in Europe and it would be really bad for the most vulnerable countries in the world. We in the European Union depend on open, rule-based, fair trade. That is essential for our economic prosperity and that is why the European Council, already in June last year, asked the Commission to take forward comprehensive approaches to modernising the WTO in its main functions – rulemaking, monitoring and dispute settlement – as a way out of the crisis. This was also echoed in the G20 meeting, for instance, so this is something that the whole world is aligned on. There are many threats to the WTO. The Appellate Body is the most urgent one and there is a clear realisation about the need to resolve the Appellate Body crisis. Until recently, we hadn’t seen a real strong awareness in the WTO community about the urgent need to reform, but I think this is gradually changing. The European Union is leading the reform efforts here and working with many other countries as well, and we are deepening and accelerating the work that I presented to you in September. There is a long list of challenges that need to be addressed – you mentioned them in your report – and it is absolutely necessary to put the WTO at the centre of a rules-based, multilateral trading system. As I said, the Appellate Body is the most urgent challenge. We believe that the proposal that we put on the table this week, together with 11 other countries, is a credible basis to engage with the WTO and show a way forward that would lead to a strengthened and modernised Appellate Body. We have also tabled, together with the US, Japan and a handful of other countries, a proposal on transparency and notification, which is important for trust and the functioning of the WTO internal procedures. We also need to address gaps in the WTO rulebook. Mr Lange said that the rulebook is from 1995. Absolutely. So, of course, we need to update it. We need to address issues such as non-market policies, forced technology transfer and other items. We are working with the US and Japan to try to see if we can draft new rules in the WTO on these, and, of course, there are many other issues as well. We are working together with a large group of WTO members on e-commerce. There were more than 80 countries engaging in this in Geneva as a result of the joint statement made in Buenos Aires almost a year ago – many of you were there – and that has translated to very active engagement and that is really good news. Of course, there are the outstanding Doha issues, the development issues, which are not to be forgotten. We need to address them as well. Finally, I agree with you that more should be done to contribute to achieving the Sustainable Development Goals, as we set out in the September paper. This is a vital strand of the WTO modernisation. We are engaged in the fisheries subsidies. That is one key in this, of course, but we are also working on identifying how the WTO could contribute to achieving the Sustainable Development Goals. I am committed – and so are we all – to continuing to make every effort to engage with the WTO membership. The members of the Council of the EU countries are all supporting this strategy. We’re engaging with major trading partners, as well, to support our ideas and to push this forward. Prospects are uncertain. They are gloomy and, therefore, I very much appreciate not only the support that you are giving to the Commission, but also the hard work that you are doing and I encourage you to continue reaching out to parliamentarians across the world to support this as well. Thank you very much for this very timely debate and I am looking forward to the debate.

name: Linda McAVAN
text: deputising for the rapporteur for the opinion of the DEVE Committee. – Mr President, I’m speaking tonight on behalf of Lola Sánchez, who was the rapporteur for opinion in the Committee on Development (DEVE). There are two key messages from our committee which tie in with what people have already said. The first is that, yes, we need a rules-based system, but this is particularly important for developing countries, because in a multilateral system they’ve got a better chance of getting a level playing field, of getting a seat at the table and having their voice heard, unlike in bilateral deals where bigger economies can call the shots. Secondly, our key message is that the multilateral trade system must be fair to all countries including the least developed countries (LDCs) and be set in the context of the sustainable development goals (SDGs). Free trade alone will not be enough to lift all boats, and so we need trade agreements which are broadly based, cover human rights, social and environmental aspects, and not just tariffs and trade liberalisation issues. We also need concrete steps to deliver on this agenda, like supporting the UN process to negotiate a UN binding treaty on business and human rights, and we need initiatives on the value chains that Bernd Lange spoke about. We have two areas where we could make quick progress: the first is cocoa and the second is textiles. These are areas where there is a growing mood to get something done, and I think we could work with businesses and Member States to get things done. Otherwise, we’re going to see national legislation and patchworks of national laws instead of having an EU law.

name: Christofer FJELLNER
text: On the other: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr The World Trade Organisation, the WTO, is facing two threats at the moment. Firstly, the growing protectionism of the world, where more and more countries are challenging regulatory trade, is most clearly the United States. However, we have talked a lot about this.  Secondly, which is just as important, the serious threat of the WTO becoming outdated, that it is in fact not up to the challenges of our time, and of the future: Chinese state capitalism, trade in services, digital trade and our increasingly over-regulated societies. I therefore believe that those who defend world trade and the World Trade Organisation are committed to reforming the World Trade Organisation. That is why the Commission's proposal is very good. If we do not succeed in this, we will leave the rule-driven trade. Then Europe and countries like Sweden become the biggest losers. Then we leave a system where rules govern trade, and it will instead be the right of the strong that governs. We must prevent this at all costs, and this work has only just begun.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, Commissioner, the Committee on International Trade expressed almost unanimous support for the report they have made and which will be voted on in plenary tomorrow. And, by the way, I congratulate the two co-people because I believe that we raise a clear, strong and firm loud voice on behalf of five hundred million citizens in defence of multilateralism, in defence of a dialogue-based international order, based on democracy, based on the mutual respect that some seem to have forgotten—or may never have.  But these are the basis for moving forward and, in order to move forward, it is essential, as you said, Commissioner, to modernize the WTO in order to meet the challenges we need to address and provide solutions, such as digital commerce, such as, indeed, the objectives of sustainable development, such as standardisation in labour rights.  But we also need, let us not forget, to solve the outstanding problems of the Doha Round and to make the World Trade Organization stronger, because it is the best guarantee that it can solve them and stand up to those who defend protectionism. And, of course, we must express tomorrow all the support for the Commission's efforts to defend this reform, seeking an alliance with the solidarity partners. I think it's the best message we can give to citizens: together for a better future.

name: Elsi KATAINEN
text: On behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, as is well known, the WTO is in a deadlock in many ways. The World Trade Organisation has been crippled as its most important part - the dispute settlement body - has become incapacitated. This weakened system breaks the rules of global trade, undermines the potential of European companies when the predictability and regularity of trade is not guaranteed, and that needs to be changed.  Maintaining an open, rules-based and non-discriminatory trading system is a lifeline for European companies living off exports. The WTO is an important player in solving a number of global issues, such as ensuring food safety. Similarly, it provides an opportunity to contribute to the achievement of climate objectives globally, where solutions must be found at global level. If we want to maintain an organisation that monitors the rules of the game in the common world trade, we must change its rules. The initiative put forward by the Commission to reform the trade organisation is absolutely essential. In this debate, the EU must act as a champion of trade and find like-minded WTO members with whom it is possible to develop reforms.

name: Klaus BUCHNER
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, I would like to thank the We need a World Trade Organisation that guarantees fair trade. Today, international corporations often determine what happens, which is sometimes anything but fair. For example.B. we have a highly subsidised production of milk and chicken. If we export this, the local farmers will not be able to keep up with the prices; they are deprived of their livelihoods. Our free trade agreements make it possible for land grabs to take place, in which farmers are driven out of their ancestral territory. We are getting cheap goods, such as coffee, cocoa and so on, from these countries from areas that should actually be used to grow food for their own people. This is how we create refugee flows. Reform of the World Trade Organisations can remedy this situation.

name: Helmut SCHOLZ
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done. As has rarely been done before in recent years, questions of trade policy, the regulation of international trade flows and, through them, the questions of how we actually produce, how do we consume, have become the focus of public interest. A stronger link between the WTO and the ILO, with which UNCTAD is with other international organisations, is important and necessary for the maintenance and strengthening of a binding, rules-based and transparent international system, and one-to-one applicable to the entire multilateral trade architecture building. It is not the economically stronger who must set and decide the rules of the game, but rather that partnership and a problem-solving approach must be the benchmark for action, including in the reform of the WTO – including the WTO judiciary. Making the WTO fit for the future clearly requires us to also answer how far we, as Parliament and the government, are able to include and regulate global value-added processes and the actions of transnational companies and the groups of capital operating on the financial markets in the interests of people and the environment.

name: France JAMET
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this draft report curiously tends to reinforce the past dogma of globalised free trade, which is rejected by more and more countries.  Why ask the WTO for transparency in the negotiations and call itself a guarantor of multilateralism when all our trade powers have been devolved to Mr Juncker's Commission? Why commit the WTO to strengthen its powers in order to force the hand of states when it is, above all, our interests that the Union should defend here? No, free trade does not create jobs. No, arbitration tribunals do not protect states or consumers. Yes, intelligent protectionism, like renegotiated NAFTA, can be a solution.  If there was one reform to be proposed, as of today, in the framework of fair trade, it would already be to take agriculture out of the competence of the WTO and free trade agreements.  The principle of self-sufficiency and food security do not belong to firms but to nations.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: – Mr President, while the WTO has been at the centre of trade liberalisation, free trade agreements (FTAs) have also been a part of pushing free trade forward. It has actually been the interplay between the FTAs and successive GATT rounds that drove liberalisation forward, but now this has changed. Why? Among others, we reduced our tariffs and non-tariff barriers. We also grant generalised system of preferences (GSP) tariff privileges to developing countries. We did all this for the benefit of our consumers and industrial users, but now we have almost nothing to offer to our developing trading partners. Also I don’t think we have done enough in our trade system to protect our industry from those imports that have contributed to high CO2 and other greenhouse gas emissions. I note that there is an opinion from the Committee on Development (DEVE) that calls for a carbon emission tax. I think we should follow this call. Our EU industries are very efficient at reducing CO2 emissions. We should consider imposing fees on imports that are not subject to similar achievements in the place of production.

name: David MARTIN
text: – Mr President, I think we’re nearly all agreed in this Chamber that the World Trade Organisation (WTO) is in crisis. Our message should be that this is the occasion for fundamental change and not an excuse for postponing it. We need to use this opportunity to trigger negotiations on social and environmental standards in order to make sure that trade delivers on sustainable development. We need to start the discussion on ending the present consensus rule because as it stands, it threatens to paralyse the whole system. We need to rethink the definition of a developing country. Should China, given its prominent role in global trade, still be considered a developing country? Surely this is unfair on real developing countries which are in most need of special and differential treatment. The WTO needs saving. We need a strong rules-based global trading system, but if we don’t act soon I’m afraid it will wither on the vine.

name: José Ignacio SALAFRANCA SÁNCHEZ-NEYRA
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen.
