The European Union, with 6% of the world's population, is the main exporting bloc of goods, the main exporting bloc for services, one of the main importers and, at the same time, the main issuer and recipient of foreign direct investment. On this basis it is clear, Commissioner, that the European Union must lead efforts to reform the World Trade Organisation on the basis of the Council Conclusions of June and obviously adapt it to the new economic circumstances. A principled, value-based, rules-based model that is predictable and, above all, effective for our companies.  That is why we support the Commission's efforts for this reform, its contacts with all international bodies and, of course, its dynamics of preferential trade agreements. You know very well, Commissioner, what my clear trend is in a very particular agreement, and I hope that at this G20 meeting in Buenos Aires we will be able to make substantial progress and complete the work you have been doing.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: – Dear Chairman, by changing the political map in the West, free global trade has lost some support. Calls for protectionist measures are strengthening in both America and Europe. Many would gladly take it down to Brexit and Trump, but the real truth is that Europe has long since become a mad man.  We can freely remind ourselves how CETA and TTIP were received across the continent and how the left spectrum in this home reacted to them. And Europe bears its share of responsibility for narrowing the space of freedom in global trade, but I must acknowledge that the situation is changing for the better, even if only because of resistance to Trump. In this sense, he is proving very useful.  The WTO must adapt to the new circumstances, but also to new trends in the world market. First of all, the digitization of trade. In this, the EU must be a support and a major advocate of free trade.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: Trade, in order to be sustainable and have a future, must be fair. That was the principle - as I have already said here, Mrs Malmstrom knows this and I think she knows the Havana charter: not too many deficits, not too many surpluses. Trade must not become an economic war that impoverishes others, because then, if it turns into an economic war, it cannot have a future. And for that, the Havana charter proposed balances. Put yourself in the shoes of the United States: they have more than 600 billion deficits, 400 billion with China; of the half - 200 billion - they want to put tariffs. We must understand them: before, of course, they were for an open trade since they dominated the world. But in the new balances, they are to restore the balance, they regain the charter of Havana. And we, Europe, should do the same, Mrs Malmstrom. We have a $120 billion surplus with the United States, we should ask ourselves how to balance our trade and we should ask ourselves how to balance our $170 billion deficit with China. Let's take a new organization, let's rediscover the spirit of the Havana Charter.

name: João FERREIRA
text: – Mr President, establishing a new world order, based on the deregulation and liberalisation of international trade – that is, a new form of protectionism for the rich, a dictatorship of multinationals, forcing competition from the labour force with different geographical backgrounds to achieve the general devaluation of the labour force – was, and this, to a large extent, the aim of the World Trade Organisation.  The last few years have been marked by a substantial change in the relations of forces at the global level, by the rise and increasing preponderance of emerging economies and by the breakdown of the relative hegemony of the United States and also of the European Union and Japan, which dictated contradictions, constraints and blockades within the WTO, with which these imperialist powers could not cope as they wanted.  Thus, the theses of the Reform of the WTO arise to overcome blockades and contradictions. The WTO must be better in the interests of the service of which it was created. They certainly do not correspond to the interests of workers and peoples. They demand another order, based on fair and regulated trade, complementarity, social progress and mutual benefit.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The WTO is in crisis. On this, everyone agrees, but there is no uniform opinion as to whether a facelift is enough or whether deep reform is needed. We know that there is a lack of up-to-date legal solutions. We know that modern technologies are eerily to the WTO, in two respects: first of all, as an object of trade, and also as something that can serve as an instrument not only of control, but also of solutions. From my point of view, it is important, above all, to anticipate the situation.  On the other hand, I would like to counter the opinion that has emerged here that little has been done recently. I believe that, in terms of changes in the WTO, quite a lot of different actions have really been carried out, although they are obviously insufficient today.

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, we are discussing a lot of issues here, but let me just focus on the World Trade Organisation (WTO) reform and the reports that are in front of us here. You’re absolutely right that there’s a lot to be done. When the WTO was created the world looked very different to the one we have today, so it needs to be updated. But it’s also an international organisation with 164 members operating by unanimity. We have difficulties agreeing among 28 countries, but with 164 countries is indeed complicated. Nevertheless, it is in urgent need of strengthening, updating and modernisation, to live up to the demands that we face. So it’s far from perfect, but if we did not have the WTO we would be much worse off. We would have total anarchy and those who would suffer the most, I have to repeat that, would be the poorest countries. It has been good for them to have these rules, this predictability, to be helped, to be inside the global system with the multilateral rules, and that’s what we need to preserve, strengthen and develop. But there’s so much to do. We need to develop the internal function. Here the EU has been in the lead, together with a couple of other countries, to try to emphasise the need for continued transparency and notification. That is key for the WTO to function and to have its trust. We need to make sure that the rules that we have agreed upon in the WTO are enforced. It is the appellate body, it has served us well in the European Union, it has served many other countries well as well, and that’s what the most urgent need is. We have proposed here, with several other countries joining up, a way to come out of that deadlock and I hope this will be discussed in the coming weeks. We do need to address the so-called old issues, the old Doha issues, absolutely we need to do so, and we are engaging with other countries to try to see if there’s a way we can break the deadlock here. We need to address new issues. As I said, we are talking about e-commerce and digital trade with many other countries. That is a good thing. Furthermore, we are discussing how women can be included in a more systematic way in trade, and we need to discuss, I fully agree with you, how the WTO can play a greater role in living up to the sustainable development goals. We need to find ways there where we can work with all the other members and we need of course to make sure that we have modern rules, that the rule book is updated. And here, as I said, we are working with the US and Japan, but also with other countries. So we are trying to put forward proposals. We will continue to do so. We will continue to ally with countries across the globe to work on this, but we do need your strong support here, and therefore I really appreciate the reports that we have been discussing, I thank again the two rapporteurs and also for the opinion of the Committee on Development (DEVE), I think that is very useful. So thank you very much for this and I think we will see each other again to discuss this further as the issue develops.

name: Bernd LANGE
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done. There are increasingly people who are very critical of globalisation. There are also many causes associated with it, as far as their own perspective on life and the possibility of shaping the future are concerned.  Then the question is: what solution is there for these fears? There are some who think that we have to go back to the nation state and organise everything there. I firmly believe that, in a world of today, this is an absolute illusion.  We can only shape our future together and then we also need strong international rules. That is what it is all about: to provide this globalisation with guidelines so that people's lives can be strengthened. If you look at the global world, we basically have only one institution globally: the WTO, which organises equality in the voting behaviour of the countries and which has a jurisdiction. 96% of the judgments are complied with. We do not have that at the UN, we do not have that at any other global institution. We really should defend, expand and expand this asset. That we really have guidelines for globalisation that can shape the interests of nations in the sense of sustainable development in a fair way.  I believe that we also need to discuss much more publicly what an opportunity we have with this. The WTO is a bit of a shadowy existence. It is not so at the heart of the public eye. I believe that we must all work to say that this is an instrument that we want to develop together, so that globalisation can be made fair.

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: Rapporteur. President Sassoli, I would like to thank mr Sassoli for his work on I am also pleased that the Presidency of the Council is present on this important reform, and State Secretary Edtstadler knows how important trade is. I believe that, together with the Commission and With Commissioner Malmström, we have recognised the following: if there is no trade, there is no purchasing power, and if there is no purchasing power, then there is poverty for all. We see this in North Korea: when the borders are tight, when dictatorship prevails, people are hungry and poverty is bitter there. You can look at how people are doing if we don't trade. I believe that we also need more respect for our partners when we negotiate. What we believe is not always ideal in politics. We can also learn from others and create a better basis together. That is why we should oppose protectionism, look at where reciprocity makes sense, and ultimately we should also be tolerant. Tolerance is part of being able to listen to where our partners see problems in trading with us, and that we also set standards that are useful to both sides. Ultimately, trading is a win-win situation. We know that military usually has exactly the counter-order, loose-less, both sides lose, whohas lost the most is the loser. No, politics means something else: we want to be a win-win for our people, we want to strengthen purchasing power, we want to create jobs, not only in Europe, but especially in the poorest of these countries, and the WTO can make a significant contribution to this. Dispute resolution is, of course, a substantive one. We want to create fair conditions for both sides with the rule of law, with legislative measures. I believe that this is the key in the future. That is why I am pleased that the reform of the WTO is at the heart of it.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this report. In a world where we are once again struggling with punitive and protective tariffs, the WTO plays an important role in continuing to shape world trade. Since its inception, the WTO has made a decisive contribution to strengthening multilateralism, promoting an inclusive world economic order and strengthening an open, rules-based and non-discriminatory multilateral trading system. Nevertheless, the WTO must also adapt to the times. Global value chains, digital commerce, environmental and societal challenges, to name but a few points where the WTO needs to catch up.

name: Karol KARSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The ECR Group would like to express its support for the text of the report reflecting the EC's approach to WTO modernisation, which aims to improve the multilateral trading system to make it fairer and more transparent. We fully agree that the most problematic issues concern market-distorting subsidies, forced technology transfer, the impasse in the Doha Development Agenda and the difficulties in appointing new members of the Appellate Body by the US.  I would also like to take this opportunity to stress that the non-exclusion of human rights standards and standards into global rules governing trade and investment will make it very difficult to held companies accountable. This is extremely important in the context of rebalancing trade law and human rights. I consider it very legitimate to actively involve the EU in the work of the UN Intergovernmental Open Working Group on Transnational Corporations and Other Enterprises in the context of human rights and to defend the primacy of human rights over the commercial interests of corporations. This should support the EU institutions and the EEAS, including the EU Delegation to the UN in Geneva, for the adoption of a treaty in this regard. At the same time, I is concerned about the failure to clarify the role of the European Parliament in this matter. I call for genuine protection of human rights and for the establishment of effective and accessible redress mechanisms for citizens to resolve disputes concerning these infringements.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. The WTO is in the midst of an unprecedented crisis and it is urgent to reiterate our support for multilateralism. It allows the development of rules-based international trade and the fight against unfair competitive practices. The WTO is now at an impasse: the current round is blocked and the last ministerial meetings have failed to reach meaningful agreements.  Reform and modernization of the WTO is the cornerstone of a new lease of life for the organization. The WTO must now respond and take into account the current and future challenges of digital, trade in services, the driving role of SMEs, the fight against climate change and gender equality. The EU must be a leader in modernising the WTO in order to ensure fair, fair, rules-based trade conducted in a spirit of reciprocity and mutual benefits.  Finally, it is urgent that a solution be found regarding the United States' blocking of the renewal of the appeals body's appeals of the WTO dispute settlement mechanism. This blockage seriously jeopardizes the sustainability of the WTO and here too we are counting on the European impetus to reach a solution.

name: Tom VANDENKENDELAERE
text: Written. – In recent decades, the World Trade Organisation has helped provide a stable and predictable framework for businesses around the world. In this way, the WTO helped to generate significant growth in many economies. But the world is changing and unfortunately the WTO has not always evolved with it. I support the mandate that the Commission received from the European Council in June this year to accelerate and help the WTO to enter the 21st century. For me, two things matter. Firstly, the role of the WTO as a mediator in trade disputes must be strengthened. This can be done by adapting the rules of trade to the technological and economic developments of the last 20 years. There is also too little emphasis on sustainability and social challenges. More flexibility may be part of the answer. In addition, we must ensure that market participants are levelled by tackling market-distorting subsidies. Finally, I would like to stress that the current political trends in different parts of the world, not to mention the US and the situation in the UK, once again and more than ever emphasise the need for a high-performing and effective WTO.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is the report by David McAllister, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, on the Commission's 2018 report on Serbia (2018/2146(INI)) (A8-0331/2018)

name: David McALLISTER
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, let me start by thanking the shadow rapporteurs, who are all present here tonight, for this report. Let me also welcome Commissioner Hahn and thank him personally for his dedication and good work in the Western Balkans region.  Today we are debating the European Parliament’s last annual report on Serbia in this legislative term. It has often been said, including in this Chamber, that Serbia is moving towards the European Union. I would like to underline this by looking back at the beginning of this legislature in 2014, when the accession negotiations had just started and, concerning the opening of chapters, Serbia literally started from zero. Today, four and a half years later, 14 chapters have been opened in the negotiation process while two have already been provisionally closed. I sincerely hope that at least three more chapters will be opened at the intergovernmental conference in December.  Three points are of utmost importance on Serbia’s path towards the European Union. Firstly, the rule of law. I would like to use this opportunity to recall that Serbia’s progress on the rule of law – Chapters 23 and 24 – remains essential for the overall pace of the negotiating process. Judicial independence has to be assured in practice. Corruption and organised crime still remain an obstacle, not only to Serbia’s but to all Western Balkan countries’ democratic, social and economic development.  On another note, I agree with the European Commission and the Council on guaranteeing unhindered exercise of the freedom of expression and media. Shortcomings in this area should be addressed as a matter of priority.  Secondly, the economy. The criteria for membership are intended to help Serbia to stand on its own feet and become fit for the European Union, the common market, and for the global economy in general. The government in Belgrade is implementing an impressive agenda of economic and structural reforms. This has already yielded results in terms of growth prospects and reduction of domestic and external imbalances.  Thirdly, regional cooperation and good neighbourly relations. We all know Serbia’s EU accession process is closely linked to the normalisation of relations with Kosovo. Agreements need to be concluded and, afterwards, implemented. That said, both sides – Belgrade and Priština – should continue to move forward with the full implementation of the already—reached agreements in good faith and in a timely manner. Serbia and Kosovo have expressed on many occasions concerns about their relations. The format where these concerns should be addressed is the Brussels dialogue. The decision of the Kosovo government to increase tax on goods from Serbia and from Bosnia and Herzegovina to 100% clearly violates the CEFTA Agreement and the spirit of the EU—Kosovo stabilisation and association agreement. I call on the government in Priština to revoke this decision immediately.  A final remark – effective communication is key. We, as the European Union, are by far the most important donor in the Western Balkans. We are engaged in several thousand projects to support reform efforts and assist in preparations for EU membership. If too many people in the region are voicing a sentiment of being left alone by the EU, we need to take this seriously. It shows that there is an urgent need for the European Union to communicate effectively about the extent of our engagement.

name: Karoline EDTSTADLER
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, on behalf of the Austrian Presidency, it is my great pleasure to participate in your discussion on the series of annual reports from the Commission, starting with the one on Serbia.  As you know, this year the Western Balkans have been in the spotlight of the European Union, highlighted in particular by the EU leaders meeting with the Western Balkans leaders in Sofia in May and the adoption of the Council conclusions on Enlargement and Stabilisation and Association Process in June. During our Presidency, we have continued to pursue the Union’s engagement with the region, aiming to achieve further progress in the accession negotiations. This is one of the priorities of our Presidency.   Serbia has made important progress since the last country report by the Commission in 2016 and accession negotiations have advanced at a steady pace, as has already been mentioned by the rapporteur. We hope to keep up the momentum in Serbia’s accession negotiations under our Presidency by opening further negotiation chapters. In the June Council conclusions, we welcomed the reaffirmed commitment of the Serbian Government to EU integration as its strategic objective. This also needs to be further demonstrated by Serbia’s commitment to reforms, because progress on the rule of law and fundamental rights chapters, as well as on the normalisation of Serbia’s relations with Kosovo, as set out in the negotiation framework, is essential and will continue to determine the pace of accession negotiations overall.  Many areas which require further reform efforts are rightly spelt out in your draft resolution. The implementation of interim benchmarks for Chapters 23 and 24 and of the respective action plans should continue to guide the reform process as the rule of law continues to be at the heart of the enlargement process. As you do in your draft resolution, we consider that Serbia needs to significantly step up its reform efforts in this area and, in particular, to ensure the independence and overall efficiency of the judicial system.  Special focus should be put on tangible results and a sustainable track record, notably as regards the fight against corruption, organised crime and money laundering. The lack of progress in the area of freedom of expression raises increasing concerns. We strongly believe that the authorities should guarantee a safe climate conducive to the unhindered exercise of freedom of expression and the independence of the media as a matter of priority.  Serbia also needs to pay particular attention to full respect for fundamental rights, including the protection of the most vulnerable groups, as well as the non-discriminatory treatment of national minorities throughout Serbia. Guaranteeing the rule of law and fundamental rights would also contribute to improving the business environment in Serbia and underpin the current positive economic developments and the continuous progress made in this area.  The normalisation of relations with Kosovo continues to be essential for the overall pace of negotiations. The Council will continue to monitor closely Serbia’s engagement towards visible and sustainable progress here so that Serbia and Kosovo can continue on their respective European paths. We continue to call on Serbia to progressively align with EU common foreign and security policy, in line with the negotiation framework. Serbia should also refrain from diverging from the EU common visa policy as Serbia’s conclusion of visa liberalisation agreements with certain third countries has raised real concerns. We note that Serbia has, in the meantime, revoked again its visa liberalisation regime with Iran.  We stress the importance of regional cooperation and good neighbourly relations. We encourage Serbia to continue sustained efforts to strengthen good neighbourly relations and to resolve outstanding bilateral issues. In this context, actions undermining regional cooperation are not helpful. We regret the introduction of tariffs by Kosovo on products originating from Serbia and Bosnia and Herzegovina. There is an urgent need for calm and de—escalation in the interest of the whole region. We welcome Commissioner Hahn’s offer of help to work on rapid practical solutions to the various trade issues at hand. I will conclude my intervention by again welcoming the continued progress in Serbia’s EU accession negotiations and the continued good cooperation with the EU and within the region.  Finally, let me also recall our appreciation for the constructive contribution of Parliament, and in particular of your rapporteur, David McAllister, to advance Serbia’s accession process to the EU. I can assure you that we pay particular attention to the views of Parliament in this regard.

name: Karoline EDTSTADLER
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, State Secretary, I would like to congratulate, first and foremost, David McAllister for his outstanding report on Serbia. This is a balanced and accurate assessment of Serbia’s progress on its path to the European Union. It’s also in line with the findings of our own report of April this year and the Commission’s assessment since then. I share your view that Serbia has made good progress towards EU membership. With 14 chapters opened and two provisionally closed, Serbia’s prospects for joining the EU are tangible, and this shows our firm commitment to Serbia’s EU path. This European perspective is even more important today when we witness a resurfacing of tensions between Belgrade and Priština. Let me stress once again that both sides need to resume dialogue. There is no alternative to this if they want to make progress on their European paths. No country can join the Union without having resolved outstanding bilateral issues. For Serbia, this means that it needs to conclude a legally binding agreement with Priština before it can join the Union. However, let me also stress that the solution with Kosovo is not the only prerequisite on Serbia’s path to the Union. Reforms in the area of rule of law, fundamental rights and good governance, remain at the heart of the country’s accession process. And, similar to the findings in your report, we found a mixed picture in our recent assessment on the rule of law in Serbia. Serbia has adopted some important pieces of legislation and carried out necessary institutional reforms. However, delays have been building up in important areas and concrete results are still difficult to demonstrate. It’s therefore crucial that efforts increase in fields such as the reform of the judiciary, anti—corruption and fundamental rights, including media freedom. In addition, and this is particularly relevant for this House, we have concerns about the process of adopting legislation in the Serbian Parliament. The continued use of urgent procedures, as well as other practices, limits legislative scrutiny and debate. I also share your views that strategic communication is of key importance. It will ensure public support for European values and understanding of the benefits and obligations of EU accession. The Union is by far Serbia’s most important partner, including on assistance, and without any possible comparison with other global players. This needs to be put up in lights. Finally, whatever the difficulties – and they are real – Serbia should not lose sight of its EU membership goal. It should keep focusing on fundamental reforms, with continued EU support, and I really appreciate that the European Parliament is on the same page. I thank you, not only for your attention, but for your strong commitment, engagement and support on the ground.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, I would first of all like to congratulate David McAllister on his report to Parliament. It is, as Commissioner Hahn said, a very balanced report. I would be very happy for Serbia to become a Member State of the European Union in 2025, but of course there is much to be done in this regard. I believe that dialogue with the Kosovars is a key dialogue. Unfortunately, behold, obstacles arise that we can only look at with stupefaction. Kosovo's recent decision to introduce taxes on products from Serbia and Bosnia and Herzegovina is a big mistake. The Serbs don't let themselves down either. I recently heard Prime Minister Brnabić explain that Srebrenica was not a genocide because only men and boys were killed, not women and girls. This is unacceptable, and unfortunately I know that in Republika Srpska, the Banjaluka parliament also decided to revoke the report declaring Srebrenica genocide. I believe that Serbia's influence in Bosnia and Herzegovina and in general in the region must be a positive one, based on moderation, and any statement of the kind of the recent one of the Prime Minister in Belgrade I think should be avoided.

name: Tanja FAJON
text: On behalf of the S&D Group.  The rift between the Union documents and the reality of the country appears to be remarkable.  While Serbia has favourable economic indicators, the rule of law, the deep polarisation of society and freedom of the media remain a concern. Here is an example of one of the headlines in Serbia: 'Dogs are released' with a photograph of a handful of those who still manage to criticise them out loud, and this is unacceptable, Serbia is moving away from the Union.  The people of Serbia tell me that they want to be part of the Union, they want more jobs and higher wages, less corruption, a functioning legal system.  The Union will never be perfect without Serbia, but one serbia in which, instead of news of the beaten members of the opposition, we read about a healthy democracy in which relations with Kosovo are regulated instead of nationalist ball-handing, of which young people are proud and have a vision at home.  And that is the kind of Serbia I see in the Union, and I will still stand up for such Serbia.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: on behalf of the ECR Club. – Dear Chairman, the accession process should be a merit-based process that depends entirely on the objective progress of each candidate country.  In this regard, I hold extremely worrying the moderate tone by which this report approaches the issue of punishing war crimes in Serbia. The conclusion is imposed on itself that Serbia is either looking through its fingers, or no detailed and due diligence has been done. Both scenarios are disturbing. War criminals in Serbia are neither investigated nor punished. Currently, serbia's ruling set uses inadmissible methods to cover up crimes committed in Croatia and Bosnia and Herzegovina. In the Ovcara case, which relates to the massacre of nearly 300 wounded from a Vukovar hospital, the government protects criminals, grants them immunity, new identities and obstructs the work of other states in investigating these crimes. Therefore, from this High House, I call on all my colleagues in the European Parliament and the competent Commissioners to finally open their eyes to prevent notorious criminals responsible for the deaths of hundreds of people from walking freely in the European Union and so that such methods do not become an integral part of the European justice system.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the Rapporteur, – Honourable President, Honourable Commissioner, I would like to thank you for the conscientious and quality work done by the rapporteur, Mr David McAllister. On behalf of the ALDE Group, I can assure you that we support Serbia's integration into the European Union, and I would like to express my satisfaction at the progress of the negotiations so far on the adaptation of the legislation to make this possible. As shadow rapporteur, I would also like to make some critical remarks: Serbia will have to do more to respect the rule of law, to establish truly pluralistic, democratic relations in its parliament and to respect the opposition and its role, to guarantee media freedom, which is seriously threatened, the security and integrity of journalists, especially research, those who are critical of the government. A higher level of communication culture is needed, the elimination of hate speech, both domestic use and serbia's international communication with its neighbours. Such and only such Serbia will be a welcome member of the European Union in the future.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Mr President, commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, i would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent work. – First of all, thank you to my colleague McAllister for his excellent work in preparing this report.  It is unambiguously noted that Serbia has made progress in several areas in the observed period: public administration reform, market economy, economic growth, macroeconomic, monetary stability and progress in the fight against corruption and organised crime.  However, since Serbia is, of course, an important player in the region itself, it is all the more important to monitor and also react to certain statements by the most prominent representatives, which can sometimes go in the wrong direction. Therefore, certain amendments are also tabled.  What I'd like... (The President shall withdraw the speaker's word.)

name: Jaromír KOHLÍČEK
text: on the part of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, at the beginning of the report on Serbia, it is considered normal to express the International Court of Justice in the context of UN General Assembly Resolution 64/298 of 2010, which de facto took note of kosovo's unilateral declaration of independence. What hypocrisy! Serbia, for all its efforts to weaken it, is still a key country in the middle of the Balkans, even after NATO's bloody aggression. Moreover, his leadership was considered a prime candidate in the last evaluation of the candidate countries. I strongly object to the attempt to determine who this candidate country can and cannot cooperate with in foreign and defence policy. I draw the attention of my esteemed colleagues to the long-term peaceful coexistence of dozens of national minorities in the northeastern part of the country. If only minorities in the Baltic countries or other EU countries had similar conditions deemed insufficient by the author of the report.  Despite Serbia's goodwill, but due to little cooperation on the part of Kosovo, technical problems related to the illegal secession of the territory from Serbia are not satisfactorily addressed. However, this is a task mainly for the European Commission. Mrs Tomašić, even murderers from Croatia should not run around the EU, not just from other Balkan states.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the report, which is undoubtedly balanced, welcomes Serbia's continued commitment to integration into the European Union and wonders whether this strategic decision is being actively promoted among the Serbian public; This is not an easy task, knowing the popular favour for serbia's inclusion in Moscow's Eurasian strategy. This must be taken into account, because it can also play a very important role in relations between Europe, the European Union and the world in Moscow. We must not forget the message that President Putin sent directly to Vučić: within a few hours he can send a rapid intervention force to defend the Kosovo Serbs. Europe is a mountains of paper; Putin reacts. The unresolved problem of Kosovo is central. Recently, Kosovo and Serbia met and spoke to try to normalise relations, a step that is clearly necessary for integration into the European Union. In September, they had come one step away from signing an agreement and then everything was compromised, despite the fact that there was an agreement to return to Kosovo the Serbian territories inhabited by ethnic Albanians in Kosovo and to Serbia those Kosovar territories with ethnic Serbian majority. At the last minute, the agreement was skipped and there was a clear risk that the tensions of the last few days, especially those linked to the unconscious introduction of tariffs, could block or slow down the new attempts at reconciliation between the two States, which we obviously see with great hope and favour.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. The report calls on the Serbian Government to implement international treaties on the rights of national minorities. It notes that no progress has been made in guaranteeing the rights of national minorities, and that what has happened is not satisfactory. There is an action plan, but it should be fully implemented. It draws Serbia's attention to the provision of minority language use in education, public administration and the media.  It is regrettable that the same findings are included in the previous report, i.e. no progress, while the protection of the rights of national minorities is a prerequisite for EU accession. It is time to call on Serbia to comply with them instead of finding them. We do not wish more for the national minorities living in Serbia, including the indigenous Hungarian population in Vojvodina, than Serbia expects for Serbs in Kosovo.

name: Victor BOŞTINARU
text: – Mr President, I will start by congratulating David McAllister for his excellent and very balanced report.  I would like to emphasise the most important thing, which is that Serbia has made tremendous efforts to implement the most needed democratic reforms and Serbia is to be judged on its own merits. This is the only way forward for the enlargement process to remain credible and give a clear perspective to the Serbian people and to the people from the region as well.  Of course, there are still important steps to be taken in order to achieve the full alignment of Serbia’s foreign and security policy with the EU one – and I am referring notably to the problems relating to its relations with Russia.  We Socialists and Democrats remain concerned about the situation regarding freedom of expression and freedom of the media. At the same time, I have to repeat, and I will never stop saying – people in Belgrade, the ruling coalition, should treat the opposition fairly and should work with the opposition, in their country’s best interests.  Finally, I welcome Serbia’s engagement in the normalisation of relations with Kosovo. But in this situation I do condemn the decision taken by Priština by increasing to 100% the taxes on imports from Serbia and Bosnia and Herzegovina.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would first like to pay tribute to Serbia on the centenary of the First World War. 16% of its population perished in this war. Serbia was the first victim of this world war in percentage terms, France in number. Once again, it was the empires that fought this war, wanted by the Second Reich, among others, and the nations, such as Serbia and France, that suffered it.  But Serbia suffers new martyrs: the Union demands that Belgrade choose between East and West, against its history, its culture, its identity. She's a bridge. The Union also obliges it to recognise the independence of Kosovo, a territory that was torn from it by a war of illegal aggression with NATO in 1999.  The Union, somewhere, is a permanent coup against peoples, nations and their identity.  Do we want to force Serbia to choose one side against the other, when it is one of these two common stories? Do we want to prevent it from regaining its history when Kosovo and its legitimate power is given to a mafia disguised as a state? We have to stop this Drang nach Osten policy. It only leads to war and can only lead to war.

name: Eduard KUKAN
text: – Mr President, this is a really good report on Serbia. I would like to thank David McAllister. The report strikes the right balance with points that underline the progress Serbia has made over the last year, but also the areas where we would like to see more done. The accession process should not be taken for granted. It’s a chance to reform, not only in terms of technical requirements, but also to adjust to the values and principles of the European Union. We have seen good progress in some reforms. Yet there are still many key areas where more effort is needed. Let us be clear: the rule of law and the independence of the judiciary is one of the fundamentals of the accession process. Serbia needs to engage seriously in these reforms, strengthening the accountability, impartiality, professionalism and overall efficiency of the judiciary. I would also like to underline the need to improve the atmosphere concerning freedom of the media.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: – Dear Chairman, I would like to immediately support this report and say that we are in a classic position. We all know that Serbia has done a lot, and there is much more to be done. We all want to see Serbia in this house one day, see lawmakers and lawmakers here and we all want to support it, but Serbia has to do its homework.  As a man who in Croatia did everything possible to help the Serb minority when it was threatened in places where it was threatened, I want to make it clear now that I want to support the Croatian minority that is in Serbia and that it needs to be discussed because it is also one of the problems in Vojvodina.  Others talked about other needs serbia needs to meet, but it is important that we talk about both human and minority rights and, of course, what is, unfortunately, still a difficult legacy of the balkan conflict that was in the 1990s.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: – Unfortunately, I was interrupted before the end of the speech itself, so i would like to have a few more thoughts below.  The fact is that, in addition to these signs of progress and chapters, where Serbia seems to be going down the right path, there are, of course, other topics and areas where there is a lot of room for improvement.  Colleagues have repeatedly mentioned freedom of expression and freedom of the media. In particular, the warnings of Serbia's NGOs testify that there is still plenty of room for improvement here. And it is precisely this communication with the non-government sector that I think is one of the opportunities for the situation in Serbia, for example, to be brought together, for example, by the government or an NGO.  And, as rapporteur for Kosovo, I would, of course, like the constructiveness of the dialogue between Belgrade and Prishina to continue. Of course, this is not the right answer to the increase in customs duties, and I think that, of course, both sides must maintain activities that deteriorate relations.  And there's a lot of effort and progress.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, a major challenge is at stake in the Western Balkans for the future and for the stability of our entire continent, and we want to make our contribution to winning it. Serbia is a friendly country, close geographically but also close to our values, traditions and culture and european spirit. I would like to thank the rapporteur for his important efforts and in this report he highlights the progress made by Serbia in recent years, including on sensitive issues, such as regional cooperation, minority rights, the judiciary and the rule of law.  Of course, further progress is needed in the fight against corruption, organised crime and media independence: but we are and remain confident and optimistic. Our vote in favour is precisely intended to underline these efforts of the Serbian people on their way to accession to the European Union, without, however, asking them to distort Serbia's traditional relations with other partners. We are concerned about the recent tensions with Kosovo, but I would like to reiterate that there can be no truly united Europe without the incidental Balkans or without Serbia. That is why we hope to open further negotiating chapters so that we can soon write together an important new chapter in European history: the 2025 objective.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Mr President, all I have to say to the friendly Serbian nation is that they will have to think about it very well before they decide to join the European Union. Serbia already has a developed industry and has all the conditions to become a stable force in its region in the future. Its economy is constantly growing, after the previous difficult decades, and it has every reason to look optimistically to the future. Membership of the Union may initially seem like an advantageous option, but in the long run it is not. For every euro of financial assistance provided by the Union, it also calls for a part of national independence. Unfortunately, we in Greece are now well aware of the price of membership. We saw in practice what European solidarity means when, during the economic crisis, Europeans tried - and are still trying - by all means to seize Greek public property, while ignoring the suffering they have caused and are causing to the Greek people. The Greeks will support any decision by Serbia, as long as it is taken in the light of the will of the Serbian people and the interests of the country.

name: Andor DELI
text: – Mr President, during the summer we could see some promising signals connected to the Belgrade—Priština negotiations, but recent economic measures and other acts of provocation by the Kosovo government triggered events which are undermining not just bilateral relations but also EU efforts in the region, such as with the Common Economic Area. It is high time for the Council to take action. The lack of European leadership in the Western Balkans is getting more and more obvious and pressing. The Commission does play a very important role but political decisions must be made by political bodies such as the Council, together with the Member States. They must stop hiding behind the Commission’s skirt of technocratic and bureaucratic criteria, benchmarks and checklists. Hoping that legal harmonisation and reaching European standards will automatically solve the issues on the Balkans are illusory and naive. They must take these matters seriously, otherwise we will have, as was always the case, the US and Russia rushing in solving European issues.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Mr President, as is apparent from Mr McAllister's balanced report, Serbia is working to harmonise with the requirements of the Copenhagen criteria in order to become a member of the European Union. It has an obligation to normalise its relations with Kosovo. This is an emotionally burdensome obligation for Serbia, because we all know that Kosovo is the cradle of Serbian culture, it is the depth of Serbia's heart. Nevertheless, Kosovo is challenging Serbia and making efforts to normalise relations difficult. It is, as we said, causing Serbia and the biggest challenge at the moment is the 100% increase in tariffs on imports of products from Serbia and Bosnia. Serbia must react and the European Union must not only press Serbia to change its policy towards Russia, but also Kosovo. As a Greek, I hope that Serbia's efforts will succeed and join the European Union under good conditions.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: – Serbia is not easy to assess, especially as it cannot be taken out of the context of the hot Balkans. For this reason, congratulations to David McAllister, not only for the report prepared, but also for the opinion that accompanies it. In particular, these two key sentences, which concern the assessment of the rule of law, and in particular the mention of chapters 23 and 24 as genuinely crucial, which will determine whether Serbia, possibly, after accession, will not be the source of legal problems related to the rule of law.  I also share the assessment, the latter much more favourable in terms of changes in the economy. Indeed, serbia has done a great deal in this matter, it can be assessed positively and keep our fingers crossed for the remaining paragraphs, chapters, so that indeed this preparation does not raise doubts.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: – Dear Chairman, I appreciate the efforts that Rapporteur David McAllister is making to support Serbia's European perspective. I am sorry that Serbia does not give a satisfactory answer to the outstretched hand of support.  Sometimes I feel like there are no significant developments, because there is no political will. How else to explain that Serbia continues to violate the rights of the Croatian national minority, that to date it has not provided data on prisoners and missing persons and that it does not prosecute its war criminals, but allows them to be politically active and even members of the Assembly? How do you interpret the Serbian law that took serbia's role as little Hague and is a threat to all Croatian defenders? It is not acceptable for Serbian border police to arrest Croatian citizens, who are also defenders, subjected them to humiliation and threats to intimidate them into stopping investigating war crimes, which are the result of Thessaloniki's aggression against Croatia.  All this supports the thesis that Serbia is going astray, not the European path, and the only thing I can do is express regret for it.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: (PPE). – Congratulations, David, for an excellent and balanced report. I agree with that part, where you draw attention to shortcomings in progress in the rule of law, freedom of the media. I am pleased that you can also highlight progress in the area of the economy, which is crucial that Serbia too will prosper and that young people will remain in Serbia, which is a key condition.  I would also like to congratulate and thank Mr Hahn, who has done an excellent job in the Western Balkans, and I think he is doing what is most necessary to improve regional cooperation. From the recent examples of customs duties from Kosovo, which I strongly condemn, it is clear how demanding this work is and congratulations on your work.  I am convinced that it will be necessary to continue in this area, because the situation in relation to both Serbia-Kosovo, Serbia-Croatia and others needs moderation by the European Union.  I support that as many chapters as possible be opened to move forward. Without regulating regional relations, where the European Union will play a key role, it is difficult to imagine Serbia's entry into the European Union.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, State Secretary, again thank you for this very interesting and ultimately encouraging debate, which reflects the importance of the enlargement process and of our relations with Serbia.  I fully appreciate the sensitivity of bilateral issues. Clearly, further efforts will be needed to overcome the legacy of the past and to foster trust and reconciliation. At the same time we should ensure that bilateral issues don’t hamper the firm prospect of EU membership, which continues to drive transformation and anchor stability and security in Serbia and elsewhere in the region. Today this is more important than ever. At the same time we should focus on good neighbourly relations, democratic values and respect for the rule of law, protection of national minorities, freedom of expression and of the media, the ability to address the legacy of the past, and war crimes issues. Those are core European values and these are simply not negotiable.  Thank you for your attention and also for your strong commitment.

name: Karoline EDTSTADLER
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, to conclude, I would like to thank honourable Members very much for this really useful debate. I have listened attentively to the views expressed. We look forward to continuing this constructive dialogue and engagement. When moving ahead in the accession process with Serbia, I would like to assure you that we closely monitor its progress, paying particular attention to the area of the rule of law, freedom of the media, the Belgrade—Priština dialogue and the other important issues which were mentioned here today.

name: David McALLISTER
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, Madam Secretary of State, Commissioner, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. First of all, I would like to thank both of you for the kind words and the factual references to my report. I would also like to thank all the Members who have taken part in this debate, which I consider to be largely objective. I would like to thank you for your praise, and I would also like to thank you for the critical remarks. I would like to warmly welcome the Ambassador of the Republic of Serbia, Mrs Hrustanovic, to the gallery, who I believe has also seen today that, in this debate across group borders, we have made it clear that we are prepared to give Serbia a positive welcome on a long, not always easy but steady road towards the European Union. I think there is a lot of potential in this country. Serbia is a European cultural nation. I very much welcome the fact that this country is so clearly on a pro-European approach. I believe that what is important now, Madam Secretary of State, when the Council meets, is that the Member States choose to open further chapters so that the reform process continues to receive active support in Serbia. Once again, thank you very much for the good cooperation, for the many amendments that we have brought together in compromises. It would be nice if we adopted this report tomorrow with a broad parliamentary majority in order to make it clear that the European Parliament stands alongside the pro-European forces in this great country.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: I close the debate. The vote will take place on Thursday 29 November 2018. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. What about this unsympatheated report, which permeates an anti-sedt bias that the rapporteur does not even try to conceal?  First of all, it is unacceptable to equate a possible exchange of territories between Serbia and Kosovo with the creation of an "ethnically pure" state. Secondly, at a time when the European Union is making a strong case of imposing recognition of Kosovo on Serbia, it is failing to demand that It withdraw its measure applying 100% tariffs on Serbian imports.  Moreover, the stinging failure on Monday of European Commissioner Johannes Hahn on a visit to Pristina says everything we need to know about the real influence of Brussels in a powder keg in the Balkans where the spark is never far away, despite the various and varied privileges generously granted to Kosovo, as does its early participation in certain European programmes.  But the most unacceptable is the real blackmail against Serbia over its relations with Russia, which reveals the very essence of a European project resolutely contrary to national interests.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: The next item is the report by Igor Šoltes, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, on the Commission's 2018 report on Kosovo (2018/2149(INI)) (A8-0332/2018).

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: I'm not going to be – Thank you very much to the President for the floor. Yours, of course, also to the honourable Commissioner and the Representative of the Council. First of all, I would like to thank all the shadow rapporteurs for their excellent work and for all the suggestions and amendments that we have received during this time of drafting of the report. The guiding principle in the preparation of the report is, above all, that there is a... the way in which progress has been made and also draw attention to topics and areas where shortcomings still exist and where improvements are needed. To highlight a few key points in the report, I would like to start this way: Kosovo has, of course, taken an important step forward in the observed period, progress, but which has not been quite as we wanted. We would like more in many areas, and in many areas there are still visible parts that will need to be improved. The reason goes out in external circumstances, but especially in internal circumstances, because sometimes it seems difficult for political groups in parliament to reach consensus, and also sometimes in the communication between political groups, that sometimes the legislation that should be passed is harder to break through in parliament. Above all, it is important that the laws adopted in the Parliament in Kosovo then experience implementation. Because it doesn't help much if we have laws as good as that, but we don't use them. However, at this point, I would, of course, draw attention to one of the topics that is extremely important, that is visa liberalisation. We have repeatedly reiterated that Kosovo has fulfilled all the required criteria, including the ratification of the border with Montenegro, which took place in March this year after more than two years of negotiations, and thus, in fact, opened the door to visa liberalisation. And this has been given the green light by both the Commission and Parliament. And also because of the credibility of the European institutions, I think it is now also on the side of Europe to fulfil its part of the agreement, and that is to allow visa liberalisation for the people of Kosovo and, in this way, to equate them with everyone else in the region. When I mentioned the laws, I must say that Kosovo has adopted quite a few important laws that can be regarded as progress. However, as I said, the report also mentions the problems of corruption and organised crime, which are still present, and it seems that a great additional effort will be needed to maximise the independence of the judicial branch of the authorities and to further strengthen the work in the field of record-keeping on the investigation of high-level corruption. This is where many of those involved, including in the region, will need to participate. Of course, in the end, I cannot pass the dialogue between Belgrade and Prishina, and we all want the situation to be as normalised as possible and to move on and to continue with the talks in search of a solution and to meet those requirements that... to which both countries have committed themselves. And, of course, the European Commission, as Parliament, is watching closely. I would, of course, mention, and without that, it is not that bilateral relations are not resolved by excessive measures, and this imposition of customs duties does not improve relations between Prishina and Belgrade. And I believe that consideration and different action is needed and that such decisions are withdrawn. Finally, of course, we all want Kosovo to move forward on these outstanding issues, too. And here I am convinced that the EU can also offer its support and cooperation.

name: Karoline EDTSTADLER
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Thank you Mr President, honourable Members, dear Commissioner, dear rapporteur Šoltes.  Let me start by underlining the importance of the Stabilisation and Association Agreement. This agreement offers Kosovo an opportunity for sustainable progress and rapprochement with the European Union.  It is therefore essential for Kosovo to continue working on the implementation of the agreement. Here we concur with your view that Kosovo should pay particular attention to improving the rule of law, including traditional independence and due process of law. Kosovo also needs to continue its fight against organised crime and corruption, which should be a clear priority of the authorities. Consensus across the political spectrum is key to advancing Kosovo's European agenda. We share your view that the Assembly is the key forum for legislative work and political dialogue. A strong political will is required from all political actors to move Kosovo forward.  Turning to the EU-facilitated dialogue between Belgrade and Pristina, we welcome the commitment of both sides to work with the High Representative on a comprehensive normalisation of relations, including in the form of a legally binding agreement. We both agree that this is key for their respective European paths and essential for sustainable regional stability. The Council will continue to monitor closely Kosovo's engagement towards visible and sustainable progress here so that Serbia and Kosovo can continue on their respective European paths. We stress the importance of regional cooperation and good neighbourly relations. We encourage Kosovo to continue sustained efforts to strengthen good neighbourly relations and to resolve outstanding bilateral issues. In this context, actions undermining regional cooperation are not helpful. We regret the introduction of tariffs by Kosovo on products originating from Serbia and Bosnia and Herzegovina. There is an urgent need for calm and de-escalation in the interests of the whole region and, again, we welcome Commissioner Hahn’s offer of help to work on rapid and practical solutions for the various trade issues at hand. Let me add a few comments on the visa liberalisation process, which as we know is high on the political agenda in Kosovo. We join the European Parliament in welcoming the ratification by the Kosovo Assembly of the border boundary agreement with Montenegro in March 2018. This fulfilled one of the key criteria for Kosovo's visa liberalisation and was an important achievement in the spirit of good neighbourly relations.  Let me recall here the Commission proposal in May 2016 to transfer Kosovo to the Schengen visa-free list and the Commission's report on the fulfilment of the remaining benchmarks in July 2018. We note that the Parliament has adopted its mandate and is ready to start negotiating with the Council on the proposal to waive visa requirements for Kosovo.  However, as you are aware, the decision on the Commission proposal is currently under consideration in the Council. Today in our discussions we focus on Kosovo's progress in 2017. However, also more generally, I would like to stress that the EU will continue to support Kosovo by putting particular emphasis on furthering Kosovo’s socio-economic reform agenda, including through financial and technical assistance. Economic growth and creating employment is a main concern of its people.  Let me finally welcome the agreement reached on the extension of the EULEX mission and underline the importance of continued close and effective cooperation with EULEX.

name: Karoline EDTSTADLER
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, first of all, I would like to thank the Parliament, and in particular the rapporteur, Mr Šoltes, for the report on Kosovo. I believe that it is a balanced report and is in line with the main findings of our 2018 Commission report regarding progress and challenges in Kosovo. But we cannot hide the fact that today the discussion is overshadowed by what has been happening in recent weeks in Kosovo. The recent decisions by the Kosovo Government to impose a trade tariff increase of up to 100% against Serbia and Bosnia and Herzegovina are very concerning and doing real harm to relations with Kosovo and regional cooperation ambitions. As we have said clearly, these decisions are a clear violation of the Central European Free Trade Agreement and contrary to the spirit of the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Union and Kosovo. This is why the European Union has called on the Kosovo Government to immediately revoke these decisions. Imposing blanket measures is not the appropriate way to address trade concerns. They must be addressed in the appropriate fora. I have already spoken with the Prime Minister and the President, who agreed on the urgent need to calm and de—escalate, in the interests of the country and the whole region, and offered a rapid and practical solution for the various trade issues at hand between Kosovo and Serbia. I will also use the opportunity of my planned visit to Pristina next week to help find a way out of this crisis. But now let me turn back briefly to the assessment in our 2018 report on Kosovo. As already noted also in Parliament’s report, the picture is a mixed one. We underline progress in certain areas, such as on the investment climate. We also welcome the ratification by the Kosovo Assembly of the Agreement on Border Demarcation with Montenegro last March, which was an important breakthrough. However, our overall conclusion is that Kosovo’s pace of EU—related reforms is too slow. This is partly due to a very high political polarisation and the fact that the Assembly has not been functioning as it should. Unfortunately, these conclusions are still valid today. We therefore expect all political actors to increase efforts to build consensus on strategic issues for Kosovo, in particular EU—related priority reforms and on the dialogue with Serbia. Let me now turn to visa liberalisation, which is of particular importance to Kosovo’s citizens. Kosovo has worked hard in recent years to meet its visa liberalisation roadmap criteria. Last July, the Commission confirmed that Kosovo had fulfilled all outstanding criteria. We continue to stand by our assessment that all benchmarks have been met and continue to be met. I welcome Parliament’s clear support for the Commission’s proposal on visa liberalisation. Your report also – rightly so – insists that the authorities in Kosovo demonstrate sustained efforts in the fight against organised crime and corruption. The ball is now in the Council’s court. I hope that the Council will demonstrate that when our partners deliver, the EU delivers too. In that respect I would like to thank the Austrian Presidency for its efforts to put this on the agenda and to try to start negotiations on this subject. The Commission remains committed to Kosovo and to giving Kosovo a real European perspective. We will continue to support Kosovo in its reform processes in important areas such as the rule of law, public administration, the economy and education. However, we need to see a clear commitment from Kosovo’s leaders to focus their attention on measures that will bring Kosovo closer to Europe.

name: Eduard KUKAN
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, Kosovo has seen turbulent political months. While some issues have moved forward, not much overall progress has been achieved. We are expecting more from the political leaders of Kosovo. We need to see a genuine commitment to the reform process, especially in the rule of law and the fight against corruption. However, political polarisation, and the lack of consensus and efficient work of the Kuvendi hinders progress on EU—related issues. Moreover, escalating tensions between Belgrade and Pristina resulted in unprecedented tariffs and the waste of very valuable time in reaching the agreement. Finally, the last reporting period in Kosovo has been marked by the fulfilment of requirements for a visa—free regime. This was confirmed by the Commission in July and by this House in September 2018. I will, therefore, appeal to the Council, and especially to the Austrian Presidency, to recognise this progress and move forward with granting a visa—free regime for Kosovo.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I should like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for the comprehensive and inclusive report that has been produced. The report highlights progress but, at the same time, what remains to be done, particularly as regards public administration, the judicial system and the fight against crime. Furthermore, on the subject of human rights, we call for greater integration of gender policies, the protection of minorities, in particular the Roma and Ashkali, and discrimination against LGBT people.  While stressing, as the Commissioner has done, the problematic tax choices made recently by Kosovo, I would remind you that in July the European Commission said that Kosovo has finally fulfilled all the necessary conditions for visa liberalisation. After the European Parliament's vote, the decision must now be taken in the Council; achieving this result is crucial for stabilisation, integration and cooperation with this geographically fundamental region for the European Union. Finally, it is important, for the normalisation of relations with Serbia, that the five European countries that have not yet done so recognise Kosovo, thank you.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – First, I would like to congratulate My Colleague Scholes on the report he has made. He is extremely prepared and extremely well motivated and in depth investigates and examines the situation in which Kosovo is currently located. All with alarm, it is likely that each of you will join this alert, we are monitoring the situation at the moment, the growing tensions in relations with one of Kosovo's neighbors, as well as the ongoing internal tensions within the country itself, which is not in the interest of either Kosovo citizens or helping change, reforms in Kosovo and its path of integration into the European Union , where that country's path is. Dear Commissioner, I would like to ask you specifically to pay more attention to the rights and legitimate interests of the various minorities in Kosovo, because there are significant problems and provocations. They are visible, and can not be left in this way. In particular, of course, I also address the rights and legitimate interests of the Bulgarian community in Kosovo.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, my thanks go to the rapporteur for the excellent report that shows that certain things are developing in a good direction in Kosovo, especially when it comes to the economy and economic criteria. However, certain other issues have to be worked on: relations with Serbia, certainly, and the rights of minorities, while the informal economy remains an issue, a big one. However, the ratification of the border agreement with Montenegro in March 2018 was important, a major breakthrough. On this matter, Kosovo showed that it fulfilled the criteria, together with the development of the economic area and together with the fight against corruption. It shows that it fulfilled the criteria to get the visa liberalisation, as the Commissioner has stated. Now it’s up to the Council to do its job. We cannot play with Kosovo, they fulfilled the criteria, we have to give them what we have promised.

name: Jaromír KOHLÍČEK
text: on the part of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, Kosovo, rightly Kosovo and Metohije, is the cradle of the Serbian state. The unlawful secession of that territory from Serbia, which is also contrary to UN Security Council Resolution 1244, is sufficient justification for not re-re-relinching the autonomy of that artificial State.  If the Balkans are referred to as the place of the greatest corruption in Europe, the place where the routes of drug distribution come from, where criminals from terrorist groups with their backgrounds cannot be convicted, and where the rule of law is absolute fiction, then this description best describes the situation in Kosovo. The report makes no mention of the illegal existence of the largest US base in Europe, Bond Steel, on the contrary, it seeks to find at least signs of positive developments. There is deep concern about some of the actions of local administration, including the practical unenforceability of the law and technical excesses, such as the disruption of Europe's interconnected electricity system by inappropriate action by local authorities.  I cannot agree with such a worded report. The Commission does not mind blocking the conduct of local authorities? Do you want to do visa liberalisation with this state, Commissioner?

name: Dominique BILDE
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, the Commission's reports are always the occasion for a proliferation of euphemisms. The one on Kosovo is no exception to the rule. We will appreciate the reference to the "early stage of the fight against organized crime" in this state at the heart of trafficking of all kinds. Worse, how can the Commission tout Kosovo's commitment to the normalisation process with Serbia when provocations continue at a dizzying pace? This is evidenced by the recent announcement of a 100% tax on Serbian imports, which is ironic at a time when Brussels is posing as a free trade champion against Donald Trump. Finally, what standardization are we talking about when, at the end of October, Orthodox pilgrims were greeted at Studenica Monastery with stones? The lifting of visas is all the more inconceivable as it may soon be about a bygone world, judging by the Albanian Prime Minister's call for Greater Albania, which is setting fire to the Balkan powder keg.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: – Dear Chairman, I congratulate my colleague Šoltes on a quality report. A clear perspective of EU membership must remain one of the incentives for implementing much-needed reforms in the Western Balkan countries, including in the case of Europe's youngest state. The good news from Kosovo, regarding eligibility for visa liberalisation, is not followed this time by good news from the European Union. Parliament and the Commission sent a clear message and supported the abolition of visas for Kosovo citizens to facilitate their travel, business and help fight people smuggling. I regret that the Council has not yet made possible the final liberalisation of the visa regime. This would be a clear message to Kosovo, but also to the region, that fulfilling its obligations always benefits, otherwise frustrations grow. Kosovo still has a big job in strengthening the rule of law, prosecuting politically motivated killings, fighting organised crime and corruption. Only tangible reform results justify further European support, which, in the case of Kosovo, must move from promises to implementing them.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. I was in Kosovo. There is no hiding the fact that this country has been the subject of controversy. It was created with great American help, which some Member States of the European Union looked at with some scepticism. From the perspective of years to come, we can say that it is certainly worth it for the European Union to invest in the Western Balkans at all and that their integration into the Union is part of stability. Creating a European perspective – not tomorrow, not the day after tomorrow, but even in the long term – will make Russian influence in that region smaller, to put it bluntly. Russia is constantly trying to play the Western Balkans card, even when it comes to Kosovo, and this must be seen.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: – Dear Chairman, I wish to briefly join this discussion since I was a rapporteur in the shadow of this report, and I have also visited Kosovo several times, as a member of the delegation. I know the situation in the region, I know the situation in Kosovo.  Relations between Serbia and Kosovo are very complicated, it is clear to everyone here and the commissioner said so. Normalising these relations will certainly not contribute to the introduction of tariffs and tariffs, but, likewise, visa liberalisation is something we promised them, something that this Parliament voted overwhelmingly on and certainly that kosovo citizens expect to be allowed visa liberalisation. I expect that the Council will decide on this soon, otherwise it will not be a good sign that citizens would experience this European path.  Likewise, the fight against corruption is necessary, reforms are necessary, this is evident, but also Kosovo is very important for the region and the situation in Kosovo is important for the whole of Europe, and especially for southeast Europe.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, as a friend of Kosovo, I am saddened to see that its participation in the European processes – in fact, its very existence, even – is still called into question in this House. On the contrary, colleagues, we should be putting all our efforts into Kosovo’s accession to the EU. As we engage with the country, I believe one of our priorities should be the fight against anti-gypsyism. Roma people remain a very marginalised group who face daily discrimination in all areas of life in Kosovo and everywhere else. We must double our efforts to achieve full equality for Roma people and this process should start with holding ourselves to account. In a country where the European Parliament was instrumental in ensuring compensation will be paid to women victims of sexual violence during the conflict, I’m appalled to see that the UN refuses to provide proper compensation for Roma, Ashkali and Egyptian people affected by lead poisoning in the UN-run camps. So the UN and us should lead by example. We must take responsibility for anything that caused wrongdoings or lifelong damage to affected … (The President cut off the speaker).

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: – Dear Chairman, one word is enough to describe relations between Kosovo and the European Union at the present day. That word is credibility to me.  The credibility of the European Union when it comes to visa liberalisation. After the vote of this Parliament, I expect a vote in the Council because our credibility is at stake since Kosovo, at least in this part, has fulfilled its conditions that we have given them.  Kosovo's credibility, on the other hand, has been called into question and their intention to join the European Union has been called into question with the imposition of 100% tariffs on Bosnia and Herzegovina and Serbia. If someone wants the Berlin process, if someone wants to enter the European Union, if someone wants to enter the single market, if someone wants regional cooperation, they can't impose 100% customs.  So, the credibility on our part that they could credibly ask Kosovo to adapt to us.

name: Jordi SOLÉ
text: – Mr President, I regret that five EU Member States still don’t recognise Kosovo as an independent state and I welcome the fact that the report from my colleague, Igor Šoltes, invites them to do so. One of the states that still denies this recognition is Spain. The controversial Foreign Affairs Minister, Josep Borrell, recently reiterated that his government wouldn’t change this position. This is the same minister who, in 2008, in a not very visionary and even less rigorous way, stated that the secession of Kosovo was illegal from the point of view of international law. This opinion was clearly discredited by the International Court of Justice which, in its 2010 opinion, established that general international law does not provide for prohibitions on declarations of independence, and therefore the declaration of Kosovo didn’t violate international law. For the sake of reconciliation in the Balkans and for the sake of European integration, Spain should recognise the states that are born of democratic decisions by their national parliaments.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this report balances the small progress and the various challenges that Kosovo still faces and which will mark the pace of its journey towards European integration. A long and fraught path of obstacles, which requires a constant commitment, determination and patience to carry out the reforms that the country urgently needs.
