In this respect, we must read mr Šoltes' report, for which I thank him: a further incentive to do better, especially in certain areas, such as the fight against corruption, organised crime, trafficking in human beings, drug trafficking, radicalisation and all forms of discrimination.  Bilateral relations with Serbia are undoubtedly of fundamental importance and must be based on a close, reliable, transparent dialogue and towards a binding and comprehensive standardisation agreement, agreed by both countries. I therefore call on the Kosovar authorities not to take rash decisions which undermine regional cooperation efforts. I refer in particular to the recent imposition of duties on goods imported from Serbia that violate the free trade rules in the CEFTA Agreement. Once again, dialogue must once again be the protagonist in solving the problems in the Western Balkans.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: Mr President, great corruption, organised crime, drug trafficking, trafficking in human beings, jihadists. This is the image of Kosovo, but also of Albania - to a different extent. We do not say it; You are pushing for the prospect of Kosovo joining the European Union and for albania and Skopje to join. The expansion of influence, yours and NATO -the leader of the SYRIZA-ANEL government in Greece, and the control of the Balkan corridor against Russia are what interests you alone; neither your criteria nor - of course - the interests of the peoples. Kosovo, a protectorate-American base that is a construct of the bombing and dissolution of Yugoslavia, continues to change borders to participate in Great Albania, the favorite child of the Americans, NATO and the Union, opening the appetite for territorial claims and others, such as the Albanians for Tsamuria and the Turks for the Aegean and Western Thrace. The "divide and conquer", which is insoulized by nationalisms, is a danger-death for the peoples, who must respond with concerted struggle and against your war plans, for real cooperation, security and peace.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I intend to travel to Pristina next week. The focus will be on the tariff decisions, but I’m also going to assess the implementation of the European Reform Agenda. I will be insisting that the Kosovan authorities need to get back to the issues that matter for Kosovo’s future, namely reforms and engagement in the dialogue. Kosovo’s priorities should remain the rule of law, economic development and education. Kosovo needs to become an attractive place for business, provide citizens with high—quality education and reduce the very high unemployment levels, in particular among young people. It’s also crucial that Kosovo continues to build confidence by demonstrating sustained progress in the fight against organised crime and corruption. The Commission is providing strong support for the implementation of these priorities through substantive financial assistance and technical advice. For this part Kosovo needs to keep pace with the rest of the region to promote economic growth and foster political stability, which is essential for the security of the Western Balkans as a whole. Regarding dialogue, it’s vital that Kosovo and Serbia remain committed to the full normalisation of their relations. A comprehensive, legally binding normalisation agreement should be reached as soon as possible. Both Kosovo and Serbia have expressed on many occasions concerns and grievances about their relations. They should be addressed through the dialogue which the European Union is committed to continue to facilitate. I would like to conclude by saying that the Commission remains strongly committed to driving forward Kosovo’s European agenda despite the current difficult political context.

name: Karoline EDTSTADLER
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, at the outset of my concluding remarks, let me express my sincere gratitude to the rapporteur of the European Parliament on Kosovo, Igor Šoltes. I would like to reiterate that stability in the neighbourhood and the enlargement of the European Union is a priority of the Austrian presidency. The EU will continue to assist Kosovo, including through its presence on the ground. And of course this applies also to visa liberalisation, but the Council’s deliberations are currently ongoing and the outcome cannot be pre—judged. The Austrian Presidency remains committed to moving the process forward. However, the primary responsibility for progress lies with Kosovo, its leaders, institutions and civil society. Reforms are crucial and they will require consensus across the political spectrum, and the political leaders to live up to their responsibilities for the good of Kosovo and of its citizens.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Rapporteur. – So what we have heard today, and what the report itself says, will not run out of work for Kosovo in the years to come, that is definitely, but I would like to say three things in conclusion.  I hope that the Council has also heard what we have said today, that Kosovo has fulfilled its conditions with regard to visa liberalisation, and there are arrangements in place to respect, of course, and if one party has complied with this, the other side is reasonably expected to do so.  Believe me, the people of Kosovo are already eagerly awaiting that they are not subject to discrimination further, and expect the European Union to fulfil its part of its obligations in the name of credibility.  Secondly, I think that the government in Pristina has heard today that we are not most enthusiastic about introducing or raising customs duties by 100 per cent as a means of resolving disputes between Belgrade and Pristina, and I hope that it will reconsider whether this is really an appropriate measure, because dispute resolution is taking place or resolved in a different way.  The last thing I would like to highlight is the environment, the environmental issues.  I think that we are also under-highlighting the problem of the environment in Kosovo, and I would like to draw attention here to the serious problem facing Pristina, which is air pollution, which is one of the highest in Europe.  And I think there is more to be done here in this area and also to invest resources to improve. This, of course, also has to do with power plants and polluters in the region, so I think that is one of the things where the European Union and Kosovo can work well together.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: I close the debate. The vote will take place on Thursday 29 November 2018.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: Before we get to the right item on the agenda, let me first welcome the delegation of the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia. I warmly welcome you, especially Deputy Foreign Minister Andrej Žernovski and the multi-party delegation of the Macedonian Parliament. (Applause) Thank you very much to you and to the Members for such a kind and warm welcome.  Dear Deputy Minister, I would like to thank you for your excellent work. Dear Members, I would like to thank you for your excellent work. I would like to assure you that the European Parliament will continue to support your country in its reform efforts, including the implementation of the Prespy Agreement, which sends a positive signal of agreement for the whole region.  If I can afford personal attention, then once as a student I had the pleasure of staying three months in Skopje on a scholarship, hence the city, and the Macedonian people are very close to me. Thank you for giving me this opportunity.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: The next item is the report by Ivo Vajgel, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, on the Commission's 2018 report on the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia (2018/2145(INI)) (A8-0341/2018).

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, thank you for these few of your personal kind words that you have given macedonia.  Because of the time, I'm going to shorten my intended performance a little bit and limit myself to the most essential things.  Macedonia's membership of the European Union, once the conditions are met and our promises to this country, which has been in the waiting room for too long, will certainly guarantee the most reliable future for the country, the present and future generations of its citizens, and will at the same time make a concrete contribution to the stability, security and progress of the entire region of South-East Europe.  The path to this moment of Macedonia has been steep, but we can see that the democratic will of the people prevailed in the country, a creative and responsible response of a policy that chose channels of communication, balancing in a multinational community, finding allies in the international community and new paths for strengthening fruitful and friendly relations with neighbouring countries.  The resolution we are dealing with today therefore emphasises the constructive role of the states mens of Macedonia, Greece and Bulgaria, who have sided with the inherited problems of the past and agreed on common interests in the future.  The government and parliament in Skopje are awaiting difficult tasks: first, the implementation of the agreement with the Greek Government on amending the Constitution and the relatedbriding of the long-standing conflict over the name, and then demanding work on reforms that will be a prerequisite for the opening of negotiations on the country's future membership of the European Union, I hope and believe, as early as next year in June.  All this will require creating a democratic, all-enthu veal in the country, the participation of all political parties, civil society and state institutions.  In line with the commitments made, the state will have to modernise the legislative procedures, the judiciary, ensure respect for the rule of law, open up space for truly free and plural media, protect journalists from pressure and violence, fight organised crime and corruption more effectively.  Systemic changes in the economy, improvements in the business environment, enforcement of contracts, introduction of control and transparency of public procurement data, State aid and the use of European Union funds and the like will be needed.  The resolution also noted the government's efforts to improve the living conditions of young people. The government is also calling for a comprehensive solution to the problem of long-term unemployment for women. It is important to keep the obligations under the Ohrid Agreement in full and fully respect the rights and protection of all national and other social minorities.  Dear Sirs, Macedonia has come after years of uncertainty and political crises to a situation where it can, with its own strength and will, pave the way for a more promising future as a member of the European Union and NATO. This is a journey from a complicated history, often peppered with violence, wars and conflicts in the Balkans, to a future of reciprocity and shared responsibility. It is right to ensure the full independence and functionality of the judiciary in the country, which investigates and penalises irregularities and violations of the laws of the past.  Unfortunately, the Hungarian authorities have intervened in an incomprehensible and unacceptable manner. There is more talk about this by the resolution and amendments tabled by the various parties in our Parliament.  I consider it appropriate to point out here that Macedonia, as a potential member for membership of the European Union, has always enjoyed the support of the European Parliament and that it can continue to count with this support.  I think it is right to also highlight the efforts made by the Commission, Commissioner Johannes Hahn and his team, who, also in cooperation with this House, have consistently sought and found a way to address the complex political contradictions that have hampered Macedonia's progress towards membership of the European Union.  I would also like to thank all the shadow rapporteurs for their extremely constructive and substantive cooperation. I do not thank you, Mr President, because I had six minutes, I used four.

name: Karoline EDTSTADLER
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, honourable Members, dear rapporteur, dear Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, and especially dear Minister, dear Ambassador.  Let me begin by recalling the Council conclusions of last June where the Council decided to respond positively to the progress made by the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia and set out the path towards opening accession negotiations in June 2019.  We welcome the European Commission’s necessary preparatory work. The country has overcome its deep political crises, including through the continued implementation of the Prespa Agreement, and has made substantial progress on the urgent reform priorities. This is extremely important for the country’s further progress.  Let me emphasise that even in the difficult political context, the government has taken significant steps to gradually restore a culture of compromise. It has reached out to all stakeholders, including the opposition, to strengthen democracy and the rule of law and to show a genuine desire to reform in an inclusive and transparent manner.  We welcome the changes in the tenor of atmosphere in the country. We also welcome the first concrete progress towards the restoration of the independence of the judiciary, the improvement of the work of the courts, and a follow-up to the work of the Special Prosecutor’s office, which has started to reverse the backsliding of previous years.  Let me here recall the need to find a suitable, sustainable solution for the continuation of the work of the Special Prosecutor’s office.  Moreover, we share your calls for the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia to intensify efforts to properly implement the judicial reform strategy and to make further efforts to address the outstanding recommendations. Sustained efforts are needed to ensure implementation of all commitments and to ensure that the judiciary can function independently. The Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia has achieved progress on the EU reform agenda and continues its efforts. We encourage it to deepen the reform momentum further, in particular showing real results in key rule of law areas such as the fight against corruption and organised crime, where it needs to further deliver. The institutions in charge of preventing and fighting corruption must have the necessary autonomy and the financial and human resources. The government must also implement other reforms, such as the reform of the intelligence and security services, and of the public administration. The EU will continue to follow these efforts very closely. We take note of the adoption of the public administration reform strategy and the public financial management reform programme and look forward to their implementation.  We encourage the government to continue to deepen the current reform momentum, including through Plan 18. We welcome the intention to continue working with the opposition parties, civil society and other stakeholders. Therefore, a constructive dialogue between all actors is required. We urge all parliamentary parties to put their divisions aside and work jointly on the common strategic goal of EU integration for the benefit of all citizens.  The implementation of the name agreement is one major step in this regard. Moreover, we welcome the holding of the Jean Monnet Dialogue, initiated by the European Parliament, aimed at improving the atmosphere and culture of compromise among the members of the Assembly as well as the work of the Assembly. We join you in applauding the country for reaching out to its neighbours in the spirit of good neighbourly relations. In particular, the conclusion of the Treaty on Friendship, Good Neighbourliness and Cooperation with Bulgaria, and the signature of the agreement on the name issue with Greece, have demonstrated the government’s determination to resolve all outstanding bilateral issues and build good neighbourly relations with all countries in the region.  Let me finally welcome the continued active participation and the constructive approach of the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia in different regional initiatives. Together these have contributed to an improved regional context.

name: Karoline EDTSTADLER
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to start by thanking the European Parliament, in particular the rapporteur, Ivo Vajgl, for this report. May I also say thank you for your kind words on behalf of my team, not only here in Brussels, but also on the ground in Skopje, and I would like to include in this our previous Ambassador, Aivo Orav, who also did an excellent and outstanding job. I would also like to use this opportunity to thank the Honourable Members of the Parliament, Knut Fleckenstein and previously John Howarth, but also Eduard Kukan, who together with Ivo Vajgl have shown their commitment to move, not only once but many times, to the country and to contribute to resolving the severe political crisis by engaging together with me in the facilitation of the provisional agreement. They also played a key role in the organising of the first Chamonix dialogue, which aims at creating an atmosphere of compromise among the political parties in the Parliament. These are only a few examples of how this House contributes to reinforcing democratic processes and, hopefully, standards. Let me underline that overall this draft reflects the main findings of our 2018 report and the latest developments have shown to be crucial. As you have rightly pointed out, the country has finally overcome its political crisis and is now firmly back on its Euro—Atlantic path. In the light of the latest developments, let me emphasise that the rule of law is a fundamental principle of the Union, for Member States and candidate countries alike. After years of backsliding, the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia has been making good progress in this area and it’s important that we collectively support this process. I have been impressed by the energy and efforts invested by the government to strengthen good neighbourly relations, in particular with the bilateral treaty with Bulgaria and later on with the name agreement reached with Greece. This historic agreement sets an example for the region and the Union as a whole. It shows that with vision, leadership and determination, the obstacles of the past can be overcome for once and for all. Last month, the Parliament took a courageous step by initiating the process of constitutional change. We now expect the national procedures for the implementation of the agreement to continue without delay. In our 2018 report, we stated that we were satisfied that the Pržino agreement has been largely implemented and that substantial progress has been achieved in the implementation of the Urgent Reform Priorities. Therefore, we recommended opening accession negotiations with the country. In June, our Member States acknowledged the progress achieved in advancing the EU reforms and set out the path towards opening accession negotiations in June 2019. It’s important that the current reform momentum continues to deepen, primarily in the interests of the citizens. Over the coming months we look forward to further progress, in particular in key areas such as judicial reform, the fight against corruption and organised crime, public administration reform and the oversight of intelligence services. All these areas have been identified in the so—called Plan 18 of the government. On a very personal note, I welcome the opening of accession talks with NATO and look forward to cooperating on key reforms of common interest. Finally, let me reiterate the Commission’s strong commitment to accompanying the country’s reform efforts to advance on its EU path, including through the technical explanation of the acquis.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, this report is being debated in a hopeful atmosphere and is based on broad political consensus. I think it’s a new spirit of mutual understanding with Macedonia’s neighbours that has opened the real EU and NATO perspective for this country. It is really high time for this, because in the meantime Macedonia has made impressive progress in aligning its legislation with the EU acquis.  Most importantly, there is now a positive political dynamic. Still, it is all about implementation. In the actual context it is vital for the government to prove the judiciary is truly independent and unbiased to avoid any doubts of possible political misuse of it.  The media environment has clearly improved but the progress has been modest and more should be done to free especially the investigative press from internal and external influences. To make any progress credible it should firmly rely on cross—party cooperation. Broad—based political and moral support for the reforms is the only way to further success.

name: Victor BOŞTINARU
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, Severna Makedonija has implemented robust, democratic reforms. They have taken a clear step towards good neighbourly relations and regional cooperation and the country is demonstrating every day its commitment to pursuing those efforts. Today it is considered the candidate country that has made the most progress in aligning its legislation and its policy with the EU acquis. I trust that the Prespa Agreement, like now the Pržino Agreement, will be ratified, as it has to be, and will send a much needed positive signal for stability and reconciliation in the region. Of course, there is no doubt this brave step by Prime Minister Zaev paves the way for the country’s European integration. This being said, I want to tell you something else. I am very worried about the Gruevski case. We urge Hungary to reject the asylum request and immediately return Mr Gruevski. What Hungary has done in this case is a dangerous precedent without any grounds for asylum. Never in the history of the EU has a Member State organised such an extraction operation. It is very important to make it clear that the European Parliament and Europe does not tolerate such actions.  (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – First, I congratulate the rapporteur. We have repeatedly talked about the treaty of friendship and neighborliness between Bulgaria and the Republic of Macedonia, which we welcome and for which we have worked very hard. However, what worries us and worries us is that on the part of Mr. Yev's government this treaty is not respected or observed extremely slowly. A number of measures had to be put in place long ago, such as the end of hate speech, textbooks in Bulgarian had to be issued, anti-Bulgarian speeches should not have been made. None of this has happened yet. This worries Bulgarian society. Mr. Yev is slowing down, promising everyone everything, but not fulfilling his commitments. And it will not lead to a good effect and a good end result.  Our call to Mr. Yev is to abide by this treaty if he wishes to continue to receive the support of both us as European representatives and the Bulgarian society as a whole.

name: Reinhard BÜTIKOFER
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, the Prespa Agreement is a key towards a more hopeful future for the Macedonian people. It is a vital step in building the bridges that the Western Balkans needs in order to overcome old divisions. It paves the way towards the EU integration of Macedonia and it helps Europe to continue shaping its common fate together, and to reject foreign interference. I thank all the members of the Macedonian Parliament who facilitated the progress that we are cherishing here, and I hope that next June we will be able to celebrate having a date for the opening of accession talks. The way forward is still going to be challenging but I’m optimistic that the hurdles can be overcome.

name: Sofia SAKORAFA
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, I have repeatedly stated that I am against the Agreement of the Prespas, because I believe that it is a text that cannot be implemented. It creates ambiguities that do not resolve disagreements, but highlight them. Already, the amendments to the Constitution passed by the Skopje Parliament are in breach of the agreement, as the ardent supporter of the agreement, former Foreign Minister Kotzias, points out. I have no doubt that the Greek side will do what it does not see, because some have invested their political survival in this agreement. The culmination of the expediency, however, is the paragraph of the resolution referring to the Skopje referendum. What does 'take the result into account', ladies and gentlemen? Not even 40% went to vote. The citizens of YROM turned their backs on the agreement, despite the blatant propaganda of both the European Commission and the Council in favour of a 'yes'. All that matters is the country's immediate accession to NATO at all costs, at the expense of both democracy and the peaceful coexistence of peoples in the region.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Mr President, the European Parliament's report on FYROM is yet another intervention by the European Union in all areas, in synergy with domestic interests and political forces. Economy, foreign policy, justice, education and more - all for the profitability of European monopolies! The country - overnight - is turning from unprepared to ready for membership. The reason, of course, is obvious: the report celebrates the country's accession to NATO, on the basis of the unacceptable agreement of the Prespas. That's why it was signed.  NATO, which has torn Yugoslavia apart, sows altruism by "divide and conquer", changes borders (see Kosovo) and is called a peacemaker by its flag bearer, the SYRIZA-ANEL government. It reveals the defenders of the agreement, but also its nationalist deniers, who do not say a word about NATO and the European Union, disorienting only with the nomenclature. They are on the same dangerous side: the American-NATO. The JRC is voting against the report and calling on the peoples of the region to fight in a coordinated fight against NATO and the European Union, which are sources of war and danger.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: – Mr President, I would first of all like to congratulate Colleague Ivo Vajgl on the report he is presenting this year. I think it is a report that expresses very well the state of Macedonia at the moment. Personally, I regret that Macedonia or North Macedonia, I think we can already call it this, has not received the signal to start negotiations as early as this summer. I think it was a mistake to postpone another year. In any case, the transformation from Macedonia to North Macedonia I think is the most important thing that has happened in the Western Balkans this year, and I hope that Greece will understand this and support what has happened in this candidate country. I also hope that the other Member States will also support Macedonia.  In particular, I do not think that what Prime Minister Orbán has done recently comes in support of Macedonia. I think it is a big mistake to grant political asylum to Gruevski. Moreover, I would like to remind you that the same Hungarian Prime Minister also granted asylum to a Romanian Member, who, like Gruevski, was definitively convicted and found asylum there. Here Budapest is becoming a home for the corrupt.

name: Knut FLECKENSTEIN
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which I believe that one thing is particularly clear to us about developments in Macedonia: we need courageous politicians and we need a courageous government. If you think something is right and you think it's positive for the country, then you have to want to enforce it when the wind blows in your face. This cannot be done by politicians who first look at the poll results in the morning and then act accordingly. Leadership was needed in this country, and leadership has been there. I wish the European Council would rise to a similar quality.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, Zaev and his company continue their unsyming challenges. In fact, in the new Constitution of Skopje, article 36, the so-called 'Macedonia' and so-called 'Macedonian people' references continue. Furthermore, the preamble to the new Skopje Constitution refers to the declaration of the first meeting of ASNOM - the well-known anti-fascist assembly - of 1944, which, Mr Hahn, explicitly mentions the right of self-determination of the so-called 'Macedonian nation' and the so-called 'Macedonian people' and requires the abolition of the borders which supposedly separate, as ASNOM says, brother from brother and Macedonian from Macedonians.  Therefore, with their new Constitution, Skopje is burning the name of our Macedonia and our history and expressing even more aggressively their altruism against Greece, blatantly violating even the despicable agreement of the Prespas. That is why Skopje cannot have any place in the European Union and I declare, once again, that I am opposed to any future accession of Skopje to the European Union.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: – Mr President, I welcome the report and also the references to the Prespa Agreement. This is an agreement for peace in the Balkans. It is a model for solving international relations, and it also takes political courage by both Mr Tsipras and Mr Zaev to proceed, because do you know what is happening in Greece? The nationalists and the extreme right and the neo-Nazis are accusing the government of treason and now they are trying to mobilise secondary school students. You know the system, the main slogan of the mobilisation: democracy is selling out Macedonia, they mean Greek Macedonia. Democracy is betraying Macedonia. That’s their slogan and those mobilisations are also supported – and I am referring to my colleagues from the Popular Party – those mobilisations of the extreme right are supported by new democracy. So you have to say to your cameras in new democracy not to play with fire.

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: – Let's reiterate – I support Macedonia's Euro-Atlantic future. I hope that the ratification process will be completed as soon as possible, both in the Parliament in Skopje and in Athens. This would allow the country to be admitted to THE EU as early as spring 2019 and start accession negotiations with the European Union as soon as possible. Macedonia has always been an integral part of Europe, as well as part of the Bulgarian heritage. All historical disputes must be addressed in the way of good neighbourliness, tolerance and historical justice. In this regard, I cannot hide my disappointment at the ongoing anti-Bulgarian statements in some Macedonian media. It's not just physical boundaries that need to be symbolic. Our common future, for which the governments of both Bulgaria and Macedonia work, but also the spiritual borders that were built by totalitarian regimes, the speech of hatred, all of this must be overcome on the path of European integration. Thank you very much and wish good luck to our friends and brothers from Vardar.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: – Dear Chairman, I congratulate my colleague Vajgl on a well-balanced Resolution that, above all, clearly notices and supports positive processes in Macedonia.  Macedonia is an example of the long-awaited good news from a region plagued by chronic but also some entirely new deficits. At the same time, we expect Macedonia to continue key reform processes, particularly in strengthening the rule of law. Unfortunately, this principle also requires recalling some Member States that have been part of the European Union for more than a decade. Skopje is required to meet serious preconditions not adhered to by one of the bloc's members before entering the bloc, as evidenced by Hungary's role in the Gruevski case. If we are to remain a credible community, respect for the rule of law must not be arbitrary.  I congratulate the Macedonian government on its progress in implementing the Prespa Agreement. I call on them to use this positive momentum to continue reforms in order to bring the possibility of a better life closer to all their fellow citizens as soon as possible by opening membership negotiations.

name: László TŐKÉS
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support I anticipate that the Hungary is a committed supporter of the Accession of the Western Balkan countries, including Macedonia, to Europe. We welcome the fact that accession negotiations are expected to start with the resolution of the so-called name dispute.  However, we reject the fact that, in connection with the unexpected Gruevski affair, the Socialists and the Greens are using the Macedonian country report to attack Hungary ideological background. The overthrow and conviction of former Prime Minister Nikola Gruevski is certainly due to the migration issue and the Soros lobby.  It can only be agreed with the report that the fight against corruption in Macedonia must be continued and that further efforts are needed to protect the judiciary from political interference. Justice cannot become a tool of politics.

name: Eduard KUKAN
text: – Madam President, may I extend my congratulations to Ivo Vajgl on this report. Macedonia made good progress over the last year, which has been well noted in the report. I am pleased to see the country moving ahead with many important initiatives and reforms. Also I would like to congratulate the government on the agreement with Greece. I strongly believe these efforts will open the doors for closer integration of the country and involve the European Union and NATO. At the same time the Macedonian Government needs to concentrate on continuous reforms in the area of the judiciary with the implementation of the judicial reform strategy, in the economy and in the fight against corruption and organised crime. It will be important not to lose this pace and come up with concrete results and records of accomplishments.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, I recently attended an important conference organised by the Equal Rights Association in Skopje where I met many brilliant, brave, LGBTIQ+ activists from across the Balkans. I really admire their courage and commitment as they defend the rights of LGBTIQ+ people in sometimes very hostile environments.  In the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, gender based discrimination and the situation of sexual minorities is particularly difficult. The legal framework has significant shortcomings in terms of non-discrimination, legal gender recognition and body autonomy. But the conference I attended was organised in partnership with the Socialist government of fYROM which demonstrated their political commitment to improving the situation of LGBTIQ+ people. It’s an excellent example of how governments can work with and support civil society, and we have to make human rights defenders and civil society support one of our priorities in the Balkans.  I know that the Macedonian parliament is currently discussing draft laws aimed at improving the situation of LGBTIQ+ people in the country, and so I hope these discussions will bring tangible results that better fulfil human rights.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Madam President, Madam Secretary of State, Commissioner, from the outset I want to say that I support the report. It's a reality-reflective report. Moreover, from the presentation of the Council representative, the Commissioner, the other colleagues, it was very clear that Macedonia has made progress.  I know the country very well, I live in the western part of Romania, I visited the country many times, I wanted to make investments there and I was surprised by the responsiveness of the government, the institutions, the way they work, the transparency. So I think it's worth going the European route, and I think we need to vote and not be late any longer, because any delay actually backs down a European road of some citizens who want it, they are very ambitious and wish them every success. You have my full support.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: – Madam President, I just want to remind everybody of something that the rapporteur has hinted at, which is what a tremendous sacrifice the citizens of northern Macedonia have made. It has demanded a tremendous amount of energy and no other single European country would accept to change the name of a country, which is so deeply connected with identity. You can see from the reactions here in Parliament from the nationalists as to how this affected it.  So now I really beg the Council, really beg, to fulfil our part of our obligation and start opening the negotiations as soon as possible. The Commission has hinted it will do it. Parliament will do it. It’s up to the Council now, because if we let these people down we will lose every credibility and it will make a mess in the region of outrageous proportions. (Applause)

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Madam President, it would be good for the European Parliament not to be under any illusions and, above all, not to express its wishes as a reality. This evil state, created only to serve the expansionist plans of a communist dictator, as well as the very ideal of the so-called "Macedonianism" of its Slav inhabitants, will not enter the European Union. Even if, at the moment, in Greece, a traitorous government tries to impose the Agreement of the Prespas, it will soon be a thing of the past, as will the agreement itself. Everything else mentioned in the report is meaningless, as before their repudiation of any reference to the Greek name of Macedonia there can be no other discussion. Finally, since your satisfaction with the result of the referendum is mentioned in the text, the hypocrisy of the Union is striking, since you very conveniently forget the fact that the vast majority of citizens never came to vote. The Agreement of the Prespas is therefore a dead agreement which will never be implemented, since both peoples are opposed to it and only Berlin, Brussels and their local submissives support it.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: – Dear Chairman, last week I was a guest at an event organised by the Macedonian national minority in Croatia. When someone in the hall shouted, "Hey, you who love Macedonia!‟, I answered because I love Macedonia. This does not mean that I am not aware of the weaknesses that Macedonia has and that needs to be worked on from within.  For most of them, the causes should be sought at the point of their creation, but I am convinced that these weaknesses would not be so strong today if the EU had been fair to Macedonia. Macedonia, neither guilty nor indebted, has become held hostage to the unreasonable policies of the European Union, which has been keeping one of its members' side for 10 years, thus destroying Macedonia's European perspective and future. I am sorry that this report does not give an objective account of the situation and does not offer a self-critical overview of the failings by the European Union.  I believe that it is not too late for the mistake to be corrected and for negotiations to be opened for Macedonia, and to express support to the citizens of Macedonia in order to overcome the difficulties and implement the necessary reforms and ensure stability in the region.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: – Dear Chairman, I would like to address my colleagues on the balcony and colleagues. In 2000 in Zagreb I had the opportunity to host the Office for European Integration of the Macedonian Government and we started, Croatia and Macedonia together, the European path.  Dear friends and friends, I'm here, and you're on the balcony. It's a shame it didn't work out together. I also expected Croatia to enter at least together with Romania and Bulgaria into the European Union, but we failed. I'm sorry that you're still not sitting with us, but I want to really, and I believe, that you will be able to fulfill that homework that is in front of you, the ambitious plans that the Government has and hopefully, a smart opposition, will allow North Macedonia, hopefully soon, to open all roads and finally come here, where you belong.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, State Secretary. In the coming months, the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia will have to make important decisions concerning the finalisation of the process of constitutional changes on the one hand and the continuation of the implementation of key reforms on the other. This will require focus and determination to fundamentally improve the lives of citizens.  I count on all political forces to put the interests of the country first and support the common strategic goal of Euro-Atlantic integration. In that respect I think it's time that everyone starts to accept the outcome of the referendum. Just last Sunday we had several referenda in Switzerland, usually considered one of the role models of mature democracy, and there the turnout rate is usually below 50% but nobody criticises or challenges the democratic result and the consequences. In that respect I can only urge everybody to start to respect the people's vote and the people's thinking by participating in a meaningful way in such a referendum. The Commission, in any case, will support and continue to support the reform efforts in every way we can in order to prepare the country to open accession negotiations.  So I count on the support of this House to remain engaged and to send common messages of encouragement to the country and in particular to all your sister parties, but even more importantly, to all the citizens of the country. More than ever, the Union needs to continue to show its unity and fight for our fundamental values and principles.

name: Karoline EDTSTADLER
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, let me thank once again Parliament’s rapporteur on the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, Mr Vajgl, for his excellent work.  The EU attaches great importance to moving forward with the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, and we hope to see continued progress. Reforms are crucial and will require the political leaders to live up to their responsibilities. The EU remains fully engaged and stands ready to support the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia in its efforts.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: Rapporteur. – Honourable Chair, I would like to thank all my colleagues who have taken part in this very interesting debate.  I have come to the point that there is still a growing belief in the European Parliament that Macedonia's membership of the European Union will add value to our Union, that there will also be an additional guarantee of the stability and security of this part of Europe.  We have also heard some dissonan opinions today, and I would like to comment on these opinions only by not understanding that anyone finds it more favourable if it has a neighbour with whom it has open problems and is arguing, rather than having a neighbour with whom it has common goals for the future and common interests, especially for young generations.  I would like to say what many colleagues have concluded today is Macedonia, that it is Macedonian policy, that the Macedonian people were prepared to accept quite an important, great sacrifice, many sacrifices, by agreeing to really difficult conditions: changing the constitution and changing the name of the country.  But they have done so, and it is gratifying that the Macedonian opposition (including with the support of the fraternial and sister parties in this House) has also realised that this opportunity, which may be unique and inimitable in the history of Macedonia and its people, must be supported.  I would therefore also like to address Macedonian politicians, members of the co-host, from this place to participate actively in the ratification of the agreement and to help open the door to the European Union and also to NATO for their country's membership of these organisations.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday 29 November 2018. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. – In connection with the Commission's country report in Macedonia, we are obliged to talk about Viktor Orban again. It must be said that former Prime Minister Nikola Gruevski did not simply escape justice, but was smuggled out by Hungarian diplomats at the personal behest of Viktor Orban. The action was condemned by a significant part of the Hungarian public, the opposition and the remaining free press. This is Orban's own, which once again shows why it was right that the EP voted in favour of the Sargentini report. Viktor Orban has once again ruled out the rule of law, not only at home, but also in the Balkans. It has again used public bodies in an impermissible manner to carry out and cover the infringements it has invented. Now Orban's mafia government is wraps a politician legally convicted of abuse of power in cotton wool. Even in Viktor Orbán's Hungary, the foreign ministry's escape operation is a crime. The fact that there are no consequences proves once again that the Hungary is not a rule of law today.  On behalf of all hungarian democratic citizens, I demand that the Hungarian Government release Nikola Gruevski to Macedonia; follow the Macedonian, Albanian and Serbian governments for illegally using the Hungarian diplomatic corps. I call on Parliament to support the S&D motions condemning gruevski's escape; I call on the European People's Party to draw a conclusion from Orban's recent violations and to take the long-delayed decision to exclude fidesz from the Christian Democratic Party family.

name: Bogusław SONIK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Macedonian MEPs approved the government's proposal to amend the constitution in order to implement the agreement signed in June with Greece. Under it, the country will change its name and become officially the Republic of North Macedonia. This will end the 27-year dispute with Athens and open the door for Macedonians to join the EU and NATO. Macedonia is considered the candidate country that has made the most progress in aligning its legislation with the EU acquis.  Despite this positive opening, I must express my concern that former Macedonian Prime Minister Nikola Gruewski, who fled his country for fear of being imprisoned, has been granted refugee status in Hungary. In Macedonia, he was convicted by a final verdict for exerting pressure on public procurement officials, and five other investigations are underway against him. It is difficult to understand why the authorities in Budapest accepted his request, considering that he was being persecuted for political reasons and granted asylum to a politician who had acted against Macedonia's accession to the EU and NATO.  I fully support the Commission's recommendation and the Council's decision that accession negotiations should start in June 2019. The smooth opening of the monitoring and negotiation process is likely to accelerate the pace of reforms in Macedonia even further.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: in writing. – This report reconfirms that the fYR of Macedonia is a functioning state of law, and has been making important progress in reforming its judicial system to deal with – among other things – corruption—related crimes. That is why in this debate we cannot avoid facing the ongoing Gruevski scandal: the fact that a member of the EU – the Hungarian authorities, acting upon orders from Viktor Orbán himself – have actively assisted the illegal escape of the former Macedonian Prime Minister, and granted asylum to this legally convicted criminal. Orbán’s unprecedented provocation, in total contempt of international – and EU – law deliberately damages European interests and jointly agreed CFSP and enlargement policy decisions. The Gruevski scandal raises the responsibility of those who just recently decided to keep Orbán in their ranks, and – naively, or cynically – took his promise to behave more democratically. Well, Mr Weber, you cannot hold this actual dictator on a short leash. What you got from your political friend Orbán is a slap in the face, another humiliating, anti—European provocation, making the PPE an accomplice to his – and Gruevski’s – illegal actions... and hopefully the conviction that it is time to act now, to get rid of this source of embarrassment.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: The next item is the 2018 report by Knut Fleckenstein on Albania (2018/2147(INI) – A8-0334/2018).

name: Knut FLECKENSTEIN
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Madam Secretary of State, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for the work she has I am pleased that the debate on the Albanian report falls on Albania's Independence Day today, and I would like to offer my warmest congratulations to the people of Albania and the diaspora, certainly on your behalf. Before tomorrow's vote, I would like to begin by thanking the shadow rapporteurs from the other groups for their very constructive cooperation. I have tried to take on board the main points of the various groups. I am therefore confident that, in tomorrow's vote, we will achieve a great deal of agreement on the content of the report. I would like to refer to the main messages that we, as the Committee on Foreign Affairs, want to send with this resolution to our Albanian partners, but also to the Council and the Commission. It is now more than four years since Albania was officially recognised by the EU as a candidate for eu membership. We make it clear that this must also be reflected in the practical reality and support the European Commission's recommendation to open accession negotiations with Albania. At the same time, we take note of the Council's decision before the summer and welcome the clear path shown in the start of these negotiations. We expect – and I think we can expect it – for the Albanian Government to use the time until then to make all the arrangements for the negotiations. However, we also expect the Council to stand by its word and take the appropriate decision in June next year, because anything else would be incomprehensible and counterproductive in terms of the role and credibility of the European Union in the region. Of course, this report is also, and above all, a contribution to the Albanian Government and the opposition in terms of the work that still needs to be done in the country and the work that has been done so far. It is important for me to point out that these reform efforts must always have one objective: to improve the practical reality of life for the people on the ground and not to do good for a Commissioner or a Member or A MEPs in general. In view of what has already been achieved, it must be said that Albania has earned the opening of the accession negotiations by implementing the key priorities required – in particular, the very ambitious judicial reform, which goes beyond what was originally requested by the Commission. They show clear results: the vetting process in the justice sector is in full swing and not only shows initial results, but also has a deterrent effect for the future. It could be a good example for all governments in the region that are still looking for ways to carry out their judicial reform. Let me conclude with two points: we urgently need electoral reform. It is essential that this reform is carried out in line with the OSCE recommendation, even before the 2019 local elections. And I am, still, very hopeful and hopeful that I can remain so, that the two chairmen of the ad hoc commission of the Democratic Party and the Socialist Party will find a common way to make a good proposal. We should certainly support them in this. We must encourage Albania to continue along the path of reform that has been taken, because that is precisely the way to consolidated democratic institutions and to a functioning rule of law that leads to the EU. I look forward to tomorrow's vote.

name: Karoline EDTSTADLER
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, honourable Members, dear Commissioner, dear rapporteur, let me begin by recalling the Council conclusions of June 2018, in which the Council decided to respond positively to the progress made by Albania and set out the path towards opening accession negotiations in June 2019. We welcome the Commission’s necessary preparatory work. We concur with your view that Albania has made steady progress in addressing the five key priorities. These are positive signals which show that Albania is on the right path, and we strongly encourage it to continue its efforts. Moreover, Albania is implementing a comprehensive justice reform, as the rapporteur already mentioned; the re-evaluation process for judges and prosecutors – the so-called vetting – has started to deliver under the oversight of the international monitoring operation. We encourage Albania to build on the progress made and to pursue the justice reform in order to achieve increased independence, accountability and professionalism of the judicial system. Establishment of the independent judicial structures, as provided for by the constitutional reform, should be finalised. Albania has worked towards the establishment of a solid track record in the fight against corruption and organised crime. However, it is important that the Government delivers tangible and sustainable results, including against the cultivation and trafficking of drugs. Dismantling organised groups remains an important challenge. We commend Albania for its close cooperation with external law enforcement agencies. We welcome its participation in international police operations and joint investigations, in particular with EU Member States, and urge it to be even more proactive in international police cooperation. On elections, as set out in your report, we expect Albania to address the outstanding OSCE/ODIHR recommendations, amend its electoral code and introduce measures for further enhancing the independence, impartiality, professionalism and capacity of election administration.  We emphasise the need for legislative and policy measures to reinforce the protection of human rights and anti-discrimination policies, including the equal treatment of all minorities and access to rights for persons belonging to them throughout the country. Albania has made efforts to put in place effective measures to counter the high flow of manifestly unfounded asylum applications lodged to Albanian citizens. These measures need to be further pursued with the countries most affected until sustained results are achieved.  We welcome Albania’s constructive engagement in regional cooperation and good-neighbourly relations, which remain an essential element of the enlargement process. I equally want to commend Albania for its full alignment with the EU’s common foreign and security policy. Today in our discussion we are focusing on Albaniaʼs progress in 2017, on which we have a very similar opinion. However, and more generally, I would like to stress the importance of tangible and sustainable results focusing in particular on the rule of law: this will take Albania closer to the opening of accession talks.

name: Karoline EDTSTADLER
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would also like to congratulate the Albanians on their national day, at least as long as we are still on the same day. I would also like to thank the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs for their work leading up to this resolution. Clearly, significant coordination efforts resulted in a document which, in my view, is a very balanced one. The resolution captures the progress that Albania has made in the past years and it highlights well the challenges that lie ahead in order to move the country closer to the Union. Starting with the progress, Albania continues to advance in many crucial areas. The vetting of judges and prosecutors has proven to be a thorough and fair process and continues to yield concrete and tangible results. The ongoing judicial reform is a major demand from Albanian citizens and its successful implementation will foster public trust in state institutions, enhance the credibility and effectiveness of the justice system, and contribute to the embedding of the rule of law throughout the country. We cannot compromise on quality in this very important process and we are monitoring it thoroughly. As regards current challenges, constructive political dialogue and cooperation across parties is crucial for further advancing in delicate areas such as the restructuring of the judiciary, as well as the electoral reform process. Cross—party consensus is necessary to guarantee that outstanding OSCE/ODHIR recommendations are met. This includes, in particular, the transparency of party financing, as well as the independence and professionalism of the electoral administration.  Strengthening the administrative capacity of institutions is essential, not only for the successful implementation of reforms, but also for the effective preparation of EU accession negotiations. That is why we continue to encourage Albania to pursue public administration reform by adhering to the highest standards. Progress in the fight against organised crime and corruption also continues to be necessary for Albania to further advance on its path towards EU accession. Further achievements are expected towards establishing a solid direct record of proactive investigations, prosecutions and convictions in the fight against organised crime and corruption at all levels.  Good neighbourly relations and regional stability are essential elements of the stabilisation and association process. Albania is an important actor in promoting regional cooperation. We appreciate in this regard the full convergence of foreign and security policy between Albania and the European Union, as already highlighted by previous speakers.  The Commission maintains its strong commitment to support Albania’s efforts to advance further on its path towards European integration.  I look forward to continuing the fruitful cooperation with the European Parliament in all of these matters in the months ahead.

name: Eduard KUKAN
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, I want to express my appreciation for the work of Mr Fleckenstein on this report and the very good cooperation of the shadow rapporteurs. I welcome the Commission's recommendation for opening the accession negotiations as well as the Council decision to reevaluate the progress made by Albania next year. Albania has achieved good progress in the implementation of justice reform, which is crucial for the further integration process. It has also proved its readiness to go through other difficult reforms. This progress was possible only through constructive political dialogue and cooperation with all the major political parties from the government and the opposition.  Therefore, I can only strongly encourage all political actors in Albania to work together on the consolidation of reforms across all five priorities. I hope this will be also the case in upcoming electoral reforms. Albania is indeed our key partner in the region. We should fully appreciate its full alignment with EU common foreign and security policy and active participation in the regional initiatives.

name: Eugen FREUND
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, Commissioner, Secretary of State, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her work on the work she has I am happy to say this again, as I said about Albania the last time: it is astonishing how positively the country has developed over the past two decades. At the beginning of the 1990s, thousands of people fled across the Mediterranean to Italy. Today, Albania is a serious candidate for accession of the European Union. The latest report in particular notes that the country is making progress in terms of the political criteria and the five main priorities for accession to the EU. Nevertheless, Albania has to be a benchmark for all EU candidate countries: the highest standards must be achieved. All doubts must be removed that Albania is actually leading the necessary reforms to the end. And before we enlarge the European Union, we must give serious thought to how we strengthen the European institutions, because in a larger Union, decision-making must not be restricted.

name: Eleni THEOCHAROUS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Madam President, as shadow rapporteur for the report, I have not raised any objections to helping the work of the rapporteur, whom I deeply appreciate. Much has been said about Albania's progress, but - unfortunately for all of us - the day before yesterday Rama, in a single sentence he said in Pristina, neutralised everything; It is clear that Albania's corrupt government is continuing its criminal action against the Greek minority. Greeks live in fear, deprived of all human rights, suffer the barbaric behaviour of the Albanian authorities and their property is trampled on by the state itself, while the education of children and the use of the Greek language are hindered. Colonization, Islamization, demographic change and ethnic cleansing are what Greeks experience every day in the North Continent. Such a state has no place in the European Union and any accession process must be stopped immediately, until the rights of Greeks in a democratic Albania are respected.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: on behalf of the ALDE Club. – Dear Chairman, I must say that I am extremely concerned about the situation in Albania and what is albania's European path.  Namely, the meetings we have regularly with the delegation in the Albanian Parliament and in our parliament, and the last meeting we had in Brussels here showed that there is a really very divided country. I can understand that the opposition is leaving parliament, that it is leaving because I did it in the 1990s, but that it leaves the session with our delegation, I can't understand that because I think if they really want to join the European Union, if they want to be part of the European Parliament, then they have to sit and talk to us, not get up and leave the session.  That is why I am concerned about the political culture and political relations with Albania in the coming years.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Madam President, despite the report's attempt to make the situation in Albania more beautiful, that country is far from meeting the Copenhagen criteria. It does not apply the principles of the rule of law and therefore fundamentally violates the rights of the Greek minority in the North Continent. Moreover, the culmination of this situation is the murder of Aristotle Gouma in 2010 and, a month ago, Konstantinos Katsifas. In fact, the Albanian authorities went so far as to ask the parents of the deceased, the murdered, where they found the money to make his funeral. He was insulted by the Prime Minister of Albania himself and, moreover, every night, to terrorize his compatriots, they shoot at night and interrupt, unnecessarily, for twelve hours the electricity of minority villages. At a time when such a situation prevails, Albania has no right to claim its membership of the European Union and we must prevent this at all costs.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Madam President, I welcome this report and congratulate the rapporteur, and recognition of the progress achieved by Albania over the last year. While examining the state of EU-Albanian relations I consider it essential to emphasise Albania’s solid commitment to the European Union integration process, and in line with this I support the opening of its accession negotiations in 2019. The opening of negotiations will give us a tangible incentive for further developments in the positive perspective for the Western Balkans region as a whole. In this respect, I share the opinion that Albania needs to keep the reform momentum, and to intensify its efforts to consolidate the reform achieved and to continue preparing for EU membership obligations across all chapters. Therefore further strengthening is needed, especially of the administrative capacity of institutions and bodies responsible for the implementation of accession-related reforms, for the transposition of EU-legislation into national law, and for the preparations to be made for EU accession negotiations. To fight corruption has to be also a high... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: Madam President, one way to assess the degree of respect for the rule of law and human rights in practice is to manage minorities. In Albania, the largest ethnic minority, recognised by Albania itself, is the Greek minority, which is subject to national clarification for which, unfortunately, no reference is made to the report.  As the European Union, we must encourage Albania towards democracy and we must also push it to escape Erdogan's Turkish influence. But after the passion of Turkey's anti-European policy - which some here even now call a 'strategic partner' - we hope to have learned our lesson from corrupt governments and corrupt rulers. We must treat them with effective tools and demand that their criteria and obligations be met;

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, today was completed a month after the murder of Konstantinos Katsifas, in the North Continent, by the Albanian police. The provocations, threats, intimidation and intimidation of the Albanian security forces continue daily against the Greek ethnic minority of the North Continent. An internationally recognized minority which, under the Corfu Protocol of 1914, has acquired the inalienable right of autonomy. Moreover, despite the rhetoric of the European Union, the Albanian authorities continue to seize the property of the Northerners, and it was only yesterday that Edi Rama made the MEPs themselves sick. Measures must therefore be taken against Albania and all its funding and accession path suspended until it begins to respect the rights of the Greek ethnic minority in the North Continent. I declare, once again, my complete opposition to any future accession of Albania to the European Union.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: Madam President, the report on Albania is of particular importance with a view to the opening of negotiations on its accession to the European Union in June 2019. However, I do not share the report's optimism about the fight against corruption and organised crime in this country. Much more needs to be done from an Albanian point of view, particularly with regard to the cultivation and trafficking of drugs.  The discrimination against the Greek minority, which has recently been characteristically manifested, must also be stopped by the excessive and unnecessary use of deadly force by the Albanian police to arrest Konstantinos Katsifas. I do not understand, moreover, how it is justified for a candidate country to ban entry to MEPs, as in the case of Eleni Theocharous. For these reasons, I shall vote white on the report.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Madam President, the Albanian State is burdened with the cold-blooded and premeditated murder of the Greek NorthernEr Konstantinos Katsifas. I cannot, as a Greek MEP, agree to any kind of assessment as long as Edi Rama, the moral perpetrator of the murder, has not been held accountable for this crime. Moreover, as long as Albania continues to oppress the Greek minority, to scare and threaten the Northern continents, to tear down churches and to try to eliminate the presence of Hellenism in the North Continent, no good neighbourhood can exist.  Albania itself has accepted the Corfu Protocol, under which the Greek minority is entitled to autonomy. For over 100 years, Albania has refused to comply. Moreover, it has created conditions such that only by integrating the North Continent into the national trunk will the planned genocide against the Greeks be avoided. Finally, the Albanian Government, through Prime Minister Rama, demonstrated how much it counts the Union and the institutions when - with pavement expressions - it wondered how MEPs dare to express an opinion on Albanian issues. Obviously, Albania is a state hostile to my country, and its accession to the Union sounds rather like a bad joke to me.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, State Secretary, honourable Members, thank you for this debate. Albania is expected to advance on the rule of law reforms to move forward on the path towards the Union, but first and foremost, it needs to deliver progress for the daily benefit of all its citizens across the country. We trust that advancing on the rule of law will progressively result in a better business environment which is crucial to create more jobs and hence foster socio-economic stabilisation.  The observations in your resolution provide very good guidance for Albania in all these areas. However, I would like to reiterate one issue that concerns regional cooperation and good neighbourly relations. I think everybody should aim at calming down the situation, especially concerning the Kosovo-Serbia relations. There is no alternative to dialogue and normalisation. This is in the interest of the entire region and its EU perspective, therefore everybody across the region should refrain from unhelpful statements that could be seen as inflammatory or taking sides. To conclude, I would like to reiterate that the Commission will continue to support Albania while monitoring results thoroughly. Concrete results will not only bring the country closer to the Union but also guarantee that all Albanian citizens can rely on a functioning democratic state that successfully provides welfare, security and opportunities. The EU reform agenda requires broad political support which needs to be matched by concrete efforts from all the parties to engage in constructive dialogue. I hope that all political actors in Albania will also work with this important objective in mind, in particular in the forthcoming months.

name: Karoline EDTSTADLER
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, again, let me express my sincere gratitude for the excellent work and commitment of Parliament’s rapporteur on Albania, Mr Fleckenstein. Albania has taken many steps in the right direction and the reform efforts are bearing fruits. We expect the political leaders to overcome internal difficulties and join their forces on advancing on the EU path. In this regard we count on the continued support of the European Parliament to call on all leaders of Albania to cooperate in good faith. Decisive action is now needed to make the required progress. The EU will continue to assist Albania.

name: Knut FLECKENSTEIN
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which I would just like to make three comments. One comment is about minorities. We have agreed that we do not specify minority rights according to individual minorities, but that they must apply to all and that they should therefore also be written down for all. Nevertheless , and you know this – there will be a motion that will deal precisely with the killing of the Albanian citizen of Greek origin and will ask questions. But talking about ethnic cleansing is definitely going too far for me. Secondly. I am also sometimes afraid, Mr Jakovic, and I wonder whether a country might not be able to join the EU, because the opposition is not yet ready. We only know this when the government does nothing, does not make reforms and so on. But sometimes we also need to remind the opposition a little bit that it has not only rights, but also tasks, and it has to fulfil them in order to give the country as a whole a face that also makes it possible to enter. And, Commissioner Hahn, if I have understood you correctly – as you have put it very diplomatically – you may have just referred to recent events. And here, too, I agree with you: if you have big hands, you can touch big tasks, but maybe you should let some finger games stay.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday 29 November 2018.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: The next item is the 2018 report by Charles Tannock on Montenegro (2018/2144(INI) – A8-0339/2018).

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, this report as ever seeks to offer as wide and broad a commentary as possible on Montenegro. On the whole, we see a picture of that country progressing well, with 31 of the 35 chapters now open in total. The government of Montenegro remains positively engaged with the negotiation process and there continues to exist a strong consensus, both in the political arena and in terms of public opinion, for the Euro-Atlantic integrationist agenda. Obviously, events during the 2016 parliamentary elections, however, show that there is no room for complacency, given the efforts of a big third country to exploit the fears and concerns of a small minority. Court proceedings concerning the coup plot continue, and whilst we wait to see the final judgments, I have little doubt that events played out in the way that the prosecution is now arguing. The general political climate has improved since then and the handling of this case has proved the robustness of Montenegro, strengthening democracy and legal systems. I am pleased to see that much of the opposition have now returned to the parliament, and I strongly urge the remaining boycotting parties to do so as well. As a first step, it would be good to see all political parties participating in the working group on reform of the law on the judicial council. Furthermore, during the reporting period, we have seen presidential elections that passed smoothly and fully in line with the ODIHR/OSCE fundamental freedoms. Clearly there is room for improvement in some of the state electoral commission’s working methods, and my report calls for reinforcing the transparency and professionalisation of the electoral administration with that end in mind. Despite the overall level of progress, there remain concerns about the media landscape in Montenegro. Three successive Commission reports have concluded that no progress has been made in the area of freedom of expression and media freedom – an important issue to satisfy the benchmark requirements of Chapters 23 and 24 of the acquis. Ongoing disputes about the role of RTCG and changes to the members of its council and leading executives have had a negative effect on public confidence in the network's editorial integrity. The attack against Olivera Lakić in May of 2018 has highlighted again the plight of journalists and acts of violence against journalists. We cannot forget that this is the second attack against her. Given her involvement in investigating cases of corruption, such incidents highlight the continuing need to fight organised crime and corruption in all its forms and at all levels. On a more positive note, engagement and cooperation in the fields of CFSP and CSDP remain very positive. Montenegro has for many years been fully compliant in these areas, and its well deserved accession to NATO in June of last year will only cement that cooperation. I particularly welcome Montenegro’s full alignment with all the sanctions regimes, particularly those concerning Russia. I should also say a few words on the elements related to the environment in this report, which has been given a much stronger focus than in previous years. As my two amendments demonstrate, this is being pushed by other political groups in this House, and to my mind has given the subject a slightly disproportionate coverage in relation to the overall balance of my report. As a self-declared ecological state, it could be argued that Montenegro deserves to be held to higher standards than others. However, we must account for the budgetary pressures that this small country faces in this regard, and we cannot seek to be too prescriptive, particularly when calls go beyond the requirements of the acquis communautaire. To conclude, ahead of the wider debate: for some nine years as rapporteur for Montenegro, I have referred to it as the ‘good news story’ of the Western Balkans. It remains today the leading EU accession candidate, but I hope that it will not be too long until we see it progress from the good news story of negotiations to the success story of accession as an EU Member State.

name: Karoline EDTSTADLER
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, Montenegro remains the front—runner in the accession process and has made further progress over the past years, as already mentioned in detail by the rapporteur. With the institutional framework complete and the legal framework largely in place, the entire rule of law system should now deliver more tangible results and a strengthened and sustainable track record. Progress in particular on the rule of law and fundamental rights chapters, as set out in the negotiation framework, will continue to determine the pace of accession negotiations overall. Therefore, Montenegro should now focus its reform efforts on meeting the interim benchmarks for Chapters 23 and 24 and on implementing the respective action plans. The Council strongly encourages Montenegro to demonstrate real results in the fight against corruption and organised crime, money laundering and trafficking in human beings, including through effective investigations, prosecutions and final convictions, and to improve the seizure and confiscation of criminal assets. Recent attacks against journalists highlight the urgent need for the authorities to guarantee a safe climate conducive to freedom of expression and the independence of the media. On economic reforms, the Council has taken positive note of the continuous economic growth and has encouraged Montenegro to take measures to ensure fiscal sustainability, decrease the high public debt, reduce the trade deficit, advance reforms in important areas, such as public procurement and labour market, and improve the business environment. With regard to elections, Montenegro’s authority needs to address all irregularities reported by international observers. Returning the political debate to the parliament remains the responsibility of all parties. The Council has warmly welcomed Montenegro’s continued positive role in further developing regional cooperation and advancing good neighbourly relations, strongly commended it also for its consistent cooperation on foreign policy issues and, in particular, for its continuous full alignment with the EU Common Foreign and Security Policy. The clear messages in your draft resolutions are well appreciated. It is clear that Montenegro has homework to do. Montenegro will have to intensify its focus on implementing reforms with determination and on fulfilling all benchmarks. To conclude, let me use this opportunity to assure you that we, as the Presidency, will continue to support Montenegro in its reform process and will do our utmost to move the accession negotiations forward. We also count on Montenegro to do its part and maintain the reform momentum.

name: Karoline EDTSTADLER
